bushijiushiPattern.description: Pattern indicating there are only 2 possiblities, similar to "If it's not X then it must be Y".

examples.zh: 他整天不是打游戏就是睡觉。
examples.en: All day, if he's not playing games, he's sleeping.

examples.zh: 他们约会不是去咖啡馆就是去电影院。
examples.en: When they go on dates, if it's not to a coffee shop, then it's to the movie theater.

examples.zh: 我买的衣服不是大就是小，都不能穿。
examples.en: The clothes that I bought are either too big or too small, I can't wear any of them.

examples.zh: 她穿的衣服不是LV就是Gucci！
examples.en: If the clothes that she wears aren't Louis Vuitton, then they're Gucci!

examples.zh: 他不是美国人，就是英国人。
examples.en: If he's not American then he's British.

examples.zh: 他们不是住八楼，就是住十楼。
examples.en: If they don't live in building 8, then they must live in building 10.

examples.zh: 我们班不是韩国人，就是日本人，没有欧美人。
examples.en: our class is all Korean and Japanese, there are no Europeans or Americans.

examples.zh: 他每天不是读书就是写文章，不干别的。
examples.en: Every day if he's not studying then he's writing essays, he doesn't do anything else.

genguobuquPattern.description:
Pattern indicating that a person is made to intentionally feel uncomfortable.
    It is used in spoken language, and requires a person-word (ex 我) between 跟 and 过不去.
    和 can also be used instead of 跟.

examples.zh: 别人迟到领导不批评，为什么专门批评我呢？这不是跟我过不去吗？
examples.en: Other people show up late and the boss doesn't criticize them, why does he just criticize me? He's intentionally picking on me, isn't he?

examples.zh: 这并不是你一个人的错，忘了它吧，别跟自己过不去。
examples.en: This isn't just your fault on your own. Forget about it. Don't beat yourself up.

examples.zh: 你干嘛总找我岔，总是跟我过不去啊！
examples.en: Why are you always making difficulty for me?

examples.zh: 我没跟你过不去啊，是你跟我过不去吧！
examples.en: I am not making difficulty for you, you are making difficulty for me instead!

examples.zh: 别提她妈妈的身体，你想跟她过不去吗？
examples.en: Don't talk about the health of her mother. Do you want to make difficulties for her?

examples.zh: 别跟我提那件事，否则你就是跟我过不去。
examples.en: Don't talk about this thing any more, or you will make a difficulty for me.

meiyouPattern.description: The verb 有 (yǒu) is negated differently from ordinary verbs. Rather than placing 不 (bù) before it as with other verbs, you must use 没 (méi) to negate the verb 有 (yǒu). 没有 (méiyǒu) can be shortened to 没 (méi) without altering its meaning.

examples.zh: 我没有问题。
examples.en: I don't have any questions.

examples.zh: 我们现在没有钱。
examples.en: We don't have money now.

examples.zh: 他没有工作吗？
examples.en: Does he not have a job?

examples.zh: 他们没有爸爸妈妈。
examples.en: They don't have parents.

examples.zh: 我们在北京没有房子。
examples.en: We don't have a house in Beijing.

examples.zh: 你爸爸没有手机吗？
examples.en: Does your dad not have a cell phone?

examples.zh: 你们在上海没有朋友吗？
examples.en: Do you not have friends in Shanghai?

examples.zh: 我的老师现在没有男朋友。
examples.en: My teacher doesn't have a boyfriend now.

examples.zh: 他们都没有电脑吗？
examples.en: Do they all not have computers?

examples.zh: 这个周末你们都没有时间吗？
examples.en: Do you all not have time this weekend?

examples.zh: 我没有车。
examples.en: I don't have a car.

examples.zh: 我没钱。
examples.en: I don't have money.

examples.zh: 你没男朋友吗？
examples.en: Do you not have a boyfriend?

examples.zh: 你们没车吗？
examples.en: You don't have a car?

examples.zh: 老板现在没时间。
examples.en: The boss doesn't have time right now.

examples.zh: 我没工作，我老公也没工作。
examples.en: I don't have a job. My husband doesn't have a job either.

yijingLePattern.description: Pattern used to express something has already happened.

examples.zh: 他们已经走了。
examples.en: They've already left.

examples.zh: 我已经有男朋友了。
examples.en: I already have a boyfriend.

examples.zh: 宝宝已经会说话了。
examples.en: The baby can already speak.

examples.zh: 妈妈已经回来了。
examples.en: Mom has already come back.

examples.zh: 爸爸妈妈已经老了。
examples.en: Mom and dad are already old.

examples.zh: 已经很晚了，我们走吧。
examples.en: It's already really late. Let's go.

examples.zh: 爷爷已经八十五岁了。
examples.en: Grandpa is already eighty-five years old.

examples.zh: 已经9点了。
examples.en: It's already nine o'clock.

structures: x 年 + y 月 + z 日
x 年 + y 月 + z 号
structureOfDatesPattern.description: Dates in Chinese follow the order "year, month, day." This is in keeping with the "from big to small" trend which pervades many facets of Chinese culture.

examples.en: January 18, 1868
August 9, 1910
July 20th, 2001

examples.zh: 1月1日是新年。
examples.en: January 1st is New Year's Day.

examples.zh: 12月24日是平安夜。
examples.en: December 24th is Christmas Eve.

examples.zh: 10月1号我们去上海。
examples.en: We will go to Shanghai on October 1st.

examples.zh: 我1990年7月出生。
examples.en: I was born in July 1990.

examples.zh: 你的生日是11月11号吗？
examples.en: Is your birthday November 11th?

examples.zh: 我2006年4月17号认识了他。
examples.en: I met him on April 17, 2006.

examples.zh: 1980年9月4号我们结婚了。
examples.en: We got married on September 4th, 1980.

structures: (Date and/or time of day +) x 点
oClockPattern.description: Time in Chinese, just like in English, is expressed by stating the hour first, and then the minute (big to small).

examples.zh: 九点
examples.en: 9 o'clock

examples.zh: 上午七点
examples.en: 7 o'clock a.m.

examples.zh: 下午四点
examples.en: 4 o'clock p.m.

examples.zh: 中午十二点
examples.en: 12 o'clock noon

examples.zh: 明天晚上七点
examples.en: 7 o'clock p.m. tomorrow evening

examples.zh: 9月9号早上六点
examples.en: September 9th, 6 o'clock a.m.

examples.zh: 星期三上午九点
examples.en: Wednesday at 9 o'clock a.m.

examples.zh: 五点半
下午两点半
星期天上午十点半
examples.en: Sunday at 10:30 a.m.

examples.zh: 昨天晚上七点半
examples.en: 7:30 yesterday evening

examples.zh: 今天下午四点半
examples.en: 4:30 p.m. this afternoon.

structures: ⋯⋯， 好 / 对 / 是 / 可以 +  吗？
duimaPattern.description: As well as yes/no questions, you can also form tag questions with 吗 (ma). Tag questions are quick questions that are tagged on the end of a sentence to ask for confirmation. In English, this is often done with "right?" or negatively with "isn't it?"

examples.zh: 这样做，对吗？
examples.en: Do it like this, right?

examples.zh: 你们见过，对吗？
examples.en: You’ve met, right?

examples.zh: 他们昨天都没去，是吗？
examples.en: They didn't go yesterday, right?

examples.zh: 你没来过，是吗？
examples.en: You haven't been here, right?

examples.zh: 你喜欢我妹妹，是吗？
examples.en: You like my younger sister, huh?

examples.zh: 我们去你家，好吗？
examples.en: Let's go to your place, OK?

examples.zh: 不要告诉他，好吗？
examples.en: Don't tell him, OK?

examples.zh: 今天我们都不喝酒，好吗？
examples.en: Let's all not drink alcohol today, OK?

examples.zh: 我现在想去洗手间，可以吗？
examples.en: I want to go to the bathroom now. Is that OK?

examples.zh: 妈妈，我要吃巧克力，可以吗？
examples.en: Mom, I want to eat chocolate. May I?

yibianPattern.description: 以便 (yǐbiàn)  is a formal way to say "in order to" or "to facilitate," and is generally used to show that an outcome is the result of a particular action.

examples.zh: 我国提倡垃圾分类，以便回收再利用。
examples.en: My country advocates a garbage classification to help with reusing and recycling.

examples.zh: 老李买了一辆折叠式的自行车，以便携带。
examples.en: Old Li bought a folding bike to make it easier to carry around.

examples.zh: 老师减慢了语速，以便学生能听懂。
examples.en: The teacher slowed down her talking speed so that the students could understand her.

structures: Noun 1 + 跟 / 和 + Noun 2 + 一样
Noun 1 + 跟 / 和 + Noun 2 + 一样 + Adj.
basicComparisonsWithYiyangPattern.description: Along with 比 (bǐ) and 没有 (méiyǒu), 一样 (yīyàng) is another way to make basic comparisons. However, 一样 (yīyàng) is used to express that two things are the same in some way.

examples.zh: 我和你一样。
examples.en: I am the same as you.

examples.zh: 他的性格跟他妈妈一样。
examples.en: He has the same personality as his mom.

examples.zh: 北京的天气和上海不一样。
examples.en: The weather in Beijing and the weather in Shanghai are not alike.

examples.zh: 这个词的意思和那个词一样吗？
examples.en: Are the meanings of this word and that word the same?

examples.zh: 美国文化跟中国文化不一样。
examples.en: American culture and Chinese culture are not the same.

examples.zh: 啤酒和葡萄酒的味道一样吗？
examples.en: Do beer and red wine taste the same?

examples.zh: 你家跟我家一样大。
examples.en: Your house is just as big as mine.

examples.zh: 她和她哥哥一样高。
examples.en: She and her older brother are equally tall.

examples.zh: 你的头发和我的头发一样长。
examples.en: You hair is as long as mine.

examples.zh: 这里的天气跟我老家一样舒服。
examples.en: The weather here is just as comfortable as my hometown's.

examples.zh: 你跟老板一样忙吗？
examples.en: Are you as busy as the boss is?

structures: Place 1 + 离 + Place 2 + Adv. + 近 / 远
Place 1 + 离 + Place 2 (+ Adv.) + 近 / 远 + 吗？
Place 1 + 离 + Place 2 (+ 有) + 多远？
expressingDistanceWithLiPattern.description: Are we there yet? One of the ways to express distance is to use 离 (lí). The word order might seem a little tricky at first, but once you get it down, you'll be able to talk about distance with no problem.

examples.zh: 我家离公司很近。
examples.en: My house is close to my office.

examples.zh: 美国离中国很远。
examples.en: The USA is far from China.

examples.zh: 这个酒店离火车站很近。
examples.en: This hotel is very close to the train station.

examples.zh: 那个酒吧离这儿太远了，我不想去。
examples.en: That bar is too far away from here. I don't want to go.

examples.zh: 我不想去离家很远的地方工作。
examples.en: I don't want to go work at a place very far away from home.

examples.zh: 你家离超市远吗？
examples.en: Is your house far away from the supermarket?

examples.zh: 你的大学离你老家很远吗？
examples.en: Is your college very far away from your hometown?

examples.zh: 你们公司离地铁站近吗？
examples.en: Is your company close to the metro station?

examples.zh: 你家离学校多远？
examples.en: How far is it from your home to school?

examples.zh: 这个酒店离机场有多远？
examples.en: How far is it from this hotel to the airport?

examples.zh: 你离我远点儿！
examples.en: Stay away from me.

structures: Subj. + 还 + 好 / 可以 / 行 / 不错
moderatingPositiveAdjectivesWithHaiPatte.description: Whenever you want to imply that something is "good," but also kind of "meh," you can use 还 (hái) in front of the "good" adjective.

examples.zh: 我还好。
examples.en: I'm OK.

examples.zh: 爸爸做的菜还可以。
examples.en: The food that dad cooks is OK.

examples.zh: 我们老板还不错。
examples.en: Our boss is not too bad.

examples.zh: 这家店还行，不太贵。
examples.en: This shop is OK. It's not too expensive.

examples.zh: 我男朋友的工资还可以。
examples.en: My boyfriend's salary is OK.

examples.zh: 新的办公室还不错。
examples.en: The new office is OK.

examples.zh: 我觉得这里的菜还可以，没有那么难吃。
examples.en: I think the food here is OK, it is not too bad-tasting.

examples.zh: 这个牌子还不错，很多年轻人喜欢。
examples.en: This brand is not too bad. Many young people like it.

examples.zh: 房子还可以，但是有点贵。
examples.en: The apartment is not too bad, but it is a bit expensive.

structures: Statement， 可是 / 但是 + [Contrary Statement]
keshiPattern.description: Using "but" in Chinese is really simple to learn. It involves the two words 可是 (kěshì) and 但是 (dànshì). Make no "buts" about it; you'll understand it in no time!

examples.zh: 我喜欢他，可是他不喜欢我。
examples.en: I like him, but he doesn't like me.

examples.zh: 我很想去，但是我太忙了。
examples.en: I really want to go, but I am too busy.

examples.zh: 中文很有意思，但是也很难。
examples.en: Chinese is very interesting, but it is also very hard.

examples.zh: 我喜欢这件衬衫，可是太贵了。
examples.en: I like this shirt, but it is too expensive.

examples.zh: 老板昨天给他打电话，可是他没接。
examples.en: The boss gave him a call yesterday, but he didn't answer.

examples.zh: iPhone很好，但是我没钱买。
examples.en: The iPhone is great, but I don't have the money to buy it.

examples.zh: 你们可以在这里看书，可是不可以说话。
examples.en: You can read books here, but you can't talk.

examples.zh: 你可以吃，但是不可以吃太多。
examples.en: You can eat, but you can't eat too much.

examples.zh: 他说五点来见我，但是他没来。
examples.en: He said he would come to see me at five, but he didn't.

examples.zh: 这个地方很漂亮，但是人太多了。
examples.en: This place is beautiful, but there are too many people.

structures: 有的 + (Subj.) + Predicate， 有的 + (Subj.) + Predicate
youdePattern.description: To refer to just certain members of group, you can use 有的 (yǒude). This usage is normally translated as "some" in English. It is often used multiple times in one sentence to refer to different groups.

examples.zh: 外国人有的很有钱，有的没钱。
examples.en: Some foreigners are rich, but some aren't.

examples.zh: 我们公司有一些电脑，有的是新的，有的是旧的。
examples.en: Our company has some computers. Some are new, and some are old.

examples.zh: 他写了很多书，有的卖得很好，有的卖得不好。
examples.en: He has written a lot of books. Some sell well, but some don't.

examples.zh: 中国菜有的好吃，有的不好吃。
examples.en: Some Chinese foods are tasty, while some aren't.

examples.zh: 这家店的衣服有的贵，有的便宜。
examples.en: In this shop, some of the clothes are expensive and some are cheap.

examples.zh: 他有很多房子，有的在国内，有的在国外。
examples.en: He has a lot of houses, some of them are within the country and some are abroad.

examples.zh: 晚上六点以后，有的人下班了，有的人在加班。
examples.en: After six o'clock some people are off work, while some are still working.

examples.zh: 我的大学老师有的很年轻，有的很老。
examples.en: Some of my college teachers are young, some are old.

examples.zh: 酒吧里，有的人在喝酒，有的人在跳舞，还有的人在聊天。
examples.en: In the bar, some people are drinking, some are dancing, and some are chatting.

examples.zh: 因为工作，我认识了很多人，有的是大学老师，有的是CEO。
examples.en: I know a lot of people because of my work. Some are college teachers and some are CEOs.

structures: Subj. + 那么 / 这么 + Adj.
nameZhemePattern.description: In  English, the words "that" and "so" are often used to increase the extent of an adjective (ex. "he is so tall" or "this food is so good"). In Chinese, 那么 (nàme) and 这么 (zhème) serve the same function.

examples.zh: 你说得这么快，我怎么能听懂？
examples.en: You speak so fast. How could I understand you?

examples.zh: 你怎么那么忙？
examples.en: How come you are so busy?

examples.zh: 雨这么大，明天再去吧。
examples.en: It's raining so heavily. How about we go tomorrow?

examples.zh: 你那么有钱，为什么还要工作？
examples.en: You are so rich. Why are you still working?

examples.zh: 中国人口这么多，当然会有很多社会问题。
examples.en: China has such a big  population. Of course there will be many social problems.

examples.zh: 我没想到这个考试这么难。
examples.en: I didn't expect this exam is so difficult.

examples.zh: 你怎么有这么多问题要问？
examples.en: How come you have so many questions to ask?

examples.zh: 这个老外怎么会了解那么多中国历史？
examples.en: How come this foreigner knows so much about Chinese history?

examples.zh: 今天这么冷，你怎么穿那么少？
examples.en: It's so cold today. How come you wear so little?

examples.zh: 科技那么发达，什么都是有可能的。
examples.en: Science and technology is so developed. Nothing is impossible.

structures: Subj. + 差点(儿) + [Verb Phrase] + 了
butDidntPattern.description: To say that something bad almost happened (but didn't), you can add the word 差点 (chàdiǎn) before the verb.  You will also hear 差点儿 (chàdiǎnr) in northern China.  There is no difference in meaning between 差点 and 差点儿.

examples.zh: 我差点忘了。
examples.en: I almost forgot.

examples.zh: 他们差点就分手了。
examples.en: They almost break up.

examples.zh: 我们队差点儿就输了。
examples.en: Our team almost lost.

examples.zh: 他们差点打起来。
examples.en: They almost started a fight.

examples.zh: 这个东西差点就丢了。
examples.en: I almost lost the thing.

examples.zh: 路上堵车，我差点儿就迟到了。
examples.en: The traffic is bad; I was almost late.

examples.zh: 我差点犯了一个大错。
examples.en: I nearly made a big mistake.

examples.zh: 车差点撞到我。
examples.en: The car almost hit me.

examples.zh: 我差点笑出来。
examples.en: I almost laughed.

examples.zh: 我们差点儿错过最后一班地铁。
examples.en: We almost missed the last metro.

structures: Subj. + 再也不 + Verb + Obj. + 了
Subj. + 再也没 + Verb + 过＋Obj.
zaiyebuPattern.description: Sometimes you may do something or experience something that you never ever want to do again. How do we express that in Chinese? One of the ways is to use 再也不 (zàiyěbù)!

examples.zh: 我再也不想看到你了！
examples.en: I never want to see you again!

examples.zh: 我再也不想跟你一起玩了。
examples.en: I don't want to play with you again.

examples.zh: 我们再也不会相信你了！
examples.en: We're not going to believe you ever again!

examples.zh: 她受伤以后，就再也不能跳舞了。
examples.en: After she was injured, she can never be able to dance again.

examples.zh: 生病以后，爸爸就再也不喝酒了。
examples.en: After he got ill, my father never drinks again.

examples.zh: 从那以后，我再也没见过他。
examples.en: I've never seen him again since then.

examples.zh: 出国以后，我再也没吃过地道的中国菜。
examples.en: I've never eaten any authentic Chinese food ever since I left the country.

examples.zh: 分手以后，他们再也没说过话。
examples.en: They haven't talked to each other ever since they broke up.

examples.zh: 上大学以后，她再也没花过父母的钱。
examples.en: She has never spent her parents' money after she went to college.

examples.zh: 父母去世以后，他再也没回过老家。
examples.en: He hasn't gone back to hometown ever since his parents passed away.

nanguaiPattern.description: 难怪 (nánguài) can be used to express that the speaker finds something unsurprising. It can be used alone or in a variety of different structures, as shown below.  怪不得 (guàibude) is another way to express exactly the same thing, in a slightly more informal way. 难怪 (nánguài) when used as a verb can be translated as "hard to blame." This is usually directed at a person, and it is similar to how in English we may say "He's always sleepy, but you can't blame him because he works a night shift."

examples.zh: 难怪！
examples.en: No wonder!

examples.zh: 他和女朋友分手了，难怪他最近一直不高兴。
examples.en: He and his girlfriend broke up. No wonder he's been so unhappy recently.

examples.zh: 小张请假了，难怪今天没有看到他。
examples.en: Little Zhang asked for some vacation time, no wonder I haven't seen him today.

examples.zh: 老板过年要发红包，难怪大家最近都这么开心。
examples.en: Boss is going to give out red envelopes. No wonder everyone looks so happy recently.

examples.zh: 你的手机丢了？难怪你的手机一直打不通。
examples.en: Your cell phone is lost? No wonder I couldn't get through.

examples.zh: 难怪老板这么生气，原来那个大客户取消了订单。
examples.en: No wonder the boss is so angry. It turns out that that important customer cancelled his order.

examples.zh: 难怪这里人这么多，原来在打折。
examples.en: No wonder there are so many people here. There's a sale going on.

examples.zh: 难怪他天天都迟到，原来他要自己照顾孩子。
examples.en: No wonder he's late every day. It turns out he's raising his kids by himself.

examples.zh: 难怪他一直都不告诉我，原来是不想让我担心。
examples.en: No wonder he hasn't told me.It turns out that he doesn't want me to worry about this.

examples.zh: 难怪这么多人都想认识她，原来她爸是市长。
examples.en: No wonder so many people want to meet her. It turned out that her father is the mayor.

examples.zh: 这也难怪他，还是个孩子呢，什么都不懂。
examples.en: Don't blame him. He's just a kid. He doesn't know better.

examples.zh: 这也难怪你，他昨天才给你回复。
examples.en: Don't blame yourself. He just replied to you yesterday.

examples.zh: 这也难怪，你们第一次到这个地方还不了解这里的风俗。
examples.en: Don't blame yourselves. It's your first time here, and you don't understand the customs.

examples.zh: A:他迟到了。B:这也难怪。今天地铁坏了。
examples.en: A: He's late.  B: Don't blame him. The subway broke down today.

examples.zh: 这也难怪，他们工作这么累，工资还这么低。
examples.en: Don't blame them. Their job is so tiring but they get such a low pay.

structures: 幸亏 / 幸好 + [Lucky Incident]， 不然 ……
xingkuiPattern.description: 幸亏 (xìngkuī), 幸好 (xìnghǎo), and 还好 (háihǎo) mean "fortunately" or "luckily." They can be used to express that something has happened by chance, and has thereby enabled you to avoid some difficulty or bad luck. It is often followed with 不然 (which precedes the bad thing that could have happened).

examples.zh: 幸亏我们走得早，不然就迟到了。
examples.en: Luckily, we left early, otherwise we could have been late.

examples.zh: 幸好我妈没看到，不然她肯定要生气。
examples.en: It's a good thing that my mother didn't see it, otherwise she would definitely be mad.

examples.zh: 幸亏你在，不然我不知道该找谁。
examples.en: Fortunately you're here, otherwise I don't know who I could turn to.

examples.zh: 幸好他们都走了，不然我要疯了。
examples.en: Luckily, they all left, otherwise I could be driven crazy.

examples.zh: 幸好今天带伞了，不然要淋湿了。
examples.en: It's a good thing I brought the umbrella. Otherwise, I would have gotten soaked.

examples.zh: 还好我没听他的话，不然我就输了。
examples.en: It's a good thing I didn't listen to him, otherwise I would have lost the game.

examples.zh: 还好我保存了，不然文件都丢了。
examples.en: Luckily I saved it, otherwise I would have lost all of the documents.

examples.zh: 还好我买得少，不然都浪费了。
examples.en: Luckily I didn't buy a lot, otherwise the food would be all wasted.

examples.zh: 还好老板不知道，不然你肯定被炒鱿鱼。
examples.en: Luckily the boss doesn't know about it, otherwise you will definitely get fired.

examples.zh: 还好你提醒我，不然我肯定忘了。
examples.en: Luckily, you reminded me, otherwise I would have definitely forgotten.

structures: 通过 / 用 + Agent + 来 + Verb Phrase
usingLaiToConnectTwoVerbPhrasesPattern.description: The word 来 (lái) can be used to connect two verb phrases, relating the actions to each other. It can be translated as "in order to" or "so that" and it can help in explaining reasoning.

examples.zh: 用这种方法来赚钱，真丢人。
examples.en: Using this method to earn money is shameful.

examples.zh: 用这个APP来学汉字更容易。
examples.en: It's easier to use this application to study Chinese characters.

examples.zh: 很多人都是通过这个网站来找工作的。
examples.en: A lot of people hunt for a job through this website.

examples.zh: 我们可以通过打折来吸引顾客。
examples.en: We can use a sale as a method to attract customers.

examples.zh: 他们是通过这个平台来推广产品的。
examples.en: They promote their product through this platform.

zhiqianPattern.description: Before and after can be expressed using 之前 (zhīqián) and 之后 (zhīhòu). They are in relatively the same vein as 以前/以后, except that these two are adverbs, while 之前/之后 are prepositions. Don't forget that these two are talking about before and after in terms of time.

examples.zh: 下班之前，经理给我们开了一个会议。
examples.en: Before I got off work, the manager assembled a meeting with us.

examples.zh: 来中国之前，我的汉语水平很低。
examples.en: Before I came to China, my Chinese was bad.

examples.zh: 吃完饭之后，他们去了一家电影院。
examples.en: After they finished eating, they went to a movie theater.

examples.zh: 去北京之后，他和他的女朋友分手了。
examples.en: After he went to Beijing, he broke up with his girlfriend.

structures: 级别 / 次序 / 数目 + 以上 / 以下
时间 / 处所 / 数量 / 范围 + 以内 / 以外

examples.zh: 我老家空气还不错，PM2.5一般在五十以下。
examples.en: The air in my hometown is good. PM 2.5 is generally under 50.

examples.zh: 我们需要有两年以上工作经验的人。
examples.en: We need people with two years of working experience or more.

examples.zh: 十岁以下的孩子不用买票。
examples.en: Children under the age of 10 do not need to buy tickets.

examples.zh: 我们出差都住三星级以上的酒店。
examples.en: When we go on business trips, we stay at hotels with at least a 3-star rating.

examples.zh: 这里的冬天气温都在零度以下。
examples.en: This winter, the temperature has been less than 0 degrees.

examples.zh: 以下就谈谈这个问题应该怎么解决。
examples.en: In the following conversation, we will discuss how we should resolve this problem.

examples.zh: 以上只是我个人的看法。
examples.en: The following is just my personal opinion.

examples.zh: 两天以内必须完成。
examples.en: Must be completed in two days or less.

examples.zh: 半小时以内能送到吗？
examples.en: Can you deliver in 30 minutes or less?

examples.zh: 这个大楼50米以内不能停车。
examples.en: You cannot park within 50 meters of this building.

examples.zh: 请你站在两米以外的地方。
examples.en: Can you stop 2 meters outside of this place?

examples.zh: 这个区以外的几个区都不太发达。
examples.en: All of the areas outside this one are not very developed.

examples.zh: 除了这个以外，还有一点也很重要。
examples.en: Aside from this, there is still one point that is very important.

structures: A + 比 + B + 大 / 小 + number + 岁
A + 跟 + B + 一样 + 大
expressingAgeDifferenceWithDaAndXiaoPatt.description: 如果你有兄弟姐妹，中国人常常会问你"他（她）比你小几岁" or "他（她）比你大几岁 "。注意，这里一定不能不用"年轻"或者"老"。

examples.zh: 我姐姐比我大两岁。
examples.en: My sister is two years older than me.

examples.zh: 你爸爸比妈妈小几岁？
examples.en: How many years younger than your mom is your dad?

examples.zh: 他女朋友比他大十岁。
examples.en: His girlfriend is 10 years older than him.

examples.zh: 我跟我的中文老师一样大。
examples.en: My Chinese teacher and I are the same age.

examples.zh: 我老板很年轻，只比我大三四岁。
examples.en: My boss is very young. He is only three or four years older than me.

structures: Subj. + 一点也 / 都 + 不 + Adj.
Subj. + 一点也 / 都 + 不 + Verb
Subj. + 一点都 / 也 + 没 + Verb
yidianrYeBuPattern.description: Sometimes we may want to say something is "not even the least bit [adjective]." For example, we might say in English: "I am not at all hungry."  In Chinese, we can use 一点也不 (yīdiǎnr yě bù) or 一点都不 (yīdiǎnr dōu bù) to express "not at all [adjective]."

examples.zh: 你一点也不性感。
examples.en: You're not even a little bit sexy.

examples.zh: 他的朋友一点都不可爱。
examples.en: His friend is not cute at all.

examples.zh: 我的同事一点都不幽默。
examples.en: My colleague is not humorous at all.

examples.zh: 他一点也不喜欢啤酒。
examples.en: He doesn't like beer even a little bit.

examples.zh: 你一点也不会说吗？
examples.en: You can't even speak a little?

examples.zh: 她好像一点都不知道这件事。
examples.en: She doesn't seem to know even a little about this.

examples.zh: 我一点也不习惯熬夜。
examples.en: I’m not used to staying up late at all.

examples.zh: 我一点也没生气。
examples.en: I didn't get even a little bit angry.

examples.zh: 宝宝打针的时候一点都没哭。
examples.en: The baby didn't even cry a little when it got the shot.

examples.zh: 今天她一点也没吃东西。
examples.en: She didn't even eat a little today.

examples.zh: 工作虽然很累，但他一点都没抱怨。
examples.en: Although the job was tiring, he didn't even complain a bit.

structures: Adj. + 是 + Adj. ， 但是 / 就是 ⋯⋯
concedingAPointWithShiPattern.description: When conceding a point, we often put emphasis on the point we are conceding, and in Chinese there is a way to do that with 是 (shì).

examples.zh: 好吃是好吃，就是不太健康。
examples.en: It is tasty, but it's not very healthy.

examples.zh: 这个东西好是好，就是太贵了。
examples.en: This thing is good, but it's too expensive.

examples.zh: 工作忙是忙，但是我很开心。
examples.en: I am busy at work, but I'm very happy with my job.

examples.zh: 这件衣服便宜是便宜，但是质量不太好。
examples.en: This piece of clothing may be cheap, but the quality isn't very good.

examples.zh: 这个学生聪明是聪明，就是不太努力。
examples.en: This student may be smart, but he's not very hardworking.

examples.zh: 这个办公楼好是好，但是交通不太方便。
examples.en: This office building is great, but the transportation is not very convenient.

examples.zh: 他女朋友漂亮是漂亮，就是有点矮。
examples.en: His girlfriend is pretty, but she is a little short.

examples.zh: 玩得开心是开心，但是有点累。
examples.en: We had lots of fun, but we were also a little tired after that.

examples.zh: 这个老师严格是严格，但是她教得好。
examples.en: This teacher is strict, but she teaches very well.

examples.zh: 这个运动危险是危险，但是很刺激。
examples.en: This sport may be dangerous, but it's also very exciting.

structures: 虽然 + Subj. + 但是 + Contrary Reaction
suiranDanshiPattern.description: The grammar pattern "虽然⋯⋯ 但是⋯⋯" (suīrán... dànshì...) is one of the most common used patterns in Chinese, especially in written Chinese. You can think of it as meaning "although," but unlike in English, you still need to follow it with a "but" word in Chinese.

examples.zh: 虽然他是美国人，但是他还没去过华盛顿。
examples.en: Although he's American, he still hasn't been to Washington D.C.

examples.zh: 虽然她说不太饿，但是她点了很多菜。
examples.en: Even though she said she isn't hungry, she ordered a lot of food.

examples.zh: 虽然他的家里很有钱，可是他从来不浪费钱。
examples.en: Even though he‘s got a rich family, he never wastes money.

structures: 除了 + Noun Phrase + (以外) + Noun Phrase + 都 + Verb
除了 + Noun Phrase + (以外) + Noun Phrase + 也 / 还 + Verb
chulePattern.description: Using 除了 (chúle)⋯⋯ 以外 (yǐwài) will help you spruce up your sentences when you want to express "except," "besides," and "in addition."  You may feel that "except" has a pretty different meaning form the other two. Well, read on!

examples.zh: 除了妈妈以外，我们全家都去香港。
examples.en: Except for mother, the whole family went to Hong Kong.

examples.zh: 除了白酒以外，他什么酒都喝。
examples.en: He will drink anything except white wine.

examples.zh: 除了星期天以外，我们每天都上班。
examples.en: Except for Sunday, we work every day.

examples.zh: 除了海南岛以外，我还想去台湾旅行。
examples.en: In addition to Hainan Island, I also want to travel to Taiwan.

examples.zh: 除了牛肉以外，她也很喜欢吃鸡肉。
examples.en: In addition to beef, she also likes to chicken.

examples.zh: 中国的功夫明星除了成龙，李连杰也很有名。
examples.en: In addition to Jackie Chen, Jet Li is also very famous as a kung fu star.

structures: (这 / 那) + 得看 / 要看 + [What "It" Depends On]
[Unknown Outcome] + 得看 / 要看 + [What "It" Depends On]
expressingItDependsWithKanPattern.description: Although there are a number of ways to express "it depends" in Chinese, the most common ones in spoken Chinese involve the verb 看 (kàn). Some common expressions include:

examples.zh: 这得看你的时间。
examples.en: This depends on when you are available.

examples.zh: 这得看天气怎么样。
examples.en: It depends on how the weather is.

examples.zh: 那得看考试难不难。
examples.en: That depends on whether the exam is difficult or not.

examples.zh: 那要看他有没有女朋友。
examples.en: That depends on whether or not he has a girlfriend.

examples.zh: 那要看孩子怎么想。
examples.en: It depends on what the child thinks.

examples.zh: 去不去要看他的心情。
examples.en: Whether he comes or not depends on his mood.

examples.zh: 能不能得到这个工作要看你的面试结果。
examples.en: Whether you can get this job depends on the result of the job interview.

examples.zh: 请多少人来得看你们的预算是多少。
examples.en: When to meet this client depends on what time he will be available.

examples.zh: 送什么礼物要看她喜欢什么。
examples.en: What birthday present to give to her depends on what she really likes.

examples.zh: 能不能赢得看我们的团队合作得怎么样。
examples.en: Whether we can win depends on how our teamwork is.

structures: Subj. + 越来越 + Adj. + 了
Subj. + 越来越 + Verb + 了
yuelaiyuePattern.description: 越来越 (yuèláiyuè) is used frequently in Chinese to express that some quality or state is increasing with time, or in tune with another factor.  There are two forms of this pattern, the "simple" one (using 来), and the more complex one (which uses two different adjectives/verbs).

examples.zh: 天气越来越冷了。
examples.en: The weather is getting colder and colder.

examples.zh: 你女儿越来越漂亮了。
examples.en: Your daughter is getting more and more beautiful.

examples.zh: 你做的菜越来越好吃了。
examples.en: The food that you cook is more and more delicious.

examples.zh: 汽油越来越贵了。
examples.en: Gasoline is getting more and more expensive.

examples.zh: 上海的房价越来越高了。
examples.en: The housing price in Shanghai is getting higher and higher.

examples.zh: 来中国以后，他越来越喜欢吃辣了。
examples.en: After he came to China, he likes eating spicy food more and more.

examples.zh: 我越来越想家了。
examples.en: I'm getting more and more homesick.

examples.zh: 大家越来越习惯当地的生活了。
examples.en: Everyone is getting more and more used to local life.

examples.zh: 你越来越会做菜了。
examples.en: You're getting better and better at cooking.

examples.zh: 有了孩子以后，我越来越能理解我自己的父母了。
examples.en: After I have my own kid, I can understand my own parents more and more.

structures: 一 + Measure Word + (Noun) + 也 / 都 + 不 / 没 + Verb
Topic + Subj. + 一 + Measure Word + (Noun) + 也 / 都 + Verb
expressingNotEvenOnePattern.description: In English we might want to say something like "I have absolutely no money, not even one penny." That "not even one" is the focus of this article.

examples.zh: 我一口都没吃。
examples.en: I didn't take a single bite.

examples.zh: 他一句中文都不会说。
examples.en: He can't speak one sentence of Chinese.

examples.zh: 为什么这里一个人都没有？
examples.en: Why aren't there any people here?

examples.zh: 她一瓶酒也没喝。
examples.en: She didn't drink a bottle of wine.

examples.zh: 来上海以前，他一个外国朋友都没有。
examples.en: He didn't have a foreign friend before he came to Shanghai.

examples.zh: 这个人我一次都没见过。
examples.en: I haven't seen this person once.

examples.zh: 这样的菜我一次也没吃过。
examples.en: I've never eaten this kind of food before.

examples.zh: 这次活动我们公司一个人也没参加。
examples.en: Not one person in our company has participated in this activity.

structures: Subj. + 不但 + Adj. / Verb， 而且 + Adj. / Verb
Subj. + 不但 +  Adj. / Verb， 而且 + Adj. / Verb
不但 + Subj. 1 + Adj. / Verb， 而且 + Subj. 2 + Adj. / Verb
budanErqiePattern.description: "不但⋯⋯，而且⋯⋯" (bùdàn..., érqiě...) is a very commonly used pattern that indicates "not only, ... but also...."

examples.zh: 这种菜不但好吃，而且有营养。
examples.en: This kind of vegetable is not only delicious, but nutritious as well.

examples.zh: 她不但聪明，而且很努力。
examples.en: She is not only smart, but also very hard-working.

examples.zh: 他不但做完了，而且做得非常好。
examples.en: Not only did he finish, but he also did it extremely well.

examples.zh: 我不但会做饭，而且会洗衣服。
examples.en: Not only can I cook, but I can also do the laundry.

examples.zh: 不但我会做饭，而且我妹妹也会做饭。
examples.en: Not only can I cook, but my little sister can as well.

structures: Subj. + 不知道 + Verb Phrase + 好
buZhidaoHaoPattern.description: "不知道⋯⋯好" (bù zhīdào...hǎo) is an expression used to indicate and emphasize that the speaker does not know how to do something, or at least does not know how to do something well.

examples.zh: 这件事我真的不知道怎么办好。
examples.en: I really don't know what to do with this.

examples.zh: 那时候我真不知道说什么好。
examples.en: I didn't know what to say at that time.

examples.zh: 他的短信我不知道怎么回复好。
examples.en: I don't know how to reply to his message.

examples.zh: 这些东西我们不知道放在哪儿好。
examples.en: We don't know where to put there stuff.

examples.zh: 好吃的太多了，他不知道先吃哪个好。
examples.en: There are too much delicious food. He doesn't know which one to start with.

structures: 一 方面 + Aspect 1， (另) 一 方面 + Aspect 2
yiFangmianPattern.description: When talking about various aspects of a situation, "一方面⋯⋯， (另)一方面⋯⋯" (yī fāngmiàn..., (lìng) yī fāngmiàn...) can be used in a similar way that "On one hand..., on the other hand..." is in English.

examples.zh: 我们一方面要让客户满意，另一方面又不能让公司有损失。
examples.en: One one hand, we need to make our clients satisfied, but on the other hand, we can't cause the company any loss.

examples.zh: 这个项目一方面能增加当地人的收入，另一方面还能保护当地的环境。
examples.en: One one hand, this project can increase local people's income; on the other hand, it can protect local environment.

examples.zh: 他一方面很想创业，另一方面又担心风险太大。
examples.en: On one hand, he wants to start a business, but on the other hand, he's afraid the risk is too great.

examples.zh: 智能手机一方面让我们的生活方便了很多，另一方面也浪费了我们不少时间。
examples.en: One one hand, smart phone makes our life more convenient; on the other hand, it wastes a lot of our time.

examples.zh: 开发太阳能一方面可以减少污染，一方面也可以降低成本。
examples.en: On one hand, developing solar power can reduce pollution; on the other hand, it could also reduce the cost.

structures: 所有的 + Noun + 都 + Verb / Adj.
referringToAllUsingSuoyouPattern.description: In this grammar structure, we learn about a way to say "all" that is, well, a bit more epic. Sort of like how we might say "all the king's men" or "all the money in the world."

examples.zh: 我爱吃所有的中国菜。
examples.en: I love eating all the Chinese food.

examples.zh: 他记得所有人的生日。
examples.en: He remembers everyone's birthday.

examples.zh: 这里所有的女孩都没上过学。
examples.en: All of the girls here have never gone to school.

examples.zh: 不是所有的美国人都爱喝咖啡。
examples.en: Not all the Americans like drinking coffee.

examples.zh: 我们部门所有的员工都会说英文。
examples.en: All the employees from our department can speak English.

examples.zh: 你们公司所有的经理都是男的吗？
examples.en: All the managers in your company are male?

examples.zh: 我看过所有的迪斯尼动画片。
examples.en: I've seen all the Disney movies.

examples.zh: 他找了所有的朋友，但是没有人帮他。
examples.en: He went to all his friends, but nobody helped him.

examples.zh: 钱不可能解决所有的问题。
examples.en: Money can't solve all the problems.

examples.zh: 老板让所有的员工都去参加这个会。
examples.en: Boss asked all the employees to attend this meeting.

structures: Subj. + Special Time + 以后／之后 + Action
yihouPattern.description: If you are trying to explain what you did after a certain event, you might want to use "以后" (yǐhòu) or "之后" (zhīhòu). After all, they do both mean "after," right? Well, it turns out that there are a few rules that you need to be aware of before you use them.

examples.zh: 下过雨以后/之后空气会好很多。
examples.en: After it rains, the air will be a lot better.

examples.zh: 结婚以后/之后他们有了两个宝宝。
examples.en: After getting married, they had two babies.

examples.zh: 等我涨工资以后/之后请你吃饭。
examples.en: After I get a raise, I will treat you to a meal.

examples.zh: 听到这个消息以后/之后，我高兴得一晚上没睡。
examples.en: After I heard this news, I was so happy I couldn't sleep the whole night.

examples.zh: 以后再也不来这里吃饭了，又贵又难吃。
examples.en: In the future I will never come to this place to eat again. It's expensive and the food is not good.

examples.zh: 以后我可能会去国外上大学。
examples.en: In the future I might go to college abroad.

examples.zh: 以后的事情以后再说吧。
examples.en: We'll talk about future things some time later.

examples.zh: 我要先回家把东西放下，之后去咖啡店找你。
examples.en: I'm going to go home and drop my stuff off first, then go to the cafe to look for you.

examples.zh: 去年夏天他来过我家，之后再也没见到他。
examples.en: Last summer, he came to my house. After that, I haven't seen him.

examples.zh: 房子涨价之后，越来越多的人开始买房。
examples.en: After prices went up, more and more people started buying houses.

examples.zh: 我六点下班，之后，我去跟朋友吃饭。
examples.en: I will get off work at six o'clock, and after that I will meet with a friend to eat dinner.

examples.zh: 昨天我跟朋友吃完饭以后去了酒吧。
examples.en: Yesterday, when my friends and I were done eating, we went to the bar.

examples.zh: 昨天我跟朋友去吃饭了，之后，我们去了酒吧。
examples.en: Yesterday I ate dinner with a friend, and afterward we went to a bar.

deBudeliaoPattern.description: 得不得了 (de bùdéliǎo) can be used as a complement to suggest a situation is serious, or is likely to result in perhaps terrible consequences. It can be used in a positive sense, such as in English when we say "I'm terribly happy."

examples.zh: 升职的事情让他高兴得不得了。
examples.en: The fact that he got promoted made him extremely happy.

examples.zh: 嗨，他跟老总的关系好得不得了，你一定要小心！
examples.en: The relationship between him and the chief officer is really good, you need to be careful!

examples.zh: 爸爸气得不得了，你要倒霉啦。
examples.en: Dad is super angry. You're going to be unlucky.

examples.zh: 她的妈妈刚去世，她难过得不得了。
examples.en: Her mom just passed away, she is extremely sad.

leYidianrPattern.description: 了一点儿 (le yīdiǎnr), can be added after an adjective to mean "a little bit too." It is softer in tone than using 太, and so is often used when the speaker doesn't want to insult the listener by speaking too directly.

examples.zh: 这把椅子稍微硬了点儿，我坐得有点难受。
examples.en: This chair is a little too hard. I'm having a hard time sitting in it.

examples.zh: 这道菜稍微咸了点儿，可以重新炒吗？
examples.en: This food is a little too salty, could you make it again?

examples.zh: 我妈妈说你钱挣得少了点儿，人长得矮了点儿。她觉得我需要找一个好点儿的男朋友。
examples.en: My mother says you earn too little money, and you're a little too short. She thinks I need to find a boyfriend who's a little better.

structures: Subj. ＋Verb + 了 + 又 + Verb，还是 / 就是 ……
advancedUseOfYouPattern.description: Here we repeat the verb used and place 又 in the middle. The repetition of the verb emphasizes how the action is being repeated again and again. This one is definitely the most advanced usage of 又 here, and you're not going to use it nearly as much as the others.

examples.zh: 这个人我看了又看，还是觉得我不认识他。
examples.en: I looked at him again and again, but I still think I don't know him.

examples.zh: 我想了又想，还是觉得不能这样做。
examples.en: I thought it over again and again, I think I  can't do it like this.

examples.zh: 他找了又找，还是没找到他的钱包。
examples.en: He searched again and again, and still couldn't find his wallet.

examples.zh: 他想了又想，还是不同意。
examples.en: He thought it over again and again, and he still disagree.

examples.zh: 我们问了又问，她就是不说。
examples.en: We asked again and again, but she wouldn't say it.

examples.zh: 他试了又试，就是打不开门。
examples.en: He tried again and again, but he still couldn't open the door.

examples.zh: 我尝了又尝，还是觉得这些菜坏了。
examples.en: I tasted again and again, but I still think those food has gone bad.

examples.zh: 他闻了又闻，还是什么都没闻到。
examples.en: He smelled again and again, but he still didn't smell anything.

examples.zh: 这个方案改了又改，终于通过了。
examples.en: This plan was changed again and again, and finally it passed.

examples.zh: 这件衣服妈妈洗了又洗，终于洗干净了。
examples.en: Mother washed this clothing again and again, and it's finally clean.

structures: Subj. + 好容易 / 好不容易 + 才 + Verb，[Result Sentence]
Verb / [Verb Phrase] + 好容易 / 好不容易
haoBuRongyiPattern.description: 好不容易 (hǎo bù róngyì) means "very difficult" or "really not easy." It is often used where the speaker wants to comment on the result of their hard work, something like "It was really hard for me do to do x, but then I realized y."

examples.zh: 我们好不容易才做完这个项目，结果合同取消了。
examples.en: With great difficulty, we finally finished this project. As a result, the contract is up.

examples.zh: 我好不容易才到市中心，却发现没带手机，只好回去拿。
examples.en: It took me a long time to reach the city center, then I realized I had forgotten my cell phone and had to go back and get it.

examples.zh: 金融危机之后他好不容易才找到工作，现在又辞职了。
examples.en: After the financial crisis, he had a hard time finding a job. Now he's resigning.

examples.zh: 我好不容易才打通了银行的服务热线。
examples.en: With great difficulty, they finally climbed to the top of the mountain.As a result,it started raining heavily.

examples.zh: 他们好不容易才爬到了山顶，结果下起了大雨。
examples.en: They.

examples.zh: 要完成这个大项目好不容易啊。
examples.en: Finishing this big project will not be an easy task.

examples.zh: 养大一个孩子好不容易。
examples.en: Raising a child is not an easy thing to do.

examples.zh: 创办一个公司好不容易啊。
examples.en: Starting a company isn't easy.

expressingIfItWereNotForWithYaobushiPatt.description: 要不是 (yàobushì) is almost the same as "如果不是⋯⋯ "， and it may followed by "的话," meaning "if it were not for" or "without."

examples.zh: 要不是她帮忙，我们不可能这么快找到这个地方。
examples.en: We couldn't have found this place without her help.

examples.zh: 要不是你说你想吃，我不会做这个菜的。
examples.en: I wouldn't have made this dish if you hadn't said that you want to eat.

examples.zh: 要不是因为他是你朋友，我是不会帮他的。
examples.en: I wouldn't have helped him if it were not for him being a friend with you.

examples.zh: 要不是你们迟到的话，我们早就到了。
examples.en: We would have gotten here earlier if it were not for you being late.

examples.zh: 要不是你刚才说错话，他是不会生气的。
examples.en: He wouldn't be mad if it were not for something wrong you just said.

structures: Noun 1 + 像 + Noun 2 + 一样 + Adj. / Verb
Noun 1 + 像 + Noun 2 + 这么 / 那么 + Adj. / Verb
Noun 1 + 不像 + Noun 2 + 这么 / 那么 + Adj. / Verb
Noun 1 + 没有 + Noun 2 + 这么 / 那么 + Adj. / Verb
comparisonXiangPattern.description: 像  (xiàng) is used to compare a specific characteristic of two things or people, and can be used in the following structure:

examples.zh: 你怎么像我妈一样啰嗦!
examples.en: Why do you sound as nagging as my mom does!

examples.zh: 他生气的时候会像疯子一样大叫。
examples.en: He would scream like a lunatic when he gets angry.

examples.zh: 这个男老师不像那个女老师那么严格。
examples.en: This man teacher is not as strict as that woman teacher.

examples.zh: 我们没有你那么喜欢孩子。
examples.en: We don't like kids as much as you do.

structures: Verb + 着 + Verb + 着 + 就 + Comment + 了
usingZheWhenVerbingAwayPattern.description: A repeated verb followed by the particle 着 (zhe) is used to show that an action has be repeated for a period of time, and as a result a new situation has arisen which the speaker wishes to comment on.

examples.zh: 说着说着我就发现自己也糊涂了。
examples.en: I was talking and talking, and then I confused myself.

examples.zh: 我今天一直都在看语法的书，看着看着，就睡着了。
examples.en: Today, I was constantly studying the grammar books. As I was studying, I fell asleep.

examples.zh: 我在北京的胡同里走着走着就走丢了。
examples.en: As I was walking in one of Beijing's back roads, I got lost.

structures: 尽管 A，还是 / 仍然 B
jinguanPattern.description: 尽管 (jǐnguǎn)  means "although," and is a little stronger than 虽然, perhaps more like "even though."

examples.zh: 尽管领导今天不来，可我们还是不能偷懒。
examples.en: Even though the leaders aren't coming today, we still can't be lazy.

examples.zh: 尽管火很大，很危险，消防员仍然勇敢地冲了进去。
examples.en: Even though the fire was big and it was very dangerous, the firefighters are still bravely running in.

examples.zh: 尽管失败了好几次，可他仍然想创业。
examples.en: Even though he's failed many times, he still wants to start a business.

examples.zh: 尽管实现这个目标不太容易，但是我们不能这么快就放弃。
examples.en: Even though it's not that easy to realize this goal, we can't just give up on it.

examples.zh: 尽管没人赞同他的观点，他还是坚持自己的看法。
examples.en: Even though nobody agreed with him,he still holds to his views.

structures: 不是 + A + 而是 + B
buShiErShiPattern.description: 不是⋯⋯而是⋯⋯ (bù shì... ér shì) means "not A, but rather B." This is a useful phrase to use in arguments to overturn a point of view and state the opposite.

examples.zh: 我不是不想帮忙而是没有能力帮忙。
examples.en: It's not that I don't want to help, it's that I can't help.

examples.zh: 我认为有的人做慈善活动的目的不是为了帮助穷人而是为了提高他们的名誉。
examples.en: I think that some people do charitable things, not only to help poor people, but also to improve their reputation.

structures: 不管 + Situation + Subj. + (都 / 也) + Result
buguanPattern.description: 不管 (bùguǎn) is more informal than 无论, but it is used in more or less the same way. As with other constructions, 都 and 也 can be used in the second part of the sentence to emphasize the action or decision will not change.

examples.zh: 不管你信不信，反正我信！
examples.en: It doesn't matter if you believe or not, I believe it anyway.

examples.zh: 不管我是在英国还是不在英国，我都习惯每天吃英式早餐。
examples.en: It doesn't matter if I'm in England or not, I'm always used to eating English breakfasts.

examples.zh: 为了你，不管让我付出什么代价，我都觉得值得。
examples.en: For you, it doesn't matter how much you make me invest in our friendship, I will still think you're worth it.

structures: 无论 + Circumstances + 都 / 也 + Inevitable Result
wulunPattern.description: 无论 (wúlùn)  means "no matter," and is generally used in the first part of the sentence. As with many other constructions, 都 and 也 can be used in the second part of the sentence to emphasize the action or decision will not change. It is more formal than 不管.

examples.zh: 无论怎么样，他都会放弃，别高估他。
examples.en: No matter what it's like, he will give up. Don't overestimate him.

examples.zh: 无论多么成功，他总觉得自己不够好。
examples.en: No matter how successful he is, he always thinks he isn't enough.

examples.zh: 无论你到哪儿我都会跟着你。
examples.en: Wherever you go, I will follow you.

examples.zh: 无论你说还是不说，结果都一样。
examples.en: Whatever you say, the result will be the same.

structures: Subj.+ 之所以 + Effect + 是因为 + Cause
zhiSuoyiShiYinweiPattern.description: 之所以⋯⋯是因为 (zhī suǒyǐ... shì yīnwèi) can be translated as “the reason why... is because” and can be used if the speaker wishes to state the effect before the cause.  It's normally used in somewhat formal speech.

examples.zh: 他之所以去希腊是因为想进一步了解西方文明。
examples.en: The reason he went to Greece was because he wanted to further understand Western culture.

examples.zh: 少数民族之所以受到人类学家的注意是因为他们至今还保留着许多传统文化。
examples.en: The reason minorities receive a lot of attention from anthropologists is because they maintain most of their traditional culture up until today.

examples.zh: 你之所以能够追求精神上的快乐是因为你已经有了稳定的物质基础。
examples.en: The reason you can pursue spiritual happiness is because you already have a stable material foundation.

structures: 除非 x ，否则 / 不然 y
chufeiPattern.description: 除非 (chúfēi) can be used as a conjunction, and means "unless." 否则 (fǒuzé) or 不然 (bùrán) often appear in the following phrase, to form a construction meaning "unless x, otherwise y":

examples.zh: 老板不给你加薪，除非你表现很好。
examples.en: The boss won't give you a raise unless you perform well.

examples.zh: 公司不允许员工请假，除非理由很充分。
examples.en: The company won't allow it's staff time off unless their reason is good enough.

examples.zh: 欧洲的经济无法恢复正常，除非希腊债务问题得以解决。
examples.en: Europe will be unable to normalize it's economy, unless Greece resolves it's debt problem.

examples.zh: 我们会破产，除非能申请到银行贷款。
examples.en: We're going to go bankrupt unless we are able to apply for a bank loan.

examples.zh: 除非你表现很好，否则老板不给你加薪。
examples.en: Unless your performance is good, the boss won't give you a raise.

examples.zh: 除非理由很充分，否则公司不允许员工请假。
examples.en: Unless the reason is good, the company won't give its staff time off.

examples.zh: 除非希腊债务问题得以解决，不然欧洲的经济无法恢复正常。
examples.en: Unless Greece resolves it's debt problem, Europe won't be able to bring its economy back to normal.

examples.zh: 除非能申请到银行贷款，否则我们就会破产。
examples.en: Unless we can apply for a bank loan, we're going to go bankrupt.

examples.zh: 除非理由很充分，公司才允许员工请假。
examples.en: Only if the reason is good enough will the company give its staff time off.

examples.zh: 除非你表现很好，老板才给你加薪。
examples.en: Unless your performance is good, the boss won't give you a raise.

examples.zh: 除非希腊债务问题得以解决，欧洲的经济才恢复正常。
examples.en: Only if Greece resolves its debt problem will Europe be able to bring its economy back to normal.

examples.zh: 除非能申请到银行贷款，我们才不会破产。
examples.en: Only if we can apply for the loan will we be able to avoid going bankrupt.

ningkePattern.description: 宁可 (nìngkě) is used where the speaker wants to compare two unfavorable options, and choose a "unfavorable option" over a "most unfavorable option."

examples.zh: 我宁可没有男朋友，也不要随便找一个男朋友。
examples.en: I'd rather have no boyfriend than find a random one.

examples.zh: 他宁可输，也不想放弃。
examples.en: He'd rather lose than give up.

examples.zh: 我宁可在公司加班，也不想把工作带回家。
examples.en: I'd rather work late in the office than take my work home.

examples.zh: 他宁可每天吃方便面，也不找父母要钱。
examples.en: He'd rather eat instant noodles every day than ask his parents for money.

examples.zh: 我宁可把这些东西送给陌生人，也不会扔掉。
examples.en: I'd rather give these old things to strange people than throw it away.

examples.zh: 我宁可几天不睡觉，也要完成这个项目。
examples.en: I would be willing not to sleep for a few days just to finish this project.

examples.zh: 他们宁可花光所有钱，也要治好女儿的病。
examples.en: They would spend all my money to cure their daughter's disease.

examples.zh: 我们宁可多花点钱，也要解决这个问题。
examples.en: We'd rather spend some more money to solve this problem.

structures: 一面 + Verb +  一面 + Verb
yimianPattern.description: 一面 (yìmiàn)  is a more formal than 一边, but is used in the same way to express two simultaneous actions. It is used in the following way:

examples.zh: 他喜欢一面吃东西，一面看电影。
examples.en: He likes to eat and watch movies at the same time.

examples.zh: 我告诉你多少次了，别一面躺在床上一面吃零食！弄得床上都是碎屑!
examples.en: I told you so many times, don't eat while laying on the bed. The "clean" bed now has crumbs all over it!

examples.zh: 他们一家人一面赏月一面吃月饼。
examples.en: They enjoy the moon and eat mooncakes together as a family.

examples.zh: 你会一面拍头一面揉肚子吗？
examples.en: Can you pat your head and rub your belly at the same time?

examples.zh: 政府一面要控制通货膨胀，一面也要保证一定的经济增长速度。
examples.en: On one hand, the government is going to control inflation, but on the other hand, it's definitely going to protect economic growth.

huozhePattern.description: One easy way to give two options is to precede each one with 或者 (huòzhě).

examples.zh: 只有一块蛋糕，或者你吃或者我吃。
examples.en: There's only one piece of cake. Either you eat it, or I eat it.

examples.zh: 你或者学汉语，或者学法律，别的就别学了。
examples.en: Either study Chinese or law. Don't study anything else.

examples.zh: 咱们或者去爬山或者泡温泉。
examples.en: Let's either go hiking or go to the hot springs.

structures: 别说 + A ， 连  / 就是+ B + 也 / 都 + Verb
bieShuoPattern.description: 别说 (bié shuō) means something like "leaving aside" or "don't think about," and is used in the following way:

examples.zh: 别说一百，就是一块钱我也不给你。
examples.en: Don't think about one hundred, I won't even give you one kuai.

examples.zh: 别说白酒，连啤酒的味道我都受不了。
examples.en: Don't even mention baijiu, I can't even stand the taste of beer.

examples.zh: 这么难的问题，别说你，就是老师也不知道答案。
examples.en: Don't even mention you, the teacher can't even know the answer to such a difficult question.

examples.zh: 别说做菜了，他连怎么煮方便面都不知道。
examples.en: Don't even think about cooking. He doesn't even know how to boil instant noodles.

structures: 连 + A + 都 / 也 + Verb， 更不用说 + B + 了
gengBuyongShuoPattern.description: 更不用说 (gèng bùyòng shuō) means "let alone," and is used in the same way as the English, where we might say: "he can't even boil an egg, let alone prepare a banquet"

examples.zh: 他都不会煮鸡蛋，更不用说做一大桌子的菜了。
examples.en: He can't boil an egg, let alone prepare a banquet.

examples.zh: 他连自己国家的国旗都不认识，更不用说其他国家的了。
examples.en: He can't even recognize his own country's flag, not to mention any other countries' flags.

examples.zh: 他从来没有出过远门，更不用说出国了。
examples.en: He's never traveled very far, let alone out of the country.

structures: Subj. + 连 + A + 都 + (不 / 没) + Verb， 何况 + B + 呢？
hekuangPattern.description: 何况 (hékuàng) can mean "let alone" or "all the more." It can be used in the following structure:

examples.zh: 我连一万块钱都有，何况一千呢？
examples.en: I have 10000 yuan, and you're saying I don't even have 1000?

examples.zh: 孩子连跑都会，何况走路呢？
examples.en: The child can run, how could he not walk?

examples.zh: 你连那么难的试题都会，何况这么容易的呢？
examples.en: You can answer questions that hard, something like this should be easy, right?

examples.zh: 我连一千块钱都没有，何况一万呢？
examples.en: I don't even have 1000 yuan, let alone 10000.

examples.zh: 孩子连走路都不会，何况跑呢？
examples.en: The baby can't even walk, let alone run.

examples.zh: 你连这么简单的试题都不会，何况那么难的呢？
examples.en: You couldn't answer a question that easy, and you're kidding yourself you could answer one that hard?

examples.zh: 本地人都经常会迷路的，何况外地人！
examples.en: Natives get lost all the time, so imagine the foreigners!

examples.zh: 这个地方本来就不好找，更何况你也是第一次来！
examples.en: This place has always been hard to find, especially on your first time!

structures: Noun + 不仅 + A，而且 + B
expressingNotOnlyButAlsoWithBujinPattern.description: There are a few ways to express "not only ... but also" in Chinese. One of them is:

examples.zh: 他不仅很帅，而且很聪明。
examples.en: He is not only handsome, but also intelligent.

examples.zh: 我们不仅完成了任务而且比规定日期提前了十天。
examples.en: We not only completed the task, but we did so ten days ahead of schedule.

examples.zh: 这道菜不仅好吃而且很有营养。
examples.en: This dish is not only tasty, but also nutritious.

structures: Subj. + 不仅 / 不但 / 不只 + ⋯⋯，而且 / 还 / 也 + ⋯⋯
buJinPattern.description:
We've seen 不但⋯⋯而且 in B1, but other than that there are a number of other structures which can be used to express "not only...but also." 不但 can be substituted with 不仅(bù jǐn) and 不只  (bù zhǐ), all meaning "not only," and can be followed by 而且 (ér qiě) , 还 (hái), or 也 (yě) 
Other than 不但⋯⋯而且 being more common than the others, they are all pretty similar in usage and meaning.

examples.zh: 这篇文章不仅结构清楚，而且思想先进。
examples.en: This essay is not only written clearly, but is also well-developed.

examples.zh: 他不仅喜欢吃中国菜，而且也会做几个中国菜！
examples.en: He not only likes to eat Chinese food, but he can make some as well!

examples.zh: 这个外国人不只会唱民歌，还会说方言，真是了不起！
examples.en: Not only can this foreigner sing folk songs, but he can also speak the dialect. That's really amazing!

examples.zh: 他不但聪明还很善良。难怪他这么受大家的喜爱！
examples.en: He's not only smart, but also kind. No wonder everyone loves him.

structures: Subj. + 总算 / 终于 + Verb
zongsuanPattern.description: One pair of confusing adverbs is 总算 (zǒngsuàn) and 终于 (zhōngyú). They both can be translated as "finally" or "in the end," but they subtly different in tone.

examples.zh: 你总算来了！
examples.en: You finally came!

examples.zh: 我终于懂了。
examples.en: I finally understood it.

examples.zh: 雨总算停了。
examples.en: The rain finally stopped.

examples.zh: 我终于找到你了！
examples.en: I finally found you!

examples.zh: 飞机总算起飞了！
examples.en: The plane is finally taking off!

examples.zh: 谢天谢地，你总算来了。
examples.en: Thank God, you finally came.

examples.zh: 总算没迟到。
examples.en: You finally didn't arrive late.

examples.zh: 她的感冒总算好了。
examples.en: She finally got over her cold.

examples.zh: 你终于决定了！
examples.en: You finally decided this!

examples.zh: 终于要放假了，开心吧？
examples.en: You finally have your holidays. You're happy about it, aren't you?

examples.zh: 你们合作的项目终于成功了!
examples.en: This project you've been working on together finally succeed!

theAlsoAdverbYePattern.description: The English adverb "too" or "also" is expressed in Chinese as 也 (yě). In Chinese, it always needs to come before the verb (or adjective).

examples.zh: 我也喜欢。
examples.en: I also like it.

examples.zh: 我也是学生。
examples.en: I am a student too.

examples.zh: 她也有一个儿子。
examples.en: She also has a son.

examples.zh: 他们也是法国人吗？
examples.en: Are they also French?

examples.zh: 我也想学中文。
examples.en: I also want to study Chinese.

examples.zh: 他们也会去吗？
examples.en: Are they also going?

examples.zh: 我妈妈也喜欢吃饺子。
examples.en: My mother likes to eat boiled dumplings too.

examples.zh: 孩子也可以喝酒吗？
examples.en: Can kids drink alcohol too?

examples.zh: 你也想来我家吗？
examples.en: Do you want to come to my house too?

examples.zh: 她也觉得这个老师不好。
examples.en: She also thinks this teacher isn't good.

examples.zh: 我也不喜欢。
examples.en: I don't like it either.

examples.zh: 我也不知道。
examples.en: I don't know either.

examples.zh: 他也没有。
examples.en: He doesn't have it either.

examples.zh: 你也不想来我家吗？
examples.en: You don't want to come to my house either?

examples.zh: 你也很高。
examples.en: You are also tall.

examples.zh: 他也很胖。
examples.en: He is also fat.

examples.zh: 我爸爸也很帅。
examples.en: My dad is also handsome.

examples.zh: 湖南菜也很辣。
examples.en: Hunan food is very spicy too.

examples.zh: 这种酒也很好喝。
examples.en: This kind of alcohol is also good.

examples.zh: 这个地方也很漂亮。
examples.en: This place is also pretty.

examples.zh: 昨天很冷，今天也很冷。
examples.en: Yesterday was cold, and today is also cold.

examples.zh: 他生气了？我也很生气！
examples.en: He got angry? I'm also angry!

examples.zh: 这个问题也很麻烦。
examples.en: This problem is also very troublesome.

examples.zh: 我觉得这个餐厅也很好。
examples.en: I think that this restaurant is also good.

examples.zh: 我也是。
examples.en: Me too. / I am too.

expressingOnTheBasisOfWithPingPattern.description: 凭 is a  preposition that means "on the basis of" or "by virtue of." Usually the subject of a sentence with 凭 is a person.

examples.zh: 凭护照，外国人可以买火车票。
examples.en: With the help of a passport, foreigners can buy train tickets.

examples.zh: 他凭自己的努力学了三千多个汉字。
examples.en: He studied more than three thousand Chinese characters on his own volition.

examples.zh: 我们凭学生证在电影院享受折扣优待。
examples.en: Since we have student ID cards, we enjoy a special discount at the movie theater.

examples.zh: 怪不得那个孩子的数学不好，他只凭计算器算。
examples.en: No wonder that kid's math is so bad. It's because he always uses a calculator.

examples.zh: 学好跳舞不能只凭看迈克尔·杰克逊的音乐录像带，还得凭自己的努力。
examples.en: Watching Michael Jackson music videos isn't enough to study how to dance. You also have to push yourself.

examples.zh: 凭老李在这一行做了二十年，他就有资格做你的师傅。
examples.en: On the basis of Old Li's twenty years of experience, he is qualified to be your teacher.

examples.zh: 凭我学中文的时间比你短但是说得比你好，我就可以说我比你聪明。
examples.en: From the fact that I have studied Chinese for a shorter time, but speak better than you, I can say that I'm more intelligent than you are.

examples.zh: 你凭什么怪我！
examples.en: On what grounds are you blaming me?

examples.zh: 我没有做错，他凭什么骂我？
examples.en: I haven't done anything wrong. How can you scold me?

examples.zh: 她一直很忠诚，你凭什么怀疑她？
examples.en: She's always been honest, how can you mistrust her?

examples.zh: 小白凭着自己的努力致富。
examples.en: Off of his own hard work, Little Bai was able to become rich.

examples.zh: 他凭着智慧战胜了很多的困难。
examples.en: Using his intellect, he was able to overcome many challenges.

expressingRatherWithBijiaoPattern.description: It's rather nice to be able to read an article on how to use 比较 to mean "rather." And here it is!

examples.zh: 她比较聪明。
examples.en: She is rather intelligent.

examples.zh: 你比较胖。
examples.en: You're rather fat.

examples.zh: 这件事情比较复杂。
examples.en: This matter is rather complicated.

huxiangPattern.description: When some action is mutual, you can use the word 互相 (hùxiāng). The word "mutual" feels formal in English, but in Chinese even everyday phrases such as "learn from each other" use the word 互相, which expresses this "each other" aspect.

examples.zh: 互相帮助
examples.en: Help each other

examples.zh: 互相了解
examples.en: Know each other

examples.zh: 互相伤害
examples.en: Hurt each other

examples.zh: 互相尊重
examples.en: Respect each other

examples.zh: 互相支持
examples.en: Support each other

examples.zh: 互相鼓励
examples.en: Encourage each other

examples.zh: 互相影响
examples.en: Influence each other

examples.zh: 互相利用
examples.en: Take advantage of each other

examples.zh: 互相看了一眼
examples.en: glanced at each other

haishiBaPattern.description: One of the ways to use 还是 (háishì) is to have it mean "you had better," similar to how in English we may say "I think you had better start on your homework." 吧 is often placed after this structure, as it's a suggestion. When the part after 还是 is a negative verb phrase, it's OK to drop the 吧 at the end.

examples.zh: 我们还是明天去吧。
examples.en: We'd better go tomorrow.

examples.zh: 还是让她走吧。
examples.en: We'd better let her go.

examples.zh: 你还是帮帮他吧。
examples.en: You'd better help him with this.

examples.zh: 还是别问了吧。
examples.en: We'd better not ask.

examples.zh: 太贵了，还是别买了吧。
examples.en: It's too expensive. You'd better not buy it.

examples.zh: 你还是现在就跟我说吧。
examples.en: You'd better talk with me now.

examples.zh: 我饿了，我们还是先吃饭吧。
examples.en: I'm hungry; we had better eat first.

examples.zh: 这里太脏了，我们还是走吧。
examples.en: It's too dirty here; we'd better leave.

examples.zh: 你做得太慢了，还是让他做吧。
examples.en: You did too slowly. We'd better ask him to do it.

examples.zh: 快迟到了，我们还是打车吧。
examples.en: We're running late. Let's take a taxi.

examples.zh: 太贵了，还是别买了。
examples.en: It's too expensive. You'd better not buy it.

examples.zh: 她不想说，还是不要再问了。
examples.en: She doesn't want to say anything. We'd better stop asking.

examples.zh: 他一定不同意，还是别跟他说了。
examples.en: He will definitely disagree. We'd better not tell him.

examples.zh: 今天晚上我太忙了，不可以去酒吧。我还是做作业吧。
examples.en: I'm extremely busy tonight, so I can't go to the bar. I'd better do my homework.

examples.zh: 我听说这部电影不好看，我们还是看其他的吧。
examples.en: I heard this movie wasn't good. We should watch another one.

examples.zh: 今天的作业特别难，我们还是问老师吧。
examples.en: Today's homework is especially hard. We had better ask the teacher.

jiaruJiuPattern.description: "假如⋯⋯，就⋯⋯" (jiǎrú..., jiù...) is yet another way to express "If..., then..." in Chinese, but it is much more formal than 要是 or 如果 are (in both written and spoken Chinese).

examples.zh: 假如你的成绩再好一点儿，你就能申请北大了。
examples.en: If your grades come up a little more, then you can apply to Beijing University.

examples.zh: 假如我是你，我就戒烟。
examples.en: If I were you, I would give up smoking.

examples.zh: 假如你的女朋友不爱你，你们就分手吧。
examples.en: If your girlfriend doesn't love you, then you should break up.

zongshiPattern.description: If you are trying to describe a daily routine, a habit, or just something that consistently happens, you can use the word 总是 (zǒngshì). 总是 (zǒngshì) means "always," and like other adverbs, comes before the verb in a sentence.

examples.zh: 他总是迟到。
examples.en: He is always late.

examples.zh: 我总是忘记这个词。
examples.en: I always forget this word.

examples.zh: 他总是一个人吃饭。
examples.en: He always eats alone.

examples.zh: 你男朋友总是说脏话。
examples.en: Your boyfriend always uses foul language.

examples.zh: 我的学生总是问我很多有意思的问题。
examples.en: My students always ask me lots of interesting questions.

examples.zh: 他总是很累。
examples.en: He is always tired.

examples.zh: 你为什么总是很忙？
examples.en: Why are you always very busy?

examples.zh: 你家总是很干净。
examples.en: Your house is always very clean.

examples.zh: 孩子们总是非常开心。
examples.en: The children are always very happy.

examples.zh: 我的学生总是特别努力。
examples.en: My students are always very hard-working.

comparingHuiNengKeyiPattern.description: 会 (huì), 能 (néng), and 可以 (kěyǐ) are often translated as "can." Sometimes they are explained as: 会 means "know how to," 能 means "to be able to," and 可以 means "to have permission to." Actually, they overlap somewhat.

examples.zh: 他会修电脑。
examples.en: He knows how to fix computers.

examples.zh: 我会跳舞。
examples.en: I know how to dance.

examples.zh: 我学了两年才会说一点汉语。
examples.en: I studied for two years before I knew how to speak a little Chinese.

examples.zh: 你真的能吃三碗米饭吗？
examples.en: Are you really able to eat three bowls of rice?

examples.zh: 你能记住所有国家的名字吗？
examples.en: Are you able to remember the names of all countries?

examples.zh: 三个月的小孩子不能走路。
examples.en: Three month old children are unable to walk.

examples.zh: 我能进来吗？
examples.en: Am I allowed to enter?

examples.zh: 我可以进来吗？
examples.en: Am I allowed to enter?

examples.zh: 你可以帮我一下吗？
examples.en: Could you help me a bit?

examples.zh: 你能帮我一下吗？
examples.en: Could you help me a bit?

examples.zh: 不能带危险物品上车。
examples.en: You're not allowed to bring dangerous things in the car.

examples.zh: 不可以带危险物品上车。
examples.en: You're not allowed to bring dangerous things in the car.

examples.zh: 我能在这里抽烟吗？
examples.en: Can I smoke here?

examples.zh: 下个月我们就要结婚了，你的父母能来中国吗？
examples.en: Next month we're getting married, can your parents come to China?

examples.zh: 下个月我们就要结婚了，你的父母可以来中国吗？
examples.en: Next month we're getting married, can your parents come to China?

examples.zh: 明天你会来吗？
examples.en: Will you come tomorrow?

examples.zh: 你太过分了，没有人会这么做。
examples.en: You're too excessive. No one will do it like this.

examples.zh: 一会儿会下雨吗？
examples.en: Will it rain in a minute?

examples.zh: 这个女孩子很会唱歌。
examples.en: This girl can sing really well.

examples.zh: 我的妈妈很会做饭。
examples.en: My mother really knows how to cook.

examples.zh: 他很会骗人。
examples.en: He can really deceive people.

examples.zh: 你很会打羽毛球，以后应该当个专业羽毛球运动员。
examples.en: You can really play badminton well. You should be a professional badminton player when you grow up.

examples.zh: 你很能吃吗！
examples.en: Wow, you really can eat!

examples.zh: 你很能睡。
examples.en: You can really sleep.

examples.zh: 他今天会这么成功是因为他是一个很能吃苦的人。
examples.en: The reason he is so successful today is because he is a person who can handle a lot of burdens.

examples.zh: 我现在能跳舞了，我的脚伤好了。
examples.en: I am able to dance now, my foot is better. (The condition changed)

examples.zh: 我现在会跳舞了，我学了两个月。
examples.en: I know how to dance now, I studied for two months. (It's a learned skill)

examples.zh: 我现在可以跳舞了，我爸爸同意了。
examples.en: I'm allowed to dance now, my dad agreed. (The dad gave permission)

examples.zh: 我们学了半年中文，现在我会说一点中文。
examples.en: We have learned half a year of Chinese, now I know how to speak a little bit of Chinese (The speaker now knows a new language)

examples.zh: 你能用中文演讲吗？
examples.en: Can you use Chinese to make a speech? (The speaker is asking if that person has the ability to)

examples.zh: 我们已经说了两个小时英文，现在可以说中文吗？
examples.en: We have already spoken two hours of English, can we speak Chinese now? (The speaker is asking for permission)

examples.zh: 我会做中国菜。
examples.en: I know how to make Chinese food.

examples.zh: 你能吃辣的中国菜吗？
examples.en: Can you eat (do you have the ability to) eat spicy Chinese food?

examples.zh: 我们可以去吃中国菜吗？
examples.en: Can we go eat Chinese food? (Asking for permission)

examples.zh: A:我可以和他们一起踢足球吗？
examples.en: Can I play soccer with them? (Am I allowed?)

examples.zh: B:你的腿还没好，现在你不能踢。
examples.en: Your foot still isn't better. You can't go right now. (His rule prohibits it)

examples.zh: A:它会好吗？
examples.en: Will it get better? (会 indicates the future)

examples.zh: B:嗯，你放心吧，很快就会好的。
examples.en: Yes, don't worry, it will get better soon.

structures: Subj. + 差点 + 没 + Verb Phrase
expressingAlmostUsingChadianMeiPattern.description: Logically, 差点没 is not that different from 差点.  In fact, you shouldn't think of it as a single word; think of the 没 as belonging to what follows 差点 and it makes more sense.  Still, it can be a little confusing, and is worth a closer look.

examples.zh: 我差点儿没想起来。
examples.en: I almost forgot it.

examples.zh: 我差点没赶上火车。
examples.en: I didn't miss the train.

examples.zh: 他差点没通过考试。
examples.en: He barely passed the examination.

examples.zh: 排队的人太多了，差点儿没买到。
examples.en: The waiting line is too long. I almost didn't get it.

laoshiPattern.description: We have a few ways to say "always" in Chinese, and one of them is to use the word 老是 (lǎoshi).

examples.zh: 不要老是笑话别人。
examples.en: Don't laugh at other people all the time.

examples.zh: 他老是喜欢说脏话。
examples.en: He always likes saying bad words.

examples.zh: 他老说脏话。
examples.en: He always says bad words.

examples.zh: 老板老是让我们加班。
examples.en: The boss always asks us to work overtime.

examples.zh: 他老不来参加培训。
examples.en: He never comes to the training session.

examples.zh: 你老在别人面前说我的坏话。
examples.en: You always like speaking evil of me in front of other people.

examples.zh: 你怎么老是不高兴？
examples.en: How are you always unhappy?

examples.zh: 他对员工老是很严肃。
examples.en: He is always serious with the employees.

examples.zh: 你们不要老是紧张。
examples.en: Don't always be so nervous.

examples.zh: 我楼上的邻居晚上老是很吵。
examples.en: My neighbor upstairs is always noisy in the night.

examples.zh: 他老是对人不礼貌。
examples.en: He's always impolite to people.

structures: Subj. + Verb + Option A + 还是 + Option B
expressingOrWithHaishiAndHuozhePattern.description: Both 还是 (háishì) and  或者 (huòzhě) mean “or” and are used to present a choice.  However, 还是 is normally used when asking a question, and 或者 is mostly for declarative sentences.

examples.zh: 她喜欢你还是他？
examples.en: Does she like you or him?

examples.zh: 你喝茶还是喝咖啡？
examples.en: Do you drink tea or coffee?

examples.zh: 你中午出去吃还是叫外卖？
examples.en: Are you going out for lunch or order take-out?

examples.zh: 明天或者后天都行。
examples.en: Either tomorrow or the day after is fine.

examples.zh: 周末我想在家看书或者看电影。
examples.en: I'd like to stay at home reading or watching some movies.

examples.zh: 我不知道这本书是他的还是我的。
examples.en: I don't know if this book is his or mine.

examples.zh: 我不知道是自己跟他说还是让别人帮我跟他说。
examples.en: I don't know if I should talk to him myself or ask someone else to talk to him for me.

examples.zh: 我不清楚是我们先走还是等他们一起走。
examples.en: I'm not sure if we should leave first, or wait for them and leave together.

examples.zh: 只有一块蛋糕，或者你吃或者我吃。
examples.en: There's only one piece of cake. Either you eat it, or I do.

examples.zh: 你或者学汉语，或者学法律，别的就别学了。
examples.en: Either study Chinese or law, don't study anything else.

buguoPattern.description: Instead of just using 可是 or 但是, you can also use the softer and more informal 不过 (búguò).

examples.zh: 我可以喝白酒，不过只能喝一点。
examples.en: I can drink baijiu, but only a little.

examples.zh: 我们玩得很开心，不过住的地方不太好。
examples.en: We had a lot of fun, but the place we stayed at was not very good.

examples.zh: 他的汉语不错，不过发音不太好。
examples.en: His Chinese is pretty good, but his pronunciation is not very good.

examples.zh: 这件衣服我很喜欢，不过有点贵。
examples.en: I like this clothing, but it's a little bit expensive.

examples.zh: 这个房子很好，不过有点远。
examples.en: This house is nice, but it's a little bit far away.

structures: Subj. + 不 + 应该 + Verb + Obj.
yinggaiPattern.description: 应该 (yīnggāi) translates to the English word "should," and is an essential word to know for your conversaitonal Chinese. You should definitely get comfortable using 应该 (yīnggāi) right away!

examples.zh: 在中国，你应该喝白酒。
examples.en: In China, you should drink baijiu.

examples.zh: 我应该给你多少钱？
examples.en: How much money should I give you?

examples.zh: 感冒的时候应该喝热水。
examples.en: You should drink hot water when you have a cold.

examples.zh: 明天你应该八点半来公司。
examples.en: You should come to the office tomorrow at 8:30.

examples.zh: 他太累了，应该回家休息。
examples.en: He's too tired. He should go home and rest.

examples.zh: 你不应该告诉他。
examples.en: You should not tell him.

examples.zh: 他不应该打人。
examples.en: He should not hit people.

examples.zh: 我们不应该迟到。
examples.en: We shouldn't be late.

examples.zh: 你们不应该笑她。
examples.en: You shouldn't laugh at her.

examples.zh: 你们不应该拿别人的东西。
examples.en: You should not take other people's stuff.

expressingDontNeedToWithBuyongPattern.description: In Chinese, "要" has many meanings, one of which is "need to". However, when you want to express  "don't need to", you actually use "不用", not "不要".

examples.zh: 不用担心。
examples.en: You don't need to worry.

examples.zh: 不用你帮忙。
examples.en: You don't need to help.

examples.zh: 今天不用加班。
examples.en: We don't need to work overtime today.

examples.zh: 这件事不用跟他说。
examples.en: You don't need to tell him about this.

examples.zh: 告诉他明天不用来了。
examples.en: Tell him that he doesn't need to come tomorrow.

examples.zh: 大家不用给我买礼物。
examples.en: Guys, you don't need to buy me presents.

examples.zh: 今天人少，不用排队。
examples.en: There aren't many people today. We don't need to wait in line.

examples.zh: 五岁的孩子不用买票。
examples.en: Five-year-olds don't need to buy tickets.

examples.zh: 新员工不用参加这个会议。
examples.en: New employees don't need to attend this meeting.

examples.zh: 我们只去两天，你不用带这么多衣服。
examples.en: We are only going for two days. You don't need to take this much clothing.

connectingNounsWithShiPattern.description: The verb to be is not used in Chinese the same way as it is in English. In Chinese, 是 (shì) is for connecting nouns, and is generally not used with adjectives.

examples.zh: 我是学生。
examples.en: I am a student.

examples.zh: 你是John吗？
examples.en: Are you John?

examples.zh: 他们是有钱人。
examples.en: They are rich people.

examples.zh: 你是老板吗？
examples.en: Are you the boss?

examples.zh: 这是我男朋友。
examples.en: This is my boyfriend.

examples.zh: 那是你们公司吗？
examples.en: Is that your company?

examples.zh: 你妈妈是老师吗？
examples.en: Is your mother a teacher?

examples.zh: 这都是你的钱。
examples.en: This is all your money.

examples.zh: 那是什么菜？
examples.en: What food is that?

examples.zh: 我也是他的朋友。
examples.en: I am also his friend.

examples.zh: 他没听到，是不是？
examples.en: He didn't hear you, right?

examples.zh: 你是不是还没吃饭？
examples.en: Haven't you eaten yet?

examples.zh: 你们是不是中国人？
examples.en: Are you Chinese?

examples.zh: 你到了，是吗？
examples.en: You have arrived, yeah?

examples.zh: 你有两个孩子，是吗？
examples.en: You have two kids, yeah?

questionsWithNePattern.description: The particle 呢 (ne) can be used to ask reciprocal questions, also known as "bounce back" questions. 呢 (ne) can also be used to form simple questions asking "what about...?" or "how about...?"

examples.zh: 这个很好，那个呢？
examples.en: This one is good. What about that one?

examples.zh: 这个用中文怎么说？那个呢？
examples.en: How do I say this in Chinese? And that?

examples.zh: 我在家，你呢？
examples.en: I'm at home. What about you?

examples.zh: 你爸爸是上海人，你妈妈呢？
examples.en: Your father is Shanghainese. And your mom?

examples.zh: 你哥哥有工作，弟弟呢？
examples.en: Your big brother has a job. What about your little brother?

examples.zh: 北京下雨了。上海呢？
examples.en: It's raining in Beijing. How about in Shanghai?

examples.zh: 我现在要出去。你呢？
examples.en: I'm going to go out now. How about you?

examples.zh: 我知道你会说中文。你老公呢？
examples.en: I know you can speak Chinese. What about your husband?

examples.zh: 这个周末我想去酒吧。你们呢？
examples.en: I want to go to a bar this weekend. What about you all?

examples.zh: 今天晚上没空？明天晚上呢？
examples.en: You don't have time tonight? What about tomorrow evening?

examples.zh: 钱呢？
examples.en: Where's the money?

examples.zh: 你妈妈呢？
examples.en: Where's your mom?

examples.zh: 我的手机呢？
examples.en: Where's my cell phone?

structures: 既然＋Fact, 那 / 就 / 那就＋Suggestion / Inference
jiranPattern.description: 既然 (jìrán) means "since," and is often followed by 就 to mean "since...then...." It is used like this:

examples.zh: 你既然不想说，那就别说了。
examples.en: Since you don't want to speak, just don't say it.

examples.zh: 既然你那么喜欢，那就买吧。
examples.en: Since you like it so much, buy it then.

examples.zh: 她既然刚刚分手，那现在应该是单身吧。
examples.en: Since she just had a breakup, she should be single now.

examples.zh: 既然你们是好朋友，那他肯定会帮你吧。
examples.en: Since you guys are good friends, he will definitely help you.

examples.zh: 既然大家都不感兴趣，就换个话题吧。
examples.en: Since nobody is interested, let's change the topic.

examples.zh: 你既然不喜欢他，为什么还想跟他出去？
examples.en: Since you don't like him, why do you want to go out with him?

examples.zh: 既然你已经决定了，为什么现在后悔？
examples.en: Since you've made your decision, don't regret it then.

examples.zh: 既然他那么忙，你为什么还去打扰他？
examples.en: Since he's so busy, why would you bother him?

examples.zh: 既然已经分手了，为什么还要见面？
examples.en: Since we broke up, why would we still see each other?

examples.zh: 既然你男朋友那么有钱，那他为什么不能大方一点？
examples.en: Since your boyfriend is so rich, why can't he be more generous?

expressingHaveToWithBudebuPattern.description: 不得不 (bùdébù) has a stronger tone than "必须 (bìxū)" meaning "someone cannot help but do something."

examples.zh: 我感冒的时候一般不吃药，但是这次很严重，我不得不吃药。
examples.en: I usually don't take medicine when I have cold. But it's very bad this time, and I have to take some pills.

examples.zh: 你真的太厉害了，我不得不承认。
examples.en: You are so good. I have to admit it.

examples.zh: 老板很讨厌应酬，可是她不得不去。
examples.en: The boss doesn't like to business socializing, but she has to go.

examples.zh: 不好意思，时间有限，我不得不打断你。
examples.en: I'm sorry. We have very limited time. I have to interrupt you.

examples.zh: 这些情况很重要，我们不得不重视。
examples.en: The situation is very important. We have to take it very seriously.

expressingEverSinceWithZicongPattern.description: 自从 means "ever since" in English, and is used to express the starting point of an action in the past. It can be followed by phrases using the markers 起 and 以后

examples.zh: 自从来到湖南，我越来越能吃辣了。
examples.en: Ever since arriving in Hunan, I've been more and more able to eat spicy food.

examples.zh: 自从金融危机爆发，就业市场变得越来越不景气了。
examples.en: Ever since the economic crisis, the job market has been growing less and less.

examples.zh: 自从他跟我分手后，他就没有联系过我。
examples.en: Ever since he broke up with me, he hasn't contacted me.

auxiliaryVerbYaoAndItsMultipleMeaningsPa.description: You probably already know the basic meaning of 要 (yào) as "to want."  It is actually a quite versatile word, though, and can also take on the meanings of "to need" as well as "will (do something)."  In every case, context is crucial for figuring out which meaning someone is trying to express.

examples.zh: 你要什么？
examples.en: What do you want?

examples.zh: 我要一杯水。
examples.en: I want a cup of water.

examples.zh: 你们都要冰可乐吗？
examples.en: Do you all want coke with ice?

examples.zh: 你要茶还是咖啡？
examples.en: Do you want tea or coffee?

examples.zh: 我们要三碗米饭。
examples.en: We want three bowls of rice.

examples.zh: 你要喝什么酒？
examples.en: What kind of wine do you want to drink?

examples.zh: 爸爸要买一个新手机。
examples.en: Dad wants to buy a new cell phone.

examples.zh: 我要跟你一起去。
examples.en: I want to go with you.

examples.zh: 她要去大城市找工作。
examples.en: She wants to go to a big city to find a job.

examples.zh: 周末你们要一起看电影吗？
examples.en: Do you want to go see a movie together this weekend?

examples.zh: 你要早点睡觉。
examples.en: You need to go to bed earlier.

examples.zh: 我们明天要上班。
examples.en: We need to work tomorrow.

examples.zh: 老板今天要见一个新客户。
examples.en: Today the boss needs to see a new client.

examples.zh: 老师太累了，要好好休息。
examples.en: The teacher is too tired. She needs to rest well.

examples.zh: 明天下雨，你要带伞。
examples.en: It's going to rain tomorrow; you need to bring an umbrella.

examples.zh: 星期五我们要开会。
examples.en: We are going to have a meeting on Friday.

examples.zh: 12点我要去吃饭。
examples.en: I am going to go eat at 12 o'clock.

examples.zh: 老板下周要出差吗？
examples.en: Is the boss going on a business trip next week?

examples.zh: 他们明年要结婚了。
examples.en: They are going to get married next year.

examples.zh: 今年你要回家过年吗？
examples.en: Are you going to return home this year to celebrate the Chinese New Year?

expressingThatsAllWithEryiPattern.description: 而已 expresses that something is merely what it is. It is like saying "it's only a test, that's all." 而已 is put at the end of the sentence to emphasis that something is just what it is.

examples.zh: 他只是开个玩笑而已，不要当真。
examples.en: He's just making a joke, that's all, don't take it seriously

examples.zh: 这次会议没有达成具体的方案，仅仅是在这个问题上达成了共识而已。
examples.en: This conference hasn't reached a concrete plan, it's just been able to answer one question and that's all

structures: Subj. + 本来 + 是 +（不）要 / 会 / 应该 + Verb + 的，但是 / 可是 ...
Subj. + 本来 + 就 + 很 / 不 + Adj.
Subj. + 本来 + 就 + 会 / 要 / 得 / 应该 + Verb
benlaiPattern.description: If something was originally a certain way, or "should be" a certain way, the Chinese words used are often 本来 (běnlái) and 原来 (yuánlái). 本来 (běnlái) is usually an adverb while 原来 (yuánlái) could be either and adjective or an adverb. However, they are used in different ways and different circumstances, so this article will help you distinguish when and where to use them.

examples.zh: 我本来是要去的，不过后来不太舒服，就没去。
examples.en: I was originally going, but I didn't go because I didn't feel very well.

examples.zh: 他本来是应该考得更好的，可是那天他生病了。
examples.en: He would have done better on the test, but he was sick that day.

examples.zh: 我们本来想去找他帮忙的，可是他那么忙，就没去。
