examples.en: We were going to ask him for help, but we didn't because he was so busy.

examples.zh: 这些工作本来是要今天做完的，不过明天做也可以。
examples.en: This work needs to be done by today. But it's OK to leave it to tomorrow.

examples.zh: 我本来要跟他结婚的，可是后来发现了我们真的不合适。
examples.en: I was originally going to marry him, but then I found that we are just not meant for each other.

examples.zh: 你本来就够瘦了，还要减肥吗？
examples.en: You are already so thin and you still want to lose weight?

examples.zh: 他讲得本来就不对，为什么还要我听他的？
examples.en: What he says has always been wrong, so why do you still want me to listen to him?

examples.zh: 她本来就很有钱，当然买得起了。
examples.en: She is rich. Of course she can afford it.

examples.zh: 她本来就不喜欢你，你别再追她了。
examples.en: She never liked you in the first place, so stop pursuing her.

examples.zh: 他本来就很喜欢开玩笑，你别介意。
examples.en: He has always liked joking around, so don't take it personally.

examples.zh: 照顾孩子本来就是父母的责任。
examples.en: Taking care of children is supposed to be the responsibility of parents.

examples.zh: 老师本来就应该好好备课。
examples.en: Teachers are supposed to prepare their lessons well.

examples.zh: 美国人本来就会说流利的英文。
examples.en: Well, of course Americans speak fluent English.

examples.zh: 搬家本来就很麻烦。
examples.en: Moving is always a pain.

examples.zh: 生活本来就很不容易。
examples.en: No one ever said life was easy.

structures: Subj. + 不比 + Noun + Adj. / Verb
buBiPattern.description: You might wonder why you have 不比 (bù bǐ) for negative comparisons when you already have 没有 (méiyǒu) for comparisons. The answer is that they're not exactly the same thing! 没有 should be your "go to word" for expressing "not as... as...," but there are cases where 不比 (in all of its subtle glory) is a better choice.

examples.zh: 这个老师不比他的学生聪明。
examples.en: The teacher is not smarter than his students.

examples.zh: 明星的生活不比普通人容易。
examples.en: Those stars' life is not easier than the folks'.

examples.zh: 我不比你适应现代都市生活。
examples.en: I am not more accustomed to the life in modern cities than you.

examples.zh: 我不比你翻译得好。
examples.en: I don't translate as well as you do.

structures: 每 + Verb + Number + Measure Word + Noun + 都 + Verb
meiDouPattern.description: 每⋯⋯都⋯⋯ (měi... dōu...) is a pattern used to express "every time," even though the phrase 每次 (měi cì) may not be explicitly used.

examples.zh: 他每遇到一个问题都要记下来。
examples.en: Every time he comes across a problem, he needs to write it down.

examples.zh: 她每去一个地方都要拍照。
examples.en: Every time she visits some place, she takes photos.

examples.zh: 他每拍完一部电影都要休息一个月。
examples.en: Every time he finishes shooting a movie, he needs to take a break for one month.

examples.zh: 记住，每写完一篇文章都要保存。
examples.en: Remember, every time you finish writing an article, save it.

examples.zh: 他每换一个工作，都要搬家。
examples.en: Every time he starts a new job, he moves.

examples.zh: 为什么我每说一件事，你都要问“真的吗”？
examples.en: Why you have to ask "really" every time I say something?

expressingOnlyWithZhiPattern.description: There are a number of different ways to express "only" in Chinese, but 只 (zhǐ) is the most basic one you need to learn first. It's an adverb, so it normally comes before verbs.

examples.zh: 我只有一个哥哥。
examples.en: I only have one older brother.

examples.zh: 我们只有十块钱。
examples.en: We only have ten RMB.

examples.zh: 我们公司只有两个员工。
examples.en: Our company only has two employees.

examples.zh: 你只爱吃肉吗？
examples.en: Do you only like eating meat?

examples.zh: 他们只会说英文。
examples.en: They can only speak English.

examples.zh: 我只能说两句中文。
examples.en: I can only say two sentences in Chinese.

examples.zh: 你们只要咖啡吗？
examples.en: Do you only want coffee?

examples.zh: 我老婆只要一个孩子。
examples.en: My wife only wants one child.

examples.zh: 宝宝只会走，不会跑。
examples.en: The baby can only walk. He can't run.

examples.zh: 我只想跟你在一起。
examples.en: I only want to be with you.

structures: Noun 1 + 比 + Noun 2 + 更 + Adj.
basicComparisonsWithBiPattern.description: One of the most common words when comparing things in Chinese is to use 比 (bǐ). 比 (bǐ) has similarities to the English word "than," but it requires a word order that's not so intuitive, so you'll want to practice it quite a bit.

examples.zh: 小李比小张高。
examples.en: Xiao Li is taller than Xiao Zhang.

examples.zh: 小张比小李矮。
examples.en: Xiao Zhang is shorter than Xiao Li.

examples.zh: 他比老师聪明。
examples.en: He is smarter than the teacher.

examples.zh: 上海比纽约大吗？
examples.en: Is Shanghai bigger than New York?

examples.zh: 她比她妈妈漂亮。
examples.en: She is prettier than her mother.

examples.zh: 星巴克的咖啡比这里的咖啡贵。
examples.en: The coffee at Starbucks is more expensive than the coffee here.

examples.zh: 地铁比公交车方便。
examples.en: The subway is more convenient than the bus.

examples.zh: 你比我聪明。
examples.en: You are smarter than me.

examples.zh: 小李比小张更高。
examples.en: Xiao Li is even taller than Xiao Zhang.

examples.zh: 我哥哥比我更高。
examples.en: My big brother is even taller than me.

examples.zh: 你男朋友比我男朋友更帅。
examples.en: Your boyfriend is even more handsome than mine.

examples.zh: 这里的冬天比纽约的冬天更冷。
examples.en: The winter here is even colder than it is in New York.

examples.zh: 中文语法比汉字更好玩。
examples.en: Chinese grammar is even more fun than Chinese characters.

examples.zh: 你的问题比我的问题更麻烦。
examples.en: Your problem is even more troublesome than mine.

structures: Subj. + 不 + 可以 + Verb + Obj.
keyiPattern.description: 可以 (kěyǐ) is an auxiliary verb primarily used for expressing permission. It's often translated as "can," but in order to not get it confused with other words, it's best to think of it as "may" to emphasize the permission aspect.

examples.zh: 我可以进来吗？
examples.en: May I come in?

examples.zh: 二十一岁以后可以喝酒。
examples.en: After you are 21 years old, you may drink alcohol.

examples.zh: 妈妈，我可以出去玩吗？
examples.en: Mom, may I go out and play?

examples.zh: 我们可以在办公室吃饭吗？
examples.en: Can we eat in the office?

examples.zh: 我可以在这里停车吗？
examples.en: Can I park here?

examples.zh: 孩子不可以看这个。
examples.en: Children can't watch this.

examples.zh: 你现在不可以进去。
examples.en: You can't go in right now.

examples.zh: 这里不可以抽烟。
examples.en: You can't smoke here.

examples.zh: 我们都不可以去。
examples.en: None of us may go.

examples.zh: 你不可以说脏话。
examples.en: You can't say swear words.

concedingWithBaPattern.description: The particle 吧 (ba) can also be used to concede a point. That is, 吧 (ba) can be used to accept or agree with something that you're not particularly happy about, the way we might use "all right" or "fine then" in English.

examples.zh: A:太贵了！B:好吧，我们可以看看别的。
examples.en: A: That's too expensive! B: All right, we can take a look at something else.

examples.zh: A:下午我不在家，你可以晚上来吗？ B:行吧。
examples.en: A: This afternoon I won't be home. Can you come by this evening? B: All right.

examples.zh: A:雨太大了，明天再去买吧。B:好吧，但是明天一定要买到。
examples.en: A: It's raining heavily. Let's go buy it tomorrow. B: Fine, but tomorrow we definitely have to buy it.

examples.zh: A:可以带朋友吗？ B:行吧，但是不能带女孩。
examples.en: A: Can I bring friends? B: All right, but you can't bring girls.

examples.zh: A:我今天不太舒服，你可以自己去吗？ B:好吧，那你好好休息。
examples.en: A: I'm not feeling well today. Can you go by yourself? B: All right, rest well then.

expressingAgainInTheFutureWithZaiPattern.description: While 又 (yòu) is used for "again" in the past, 再 (zài) is used for "again" in the future. That is, 再 is used when something has happened once and it will happen again.

examples.zh: 我明天再来。
examples.en: I'll come again tomorrow.

examples.zh: 请再说一遍。
examples.en: Say it again, please.

examples.zh: 我想再看一遍。
examples.en: I want to watch it again.

examples.zh: 你再试一下。
examples.en: Try it again.

examples.zh: 你可以帮我再问一下吗？
examples.en: Can you ask for me one more time?

examples.zh: 再吃一点。
examples.en: Eat more.

examples.zh: 我们再找一个人吧。
examples.en: Let's find another person.

examples.zh: 我们再等他五分钟吧。
examples.en: Let's wait for him five more minutes.

examples.zh: 你再给我五十块。
examples.en: Give me fifty more kuai.

examples.zh: 我们再给她一点时间。
examples.en: We'll give her a little more time.

examples.zh: 再找找。
examples.en: Keep looking a little bit.

examples.zh: 再等等他吧。
examples.en: Keep waiting for him for a little while.

examples.zh: 时间还早，再玩一会儿吧。
examples.en: It's still early. Let's keep playing for a while.

examples.zh: 现在才六点半，我想再睡一会儿。
examples.en: It's only 6:30. I want to sleep a little longer.

examples.zh: 你们想不想再休息一会儿？
examples.en: Do you guys want to rest for a little longer?

ganggangPattern.description: For events that happened in the immediate past, in English we use the word "just." For example, if you pass a turn you were supposed to make, you might say, "I just passed it!" In Chinese, "just" can be expressed with 刚 (gāng) or 刚刚 (gānggāng).

examples.zh: 我们刚知道。
examples.en: We just found out.

examples.zh: 她们刚走。
examples.en: They just left.

examples.zh: 老板刚刚到办公室。
examples.en: The boss just arrived at the office.

examples.zh: 我老婆刚生完孩子。
examples.en: My wife just finished giving birth to our baby.

examples.zh: 你刚刚下班吗？
examples.en: Did you just get off work?

examples.zh: 我刚认识她十天。
examples.en: I just met her ten days ago.

examples.zh: 他刚来中国两个月。
examples.en: He just got to China two months ago.

examples.zh: 我弟弟刚工作半年。
examples.en: My younger brother just started working half a year ago.

examples.zh: 她刚结婚三个月。
examples.en: She just got married three months ago.

examples.zh: 我的车刚买两天，开的时候小心点。
examples.en: I just bought the car two days ago. Be careful when you drive.

structures: Subj. + 还 + 不 / 没 + Verb + Obj.
continuationWithHaiPattern.description: If you "still" need help on how to use 还 (hái), then this is the page for you.

examples.zh: 他还在看书。
examples.en: He is still reading.

examples.zh: 我还在加班。
examples.en: I am still working overtime.

examples.zh: 十点了，你还在睡？
examples.en: It's ten o'clock, are you still sleeping?

examples.zh: 你还在生气吗？
examples.en: Are you still mad?

examples.zh: 你还在用那个旧手机啊？
examples.en: Are you still using that old cell phone?

examples.zh: 我看了好几遍，还是记不住。
examples.en: I read several times, but I still can't remember it.

examples.zh: 父母不同意他去，可是他还是去了。
examples.en: He still went there although his patents disagreed.

examples.zh: 医生不让她喝酒，但她还是天天喝。
examples.en: The doctor told her to stop drinking alcohol, but she still drinks it everyday.

examples.zh: 老师虽然生病了，但还是来上课了。
examples.en: The teacher still made it to the class although she got sick.

examples.zh: 他在美国住了十年，可是口语还是很差。
examples.en: He lived in the USA for 10 years. But his spoken English is still not good.

examples.zh: 他还没到。
examples.en: He hasn't arrived yet.

examples.zh: 你还没吃饭？
examples.en: You still haven't eaten?

examples.zh: 你们还不走？
examples.en: You have't left yet?

examples.zh: 我还没下班。
examples.en: I haven't finished work yet.

examples.zh: 我对你那么好，你还不满意？
examples.en: I'm so good to you, you're still not satisfied?

kongpaPattern.description: 恐怕 (kǒngpà) can be used to express "I'm afraid that," or "I'm concerned that," or even "I'm worried that," followed by some sort of reason. It doesn't need to be something you're literally afraid of; it may be that you're just trying to soften the blow of some bad news, as in, "I'm afraid that I'm too busy washing my hair tomorrow night to come over and see the 2000 pictures of your trip to ComicCon."

examples.zh: 明天我很忙，恐怕没有时间。
examples.en: I'm busy tomorrow, I'm afraid I don't have time.

examples.zh: 已经很晚了，恐怕他不会来了。
examples.en: It's already very late. I'm afraid he's not coming.

examples.zh: 这样做恐怕不行。
examples.en: I'm afraid it doesn't work this way.

examples.zh: 工作太多了，恐怕今天做不完。
examples.en: There's too much work. I'm afraid I can't finish it all today.

examples.zh: 饭太多了，恐怕我吃不完。
examples.en: Rice is too much. I'm afraid I can't eat it all.

examples.zh: 恐怕我今天没有时间做作业。
examples.en: I'm afraid today I don't have time to do homework.

structures: Past Event 1 + 后来 + Past Event 2
houlaiPattern.description: "⋯⋯, 后来⋯⋯" (..., hòulái...) is used to sequence past events in the same way that "Afterward..." is in English. Something very important to note is that 后来 can only be used with two events that have already occurred.

examples.zh: 开始他不同意，但后来他同意了。
examples.en: At first he didn't agree, but then he did later.

examples.zh: 上个星期我的朋友生病了，不过后来他病好了。
examples.en: Last week my friend got sick, but then he got better.

examples.zh: 她昨天吃了海鲜，后来她食物中毒了。
examples.en: She ate seafood yesterday, but then she got food poisoning.

examples.zh: 我邻居家的孩子丢了，后来又找到了。
examples.en: My neighbor's child was missing, and then they found him .

examples.zh: 北京以前叫北平，后来改成了北京。
examples.en: Beijing used to be called Beiping and got changed into Beijing later.

structures: 每 + Measure Word + Noun + 都
expressingEveryWithMeiPattern.description: In this article we will look at the structure for saying "every" in Chinese, which is slightly more involved than just throwing in the word 每 (měi).

examples.zh: 每个菜都好吃。
examples.en: Every dish is delicious.

examples.zh: 你每个人都认识吗？
examples.en: Do you know every person?

examples.zh: 老板每个月都出差。
examples.en: The boss goes on business trips every month.

examples.zh: 他每天都不吃早饭。
examples.en: Every morning he skips breakfast.

examples.zh: 他每年都来中国。
examples.en: He comes to China every year.

examples.zh: 我每个星期都给妈妈打电话。
examples.en: I give mom a phone call every week.

examples.zh: 这个班的每个学生都很聪明。
examples.en: Each of the students in this class are very smart.

examples.zh: 老师每天都给我们很多作业。
examples.en: Every day the teacher gives us a lot of homework.

examples.zh: 我们每周都要开会。
examples.en: Every week we need to have a meeting.

examples.zh: 他们每个周末都去公园。
examples.en: Every weekend they go to the park.

expressingTheSelfevidentWithMaPattern.description: The particle 嘛 (ma) is a sentence-final particle identical in pronunciation to the simple "yes/no question" particle 吗 (ma) you learned back in the day, but with a rather different function.  It can be used when the speaker feels what he is saying is obvious (from his point of view).

examples.zh: 你的妹妹很漂亮嘛。
examples.en: Your sister is pretty.

examples.zh: 中国人口很多嘛。
examples.en: The Chinese population is huge.

examples.zh: 美国人很开放嘛。
examples.en: Americans are very open-minded.

examples.zh: 大熊猫嘛，孩子们都很喜欢。
examples.en: Pandas. All children like them.

examples.zh: 男人嘛，总是要喝点酒，抽点烟。
examples.en: Men. They're always going to drink and smoke.

specialCasesOfZaiFollowingVerbsPattern.description: When used to indicate locations of actions, 在 (zài) is usually placed after the subject and before the verb. There are certain cases, however, when 在 (zài) goes after the verb.

examples.zh: 你住在上海吗？
examples.en: Do you live in Shanghai?

examples.zh: 他坐在老板的旁边。
examples.en: He sits next to the boss.

examples.zh: 你应该站在我后面。
examples.en: You should stand behind me.

examples.zh: 不要坐在我的床上。
examples.en: Don't sit on my bed.

examples.zh: 你的衣服不可以放在这里。
examples.en: You can't put your clothes here.

examples.zh: 不要站在路中间。
examples.en: Don't stand in the middle of the road.

examples.zh: 不要坐在地上。
examples.en: Don't sit on the ground.

examples.zh: 那本书我放在桌子上了。
examples.en: I placed that book on the table.

examples.zh: 不要走在草地上。
examples.en: Don't walk on the grass.

examples.zh: 周末我不想待在家里。
examples.en: I don't want to stay at home on weekends.

structures: Subj. + 越 + Verb + 越 + Adj.
Subj. +  越 + Verb 1 + 越 + Verb 2
Subj. 1 + 越 + Verb，Subj. 2 + 越 + Adj.
Subj. 1 + 越 + Verb 1，Subj. 2 + 越 + Verb 2
Subj. + 越 + Verb + 越 + 想 + Verb
expressingTheMoreTheMoreWithYueYuePatter.description: More than just throwing anything you want after two 越s, there are a number of specific patterns you will notice if you want to go beyond using the simpler 越来越.

examples.zh: 他越跑越快。
examples.en: The more he runs, the faster he gets.

examples.zh: 雨越下越大。
examples.en: The more it rains, the heavier the rain gets.

examples.zh: 我们越说越高兴。
examples.en: The more we talk, the happier we are.

examples.zh: 她越想越生气。
examples.en: The more she thinks about it, the angrier she gets.

examples.zh: 我越看越喜欢。
examples.en: The more I look at it, the more I like it.

examples.zh: 她越说，我越生气。
examples.en: The more she talks, the angrier I get.

examples.zh: 你们越看我，我越紧张。
examples.en: The more you look at me, the more nervous I am.

examples.zh: 我越走，腿越痛。
examples.en: The more I walk, the more my legs hurt.

examples.zh: 他越问，我越不想说。
examples.en: The more he asks, the less I want to talk.

examples.zh: 你越逼他，他越讨厌你。
examples.en: The more you push him, the more he hates you.

examples.zh: 我越看越想看。
examples.en: The more I watch it, the more I want to watch.

examples.zh: 你会越吃越想吃。
examples.en: The more you eat it, the more you will want to eat.

examples.zh: 这种花的味道让人越闻越想闻。
examples.en: The more you smell this kind of flower, the more you want to smell it.

examples.zh: 不要给孩子喝这种饮料，他们会越喝越想喝。
examples.en: Don't give this kind of drink to kids. The more they drink it, the more they want to drink it.

examples.zh: 我吃了这个药以后总是想睡觉，而且越睡越想睡。
examples.en: I'm always so sleepy after taking this medicine. And also, the more I sleep, the more l want to sleep.

structures: Subj. + 没有 + 被 + Doer + Verb Phrase
Subj. + Adv. + 被 + Doer + Verb Phrase
beizijuPattern.description: Bei Sentences, which are called 被字句 (bèizìjù) in Chinese, are a key way to express the passive in modern Mandarin Chinese.  In passive sentences, the object of an action becomes the subject of the sentence, and what would have been the subject of the normal (active voice) sentence, the "doer" of the action, becomes secondary, and may or may not be included in the passive sentence.

examples.zh: 他被开除了。
examples.en: He got fired.

examples.zh: 他肯定会被开除。
examples.en: He will definitely get fired.

examples.zh: 他被开除了。
examples.en: I have been fired (but I'm not saying who fired me, probably because it's obvious).

examples.zh: 你做的事被发现了。
examples.en: You got caught for what you did (but I'm not saying who found it, probably because it's obvious).

examples.zh: 热狗被男孩吃了。
examples.en: The hot dog was eaten by the boy.

examples.zh: 热狗被吃了。
examples.en: The hot dog was eaten.

structures: 因为 + Cause, 所以 + Effect
yinweiSuoyiPattern.description: You will often come across 因为……所以…… (yīnwèi... suǒyǐ...) in both written and spoken Chinese. This pattern will give your Chinese a clear logical structure, and can help make you more persuasive.

examples.zh: 他学得很快，因为他很聪明。
examples.en: He learns fast because he is smart.

examples.zh: 我爱吃四川菜，因为很辣。
examples.en: I love eating Sichuan food because it's very spicy.

examples.zh: 我在学习中文，因为我想去中国。
examples.en: I am studying Chinese because I want to go to China.

examples.zh: 我不喜欢她，因为她不友好。
examples.en: I don't like her because she is very unfriendly.

examples.zh: 今天我们很忙，因为有很多工作。
examples.en: We are very busy today because we have lots of work.

examples.zh: 汉字太难了，所以我不想学。
examples.en: Chinese characters are too hard, so I don't want to study them.

examples.zh: 她很漂亮，所以很多男孩喜欢她。
examples.en: She is beautiful, so a lot of boys like her.

examples.zh: 他找到工作了，所以很高兴。
examples.en: He found a job so he's happy.

examples.zh: 我太忙了，所以没有时间给你打电话。
examples.en: I was too busy, so I didn't have time to give you a call.

examples.zh: 我们公司有很多外国人，所以我们要说英文。
examples.en: There are a lot of foreigners in our company, so we need to speak English.

examples.zh: 因为我有一个中国女朋友，所以我要学中文。
examples.en: Since I have a Chinese girlfriend, I need to study Chinese.

examples.zh: 因为他生病了，所以没去上课。
examples.en: Since he was sick, he didn't go to class.

examples.zh: 因为我很累，所以要休息。
examples.en: I'm very tired, so I want to rest.

examples.zh: 因为太远了，所以我不想去。
examples.en: Since it's too far, I don't want to go.

examples.zh: 因为太忙，所以我们没有时间吃中饭。
examples.en: We were too busy, so none of us had time to eat lunch.

negativeCommandsWithBiePattern.description: Instead of saying "do not" with 不要 (bùyào), we can say "don't" a little more quickly and forcefully by using 别 (bié).

examples.zh: 别走。
examples.en: Don't leave.

examples.zh: 别说话！
examples.en: Don't speak!

examples.zh: 别笑！
examples.en: Don't laugh!

examples.zh: 别动！
examples.en: Don't move!

examples.zh: 别过来！
examples.en: Don't come over here!

examples.zh: 别打孩子！
examples.en: Don't hit the child!

examples.zh: 别喝太多。
examples.en: Don't drink too much.

examples.zh: 喝酒以后别开车。
examples.en: After drinking alcohol, don't drive.

examples.zh: 吃饭的时候别玩手机。
examples.en: When eating, don't play with your cell phone.

examples.zh: 上课的时候别说英文。
examples.en: Don't speak English in class.

yiqiPattern.description: If you want to express that you are doing something together with someone else, 一起 (yīqǐ) is your word!

examples.zh: 我们一起吃晚饭吧。
examples.en: Let's eat dinner together.

examples.zh: 早上我和老公一起去上班。
examples.en: In the morning, I go to work together with my husband.

examples.zh: 周末我们一起去看电影，好吗？
examples.en: Let's go to the movies this weekend, shall we?

examples.zh: 这两个公司一起做这个产品。
examples.en: These two businesses made this product together.

examples.zh: 下班以后，你们一起来我家吧。
examples.en: After work, why don't you all come to my home together?

examples.zh: 下个月我和妈妈一起去旅行。
examples.en: Next month I'll go on a trip together with mom.

examples.zh: 你们有没有一起玩过这个游戏？
examples.en: Have you all ever played this game together?

examples.zh: 他想和他太太一起学中文。
examples.en: He wants to study Chinese together with his wife.

examples.zh: 结婚以后，你和父母会一起住吗？
examples.en: Will you live together with your parents after you get married?

examples.zh: 今天晚上老板要和我们一起加班。
examples.en: Tonight the boss is going to to work overtime together with us.

structures: Subj. + Verb + 几 + Measure Word + Noun？
Subj. + Verb + 多少 + Measure Word + Noun ？
measureWordsInQuantityQuestionsPattern.description: Quantity questions are phrases for asking questions like "how much?" or "how many?"  You'll need to use the question word 几 (jǐ) with measure words for this.

examples.zh: 他有几个孩子？
examples.en: How many kids does he have?

examples.zh: 你家有几个房间？
examples.en: How many rooms are there in your house?

examples.zh: 他们在这里住几个星期？
examples.en: How many weeks are they staying here?

examples.zh: 你带了几件衣服？
examples.en: How many pieces of clothing have you brought?

examples.zh: 老板每天工作几个小时？
examples.en: How many hours does the boss work every day?

examples.zh: 你去过多少个国家？
examples.en: How many countries have you been to?

examples.zh: 你们班有多少个学生？
examples.en: How many students are there in your class?

examples.zh: 你大学的时候看了多少本书？
examples.en: How many books did you read when you were in college?

examples.zh: 他们昨天请了多少个朋友？
examples.en: How many friends did they invite yesterday?

examples.zh: 上海有多少个外国公司？
examples.en: How many foreign companies are there in Shanghai?

zhiyiPattern.description: In order to express "one of the..." in Chinese, "之一" (zhī yī) can be used at the end of the sentence.

examples.zh: 她是我的好朋友之一。
examples.en: She is one of my best friends.

examples.zh: 我觉得百事可乐是最好喝的饮料之一。
examples.en: I think Pepsi is one of the best tasting drinks.

examples.zh: 纽约是世界上最国际化的城市之一。
examples.en: New York is the one of the most international cities in the world.

examples.zh: 他是这个公司的创始人之一。
examples.en: He is one of the founders of this company.

examples.zh: 成龙是最有名的动作明星之一。
examples.en: Jackie Cheng is one of the most famous action movie stars.

examples.zh: 中国的空气污染是的老外经常抱怨的问题之一。
examples.en: in China, air pollution is one of the problems foreigners complain a lot about.

examples.zh: 中秋节是中国最重要的传统节日之一。
examples.en: Mid-autumn Day is one of the most important traditional festivals in China.

examples.zh: 全球化是21世纪最大的特点之一。
examples.en: Globalization is one of the major features of the 21st century.

examples.zh: 个性化是我们服务的主要特点之一。
examples.en: Personalization is one of the major characteristics of our service.

examples.zh: 我选择这家公司的原因之一是我喜欢这里的工作环境。
examples.en: The reason why I choose this company is that I like the working environment here.

structures: x 点 零 y 分
差 + Minutes + 分 + Hour + 点
Hour + 点 + 差 + Minutes + 分
structureOfTimesAdvancedPattern.description: If you already know the basics of how to tell time in Chinese, you may want to get a little more specific or sophisticated, using words like 分 (fēn) and 刻 (kè).

examples.zh: 一点四十分
两点十分
三点二十分
七点十五分
九点五十分
两点零九分
三点零八分
五点零三分
七点零一分
八点零五分
九点一刻
十二点一刻
六点三刻
差五分三点
examples.en: five minutes til 3 o'clock

examples.zh: 十二点差三分
examples.en: three minutes til 12 o'clock

examples.zh: 差五分八点半
examples.en: five minutes til 8:30

examples.zh: 十点差两分
examples.en: two minutes til 10:00

structures: Subj. + 包括 + Obj.1 ( , + Obj.2, Obj.3 ... )
包括 + Obj. (+ 在内)，一共 ⋯⋯
expressingIncludingWithBaokuoPattern.description: "包括" can be used to mean "including" in English. It can be used with "在内一共" or just "一共" to express "all together" or "in total"

examples.zh: 他说“咱们”，当然包括你。
examples.en: He said "us". That certainly includes you.

examples.zh: 我每个月的房租不包括水电费。
examples.en: My monthly rent does not include my water and electric bill.

examples.zh: 公司的福利包括很多方面。
examples.en: The company's welfare benefits includes many aspects.

examples.zh: 他对很多话题都很感兴趣，包括政治。
examples.en: He finds many topics of conversation interesting, including politics.

examples.zh: 简历一般包括个人信息，教育背景，工作经历等。
examples.en: A résumé generally includes a person's information, education background, work experience, etcetera.

examples.zh: 包括税，两张机票一共是五千。
examples.en: Including taxes, two airplane tickets all together are $5,000.

examples.zh: 包括我在内，一共有十五个人参加这个会议。
examples.en: Including myself, 15 people total participated in this meeting.

examples.zh: 包括奖金在内，这个月我拿了一万块钱工资。
examples.en: Including bonuses, this month I received a salary of 1,000 RMB.

examples.zh: 包括母语在内，他一共会说四种语言。
examples.en: Including my native language, I can speak a total of 4 languages.

examples.zh: 包括每个月的物业费，我们办公室的租金是两万。
examples.en: Including monthly property fees, our office's rent is $20,000.

jiashiJiuPattern.description: "假使⋯⋯，就⋯⋯" (jiáshǐ..., jiù...) is another way to phrase "If..., then..." in Chinese, with this pattern being one of the most formal.

examples.zh: 假使明天下雨，我就不去上班了。
examples.en: If it rains tomorrow, then I'm not going to work.

examples.zh: 假使你同意，我们立马签合同。
examples.en: If you agree, then we should sign the contract right away.

examples.zh: 假使我们能找到更多的赞助，我们就可以帮助更多的孩子。
examples.en: If we find even more sponsors, then we can help even more children.

doerOfActionYouPattern.description: 由 (yóu)  is used to emphasize who is the doer or initiator of an action, a bit like in English where we might say: "Andy is the one who...."

examples.zh: 这件事由我负责。
examples.en: I am responsible for this.

examples.zh: 这是由他决定的，你就别干涉了。
examples.en: This is for him to decide, don't meddle.

examples.zh: 太悲剧了，会议由王总主持，肯定会很无聊！
examples.en: Oh no. This meeting is being led by the head manager. It's definitely going to be boring.

structures: Subj. + 终于 + Verb Phrase + 了
zhongyuPattern.description: 终于(zhōngyú) 表示经过很长时间的等待最后实现了愿望，通常都是说话人期待发生的事情，含喜悦、满意的感情色彩。

examples.zh: 你终于到了！
examples.en: You finally arrived!

examples.zh: 我们终于赢了！
examples.en: We finally won!

examples.zh: 终于做完作业了！
examples.en: I finally finished my homework!

examples.zh: 飞机终于起飞了！
examples.en: The plane is finally taking off!

examples.zh: 饭终于做好了！我快饿死了。
examples.en: Dinner is finally ready! I'm starving.

meiBanfaPattern.description: If you are trying to express that something is impossible, you can use the phrase 没办法 (méi bànfǎ). 没办法 (méi bànfǎ) essentially means "there is no way," and whule it works just fine by itself, it can also come before verbs.

examples.zh: 今天太忙了，中午没办法出去吃饭。
examples.en: It's too busy today. There's no way to go out for lunch.

examples.zh: 他没带手机，没办法给我打电话。
examples.en: He didn't bring his phone, so he has no way to give me a call.

examples.zh: 没有水，我们没办法洗衣服。
examples.en: There's no water. There's no way for us to wash clothes.

examples.zh: 这里太吵了，我没办法工作。
examples.en: It‘s too noisy here. I can't work.

examples.zh: 他不开门，所以她没办法进去。
examples.en: He didn't open the door, so she has no way to enter.

examples.zh: 你不会说中文，没办法在我们公司工作。
examples.en: You can't speak Chinese, so there is no way for you to work for our company.

examples.zh: 事情太多了，我今天没办法做完。
examples.en: There's too much to do. I have no way to finish today.

examples.zh: 老板不同意，我没办法帮你。
examples.en: The boss didn't agree, so I have no way to help you.

examples.zh: 这里没有wifi，我没办法上网。
examples.en: There is no wifi here, so I have no way of going online.

examples.zh: 他很笨，我没办法跟他一起工作。
examples.en: He's really dumb. There is no way I can work with him.

askingAboutDegreeWithDuoPattern.description: How big? How busy? How cold? Ask questions like these regarding the degree of an adjective with 多 (duō). This is just one of the many uses of this word.

examples.zh: 她多高？
examples.en: How tall is she?

examples.zh: 你家多大？
examples.en: How large is your house?

examples.zh: 你的孩子多大？
examples.en: How old is your child?

examples.zh: 黄河多长？
examples.en: How long is the Yellow River?

examples.zh: 你家离这儿多远？
examples.en: How far is your house away from here?

examples.zh: 你要在美国待多久？
examples.en: How long are you going to stay in the USA?

examples.zh: 这些东西多重？
examples.en: How heavy are these things?

examples.zh: 你知道我们现在多胖吗？
examples.en: Do you know how fat we are now?

examples.zh: 你知道这里的冬天多冷吗？
examples.en: Do you know how cold it is here in winter?

examples.zh: 你知道上海的房子多贵吗？
examples.en: Do you know how expensive housing is in Shanghai?

dengDengPattern.description: 等等 (děng děng), or simply 等 (děng), is just like saying “and so on” or “etc.” in English, but just a bit more formal.  Both are placed after listing a series of items (generally with a list that exceeds two items).

examples.zh: 西瓜、菠萝、苹果、葡萄等等都是我喜欢的水果。
examples.en: Watermelons, pineapples, apples, grapes and so on are all the fruits that I like.

examples.zh: 我的男朋友会说很多外语，英语、法语、西班牙语等等。
examples.en: My boyfriend can speak many foreign languages: English, French, Spanish, etc.

examples.zh: 我很喜欢运动，比如跑步、游泳、做瑜伽等等。
examples.en: I like exercising very much, for example, running, swimming, doing yoga, etc.

examples.zh: 我们公司有好几个部门，市场部、客户部、技术部等。
examples.en: Our company has several departments: marketing department,  client department, technology department, etc.

examples.zh: JackieChan、JetLi、BruceLi等都是中国有名的功夫明星。
examples.en: Jackie Chan, Jet Li, Bruce Li, etc. are all famous Chinese martial arts stars.

examples.zh: 长城、故宫等地方都是北京有名的景点。
examples.en: The Great Wall, the Forbidden City, etc. are all famous scenic spots in Beijing.

examples.zh: 北京、上海、广州等城市是中国最发达的城市。
examples.en: Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and so on are the most developed cities in China.

examples.zh: 牛津、剑桥等大学都是最有名的英国大学。
examples.en: Oxford, Cambridge and so on are the most famous British Universities.

examples.zh: 中国、印度、巴西等国家都不是发达国家。
examples.en: China, India, Brazil and so on are not developed countries.

examples.zh: WTO,WHO等组织都是国际组织。
examples.en: WTO, WHO and so on are all international organizations.

indicatingANumberInExcessPattern.description: A number in excess of a certain amount is expressed by adding "多" (duō) to the end of a number. This is usually translated as "more than..." in English.

examples.zh: 他的妈妈已经五十多岁了。
examples.en: His mother is already more than fifty years old.

examples.zh: 这个包三千多块钱？
examples.en: This bag is more than three thousand kuai?

examples.zh: 我的毕业论文已经写了两百多页了！
examples.en: My graduate dissertation is already more than two hundred pages!

examples.zh: 中国有五千多年的历史!
examples.en: China has more than five thousand years of history!

ageWithSuiPattern.description: Use 岁 (suì) to give a person's age, similar to how we say "years old" in English. There are a details that work differently from English, however.

examples.zh: 我20岁。
examples.en: I am 20 years old.

examples.zh: 我儿子一岁。
examples.en: My son is one year old.

examples.zh: 我妈妈今年45岁。
examples.en: My mother is 45 years old this year.

examples.zh: 你爷爷今年80岁吗？
examples.en: Is your grandpa eighty years old this year?

examples.zh: 他女朋友也20岁吗？
examples.en: Is his girlfriend also twenty years old?

examples.zh: 我的孩子一岁。
examples.en: My child is one year old.

examples.zh: 她两岁半。
examples.en: She is two and a half years old.

examples.zh: 我儿子一岁半。
examples.en: My son is one and a half years old.

zenmePattern.description: 怎么 (zěnme) means "how" in Chinese, and it's not hard to use at all: just put it before a verb.

examples.zh: 你们怎么学中文？
examples.en: How do you study Chinese?

examples.zh: 你怎么上班？坐地铁吗？
examples.en: How do you get to work? By metro?

examples.zh: 你知道怎么去外滩吗？
examples.en: Do you know how to get to the Bund?

examples.zh: 你怎么知道我喜欢旅行？
examples.en: How did you know I like to travel?

examples.zh: 我不知道怎么跟女孩子说话。
examples.en: I don't know how to talk to girls.

examples.zh: 芒果怎么吃？
examples.en: How do you eat mangos?

examples.zh: iPad怎么用？
examples.en: How do you use an iPad?

examples.zh: 语法怎么学？
examples.en: How do you study grammar?

examples.zh: 中国菜怎么做？
examples.en: How do you cook Chinese food?

examples.zh: "Apple"怎么说？
examples.en: How do you say apple?

yizhiPattern.description: 一直 (yīzhí) literally means "straight."  Used as an adverb, 一直 (yīzhí) can also be used to express that you have been doing something all along, have been continuously doing something since a certain time, or that something will continuously happen in the future.

examples.zh: 我一直在学习中文。
examples.en: I've been studying Chinese all along.

examples.zh: 昨天晚上我一直在做作业。
examples.en: Yesterday evening I was continuously doing homework.

examples.zh: 老板一直很忙。
examples.en: The boss is always very busy.

examples.zh: 我一直很喜欢你。
examples.en: I've always liked you a lot.

examples.zh: 爸爸一直都不抽烟。
examples.en: Dad has never smoked cigarettes.

examples.zh: 我男朋友一直在中国教英文。
examples.en: My boyfriend has always been teaching English in China.

examples.zh: 18岁以后，他一直一个人住。
examples.en: Since he was 18, he has always lived alone.

examples.zh: 你一直在这家公司工作吗？
examples.en: Have you always worked in this company?

examples.zh: 你们一直住在一起吗？
examples.en: Have you always been living together?

examples.zh: 北京的空气一直很不好。
examples.en: The air in Beijing has been bad for a while.

structures: A + 跟 / 和 +  B + 差不多
chabuduoPattern.description: 差不多 (chàbuduō), translated literally, means "the difference is not much." In practice it means something like "more or less," and is useful for expressing rough approximations.

examples.zh: 这几个地方都差不多。
examples.en: These places are all pretty much the same.

examples.zh: 这两个词的意思差不多。
examples.en: The meanings of these two words are pretty much the same.

examples.zh: 我们的想法差不多。
examples.en: Our ways of thinking are pretty much the same.

examples.zh: 那两家餐厅的菜差不多。
examples.en: Those two restaurants' dishes are almost the same.

examples.zh: 你们的中文水平差不多。
examples.en: Your Chinese levels are almost the same.

examples.zh: 上海和纽约差不多。
examples.en: Shanghai and New York are basically the same.

examples.zh: Starbucks和Costa差不多。
examples.en: Starbucks and Costa are almost the same.

examples.zh: 这里的天气跟台湾的天气差不多。
examples.en: The weather here is pretty much like Taiwan's.

examples.zh: 你的工作跟我的工作差不多。
examples.en: Your job and my job are almost the same.

examples.zh: 你的新手机跟我的旧手机差不多。
examples.en: Your new cell phone is pretty much like my old cell phone.

examples.zh: 这两个孩子差不多大。
examples.en: These two children are more or less the same age.

examples.zh: 我跟我哥哥差不多高。
examples.en: My older brother and I are more or less the same height.

examples.zh: 我差不多到公园门口了。
examples.en: I'm almost at the entrance of the park.

examples.zh: 电影差不多要开始了。
examples.en: The movie is almost about to start.

examples.zh: 今天的工作差不多做完了。
examples.en: Today's work is almost done.

examples.zh: 你儿子差不多五岁了吧？
examples.en: Your son should be about 5 years old, right?

examples.zh: 他住在上海差不多三个月了。
examples.en: He has lived in Shanghai for about three months.

examples.zh: 我在这家公司工作了差不多十年了。
examples.en: I've worked for this company for almost ten years.

examples.zh: 我父母结婚差不多二十年了。
examples.en: My parents have been married for about twenty years.

examples.zh: 差不多两个星期以前，我在北京见过他。
examples.en: About two weeks ago I met with him in Beijing.

youyidianPattern.description: At times you may want to politely diss something using the phrase "a little too."  For example, if you are getting lunch with a friend who wants to be seated outside, you might say, "It is a little too hot" to suggest you sit inside. In a case like this, you can use 有一点 (yǒuyīdiǎn) or 有点 (yǒudiǎn). The two are interchangeable.

examples.zh: 我有一点饿。
examples.en: I'm a little hungry.

examples.zh: 这个菜有一点辣。
examples.en: This dish is a little too spicy.

examples.zh: 昨天有一点热。
examples.en: Yesterday it was a little too hot.

examples.zh: 上海的冬天有一点冷。
examples.en: Winter in Shanghai is a bit too cold.

examples.zh: 我弟弟有点胖。
examples.en: My younger brother is a bit fat.

examples.zh: 今天有点累。
examples.en: Today I am a little bit tired.

examples.zh: 这个月公司有点忙。
examples.en: This month the company is a little bit busy.

examples.zh: 这个地方有点吵，我们走吧。
examples.en: This place is a little too noisy. Let's go.

examples.zh: 爸爸回来有点晚，妈妈有点不高兴。
examples.en: Dad came back home a bit too late, so mom was a little unhappy.

examples.zh: 老师今天有点不舒服，所以没来上课。
examples.en: Today, the teacher felt a little unwell, so she didn't come to class.

structures: Subj. + 一边 + Verb（，）+ 一边 + Verb
yibianYibianPattern.description: Multitasking is everywhere in the modern world (what else are you doing while you read this?), but you if can focus for just a minute, you can learn a way to express simultaneous tasks in Chinese! This can be done with 一边 (yībiān).

examples.zh: 不要一边吃东西，一边说话。
examples.en: Don't speak while eating.

examples.zh: 我常常一边洗澡，一边唱歌。
examples.en: I often sing songs while I take a shower.

examples.zh: 孩子喜欢一边吃饭，一边玩。
examples.en: Children like to play while eating.

examples.zh: 你喜欢一边听音乐，一边做作业吗？
examples.en: Do you like to listen to music while doing homework?

examples.zh: 我们一边走一边聊吧。
examples.en: Let's walk while we talk.

examples.zh: 请你一边读一边写。
examples.en: Please write as you read.

examples.zh: 不要一边开车，一边打电话。
examples.en: Don't talk on the phone while you drive.

examples.zh: 老板喜欢一边抽烟，一边工作。
examples.en: The boss likes to smoke while working.

examples.zh: 很多人都一边上班，一边玩手机。
examples.en: Many people play with their cell phones while working.

examples.zh: 她常常一边做饭，一边带孩子。
examples.en: She often looks after the baby while cooking food.

yiqianPattern.description: To talk about things that previously occurred, you can use the word 以前 (yǐqián). You can use this structure to talk about actions that happened at some unspecified time in the past.

examples.zh: 以前我不会说中文。
examples.en: Before, I could not speak Chinese.

examples.zh: 你以前住在哪儿？
examples.en: Before, where did you live?

examples.zh: 以前我不认识他。
examples.en: Before, I didn't know him.

examples.zh: 以前他是我们的客户吗？
examples.en: Was he our client before?

examples.zh: 以前他是一个服务员，现在是老板。
examples.en: Before, he was a waiter. Now, he is a boss.

examples.zh: 我父母以前都是老师。
examples.en: Before, both of my parents were teachers.

examples.zh: 爸爸以前很喜欢抽烟。
examples.en: Before, dad really liked smoking.

examples.zh: 姐姐以前有一个很有钱的男朋友。
examples.en: My older sister had a very rich boyfriend before.

examples.zh: 他们以前没有钱，可是很快乐。
examples.en: They didn't have much money before, but they were happy.

examples.zh: 我男朋友以前在美国工作，现在在中国工作。
examples.en: Before, my boyfriend worked in the USA. Now, he works in China.

gangcaiPattern.description: In order to say that something "just now" occurred, use the time noun 刚才 (gāngcái). It can be placed in front of the verb or the subject of a statement.

examples.zh: 你刚才说什么了？
examples.en: What did you just say?

examples.zh: 刚才谁来了？
examples.en: Who came just now?

examples.zh: 刚才你去哪儿了？
examples.en: Where did you go just now?

examples.zh: 刚才我去洗手间了。
examples.en: I just went to the restroom.

examples.zh: 老板刚才生气了。
examples.en: The boss just got angry.

examples.zh: 你们刚才在看什么？
examples.en: What were you looking at just now?

examples.zh: 不好意思，我刚才出去了。
examples.en: I'm sorry, I just now stepped out.

examples.zh: 宝宝刚才哭了。
examples.en: The baby just cried.

examples.zh: 他们刚才去开会了。
examples.en: They just went to a meeting.

examples.zh: 刚才有人找你。
examples.en: Just now, there was someone looking for you.

deShihouPattern.description: In English, if we are reflecting on a past time, we often say, "when I was a child" or "when I was in school." In Chinese, this can also be expressed by using 的时候 (de shíhou).

examples.zh: 你不在的时候，我会想你。
examples.en: When you are not here, I'll miss you.

examples.zh: 我上大学的时候，有很多朋友。
examples.en: When I was in college, I had a lot of friends.

examples.zh: 上课的时候不要吃东西。
examples.en: Don't eat when you are in class.

examples.zh: 老板工作的时候喜欢喝咖啡。
examples.en: When the boss works, he likes to drink coffee.

examples.zh: 我生气的时候，请你不要笑。
examples.en: Please don't laugh when I'm angry.

examples.zh: 妈妈不在家的时候，我自己做饭。
examples.en: When mom is not home, I cook for myself.

examples.zh: 开会的时候不要聊天。
examples.en: Don't chat when you are in a meeting.

examples.zh: 吃东西的时候不要说话。
examples.en: Don't talk when eating.

examples.zh: 你开车的时候会打电话吗？
examples.en: Do you talk on the phone when you're driving?

examples.zh: 走路的时候不要玩手机。
examples.en: Don't play with your phone while walking.

standardNegationWithBuPattern.description: 不 (bù) is generally used to negate a verb in the present or future, or to talk about what you do not do, as a habit. So expressing things like "I don't want to go" or "I'm not going" or "I don't eat meat" would be typical uses of 不 (bù).

examples.zh: 他们不是坏孩子。
examples.en: They are not bad kids.

examples.zh: 我们不喝酒。
examples.en: We don't drink alcohol.

examples.zh: 我今天不想工作。
examples.en: I don't want to work today.

examples.zh: 你不喜欢我吗？
examples.en: Do you not like me?

examples.zh: 为什么你不喜欢喝咖啡？
examples.en: Why don't you like to drink coffee?

examples.zh: 我不饿。
examples.en: I'm not hungry.

examples.zh: 这个不贵。
examples.en: This is not expensive.

examples.zh: 公司不大。
examples.en: The company is not big.

examples.zh: 老板今天很不高兴。
examples.en: The boss is very unhappy today.

examples.zh: 我哥哥不高，但是很帅。
examples.en: My older brother is not tall, but he is very handsome.

structures: A + 跟 / 和 +  B + 差很多
chahenduoPattern.description: You might be used to thinking of 差不多 (chàbùduō) as a single word, and that's totally OK. But if you want to negate the whole idea of rough equivalency, then you need to think of it as a phrase and use 差很多 (chà hěn duō). Not surprisingly, it's a little less versatile than 差不多 (chàbùduō).

examples.zh: 这两家店的东西价格差很多。
examples.en: There is a big difference in price between these two shops.

examples.zh: 我和我男朋友的年龄差很多。
examples.en: There is a big difference between my age and my boyfriend's age.

examples.zh: 中国文化和西方文化差很多。
examples.en: Chinese culture and western culture are quite different.

examples.zh: 我的收入跟我老板的收入差很多。
examples.en: There is a huge difference between my income and my boss'.

examples.zh: 这两个词的意思差不多，但是用法差很多。
examples.en: The meanings of these two words are basically the same, but their usages are very different.

examples.zh: 是不是？
examples.en: Is it (or not)?

examples.zh: 他们来不来？
examples.en: Are they going to come or not?

examples.zh: 你想不想我？
examples.en: Do you or do you not miss me?

examples.zh: 我们要去酒吧，你去不去？
examples.en: We are going to the bar. Do you want to go?

examples.zh: 我去买咖啡，你要不要？
examples.en: I'm going to buy coffee. Do you want some?

examples.zh: 你回不回家？
examples.en: Are you coming back home or not?

examples.zh: 她吃不吃鱼？
examples.en: Does she eat fish?

examples.zh: 你们要不要米饭？
examples.en: Do you want rice?

examples.zh: 你爸爸喝不喝酒？
examples.en: Does your dad drink alcohol or not?

examples.zh: 今天老板来不来办公室？
examples.en: Is the boss coming to the office today?

examples.zh: 好不好？
examples.en: Is it good?

examples.zh: 热不热？
examples.en: Is it hot?

examples.zh: 他帅不帅？
examples.en: Is he handsome?

examples.zh: 这里的咖啡贵不贵？
examples.en: Is the coffee expensive here?

examples.zh: 中国菜辣不辣？
examples.en: Is Chinese food spicy?

examples.zh: 喜欢不喜欢？
examples.en: Do you like it?

examples.zh: 喜不喜欢？
examples.en: Do you like it?

examples.zh: 高兴不高兴？
examples.en: Are you happy?

examples.zh: 高不高兴？
examples.en: Are you happy?

examples.zh: 他女朋友漂亮不漂亮？
examples.en: Is his girlfriend pretty?

examples.zh: 他女朋友漂不漂亮？
examples.en: Is his girlfriend pretty?

examples.zh: 中国菜好吃不好吃？
examples.en: Is Chinese food good?

examples.zh: 中国菜好不好吃？
examples.en: Is Chinese food good?

examples.zh: 那个地方好玩不好玩？
examples.en: Is that place fun?

examples.zh: 那个地方好不好玩？
examples.en: Is that place fun?

examples.zh: 你哥哥有没有女朋友？
examples.en: Does your older brother have a girlfriend?

examples.zh: 你们有没有孩子？
examples.en: Do you have children?

examples.zh: 奶奶有没有坐过飞机？
examples.en: Has grandma been on a plane?

examples.zh: 他有没有上过大学？
examples.en: Has he been to college?

expressingExcessivelyWithTaiPattern.description: In Chinese, the simplest structure for expressing "too" in the sense of "excessively" is by using the word 太 (tài). Don't forget to also add 了 (le) after the adjective to keep your Chinese sounding natural.

examples.zh: 米饭太多了。
examples.en: There is too much rice.

examples.zh: 现在太晚了。
examples.en: Now it's too late.

examples.zh: 老板太忙了。
examples.en: The boss is too busy.

examples.zh: 老师太累了。
examples.en: The teacher is too tired.

examples.zh: 这个厕所太脏了。
examples.en: This restroom is too dirty.

examples.zh: 你太好了。
examples.en: You are so great.

examples.zh: 他太帅了。
examples.en: He is very handsome.

examples.zh: 这个女孩太漂亮了。
examples.en: This girl is so pretty.

examples.zh: 小猫太可爱了！
examples.en: The kitten is so cute!

examples.zh: 你的孩子太聪明了。
examples.en: Your kids are wicked smart.

buyaoPattern.description: You can use 不要 (bùyào) to command someone: "don't" (do something). This is similar to the other negative command "别 (bié)."

examples.zh: 不要走。
examples.en: Don't leave.

examples.zh: 不要打我！
examples.en: Don't hit me!

examples.zh: 不要生气，好吗？
examples.en: Don't get angry, OK?

examples.zh: 不要哭！
examples.en: Don't cry!

examples.zh: 不要吃很多肉。
examples.en: Don't eat a lot of meat.

examples.zh: 你们不要喝酒。
examples.en: You guys, don't drink alcohol.

examples.zh: 不要说英文。
examples.en: Don't speak English.

examples.zh: 晚上不要喝咖啡。
examples.en: Don't drink coffee at night.

examples.zh: 上课的时候不要玩手机！
examples.en: In class don't play with your phone!

examples.zh: 不要很晚睡觉！
examples.en: Don't go to bed too late.

structures: A 比 B + 更 + Adj.
gengPattern.description: To express "even more," (as in "even more expensive," "even more ridiculous," "even more badass"), you can use 更 (gèng). 更 (gèng) generally comes before adjectives.

examples.zh: 这两个银行哪个更近？
examples.en: Between these two banks, which one is closer?

examples.zh: 我想找一个更帅的男朋友。
examples.en: I want to find a more handsome boyfriend.

examples.zh: 我喜欢在网上买书，因为更便宜。
examples.en: I like buying books online because it's cheaper.

examples.zh: 不要太高兴，我们还有更多的工作要做。
examples.en: Don't get too excited. We still have more work to do.

examples.zh: 结婚以后，她变得更漂亮了。
examples.en: She's become more beautiful after she got married.

examples.zh: 北京的房子比上海更贵。
examples.en: The houses in Beijing are even more expensive than those in Shanghai.

examples.zh: 春节比中秋节更热闹。
examples.en: Spring Festival is even more boisterous than Mid-autumn Festival.

examples.zh: 汉字比声调更难。
examples.en: Chinese characters are even more difficult than tones.

examples.zh: 他现在的女朋友比以前的更漂亮。
examples.en: His current girlfriend is even more beautiful than his previous one.

examples.zh: 中国的高铁比飞机更方便。
examples.en: China's high-speed trains are even more convenient than airplanes.

measureWordGePattern.description: 个 (gè) is the most commonly used measure word. It can be used in a pinch for any noun if you can't think of a more precise measure word. (Although you might not sound quite as smart, you'll still get your point across). Also, for many nouns, 个 (gè) is the only correct measure word.

examples.zh: 一个人
examples.en: one person

examples.zh: 四个朋友
examples.en: four friends

examples.zh: 三个苹果手机
examples.en: three iPhones

examples.zh: 五个星期
examples.en: five weeks

examples.zh: 六个月
examples.en: six months

examples.zh: 两个老婆
examples.en: two wives

examples.zh: 十个男人，七个傻，八个坏。
examples.en: Ten men: seven are fools, and eight are bad.

examples.zh: 他是个老外。
examples.en: He is a foreigner.

examples.zh: 我有个儿子。
examples.en: I have a son.

examples.zh: 她是个好老师。
examples.en: She is a good teacher.

examples.zh: 你想吃个包子吗？
examples.en: Would you like to eat a stuffed steamed bun?

examples.zh: 老师，我有个问题。
examples.en: Teacher, I have a question.

theAllAdverbDouPattern.description: The adverb 都 (dōu) is used to express "all" in Chinese. It's common to use 都 (dōu) in a variety of sentences where it would seem unnecessary in English.

examples.zh: 你们都认识John吗？
examples.en: Do you all know John?

examples.zh: 他们都在上海。
examples.en: They are all in Shanghai.

examples.zh: 明天我们都可以去。
examples.en: Tomorrow we all can go.

examples.zh: 你们都用wiki吗？
examples.en: Do you all use the wiki?

examples.zh: 我们都要冰水。
examples.en: We all want ice water.

examples.zh: 我们两个都爱你。
examples.en: The two of us both love you.

examples.zh: 你爸爸和你妈妈都是美国人吗？
examples.en: Are your father and your mother both Americans?

examples.zh: 我和我太太都不吃肉。
examples.en: Neither my wife nor I eat meat.

examples.zh: 你们两个都喜欢中国菜吗？
examples.en: Do you both like Chinese food?

examples.zh: 她和她老公都没有工作。
examples.en: Neither she nor her husband has a job.

expressingAndWithHePattern.description: When listing out multiple nouns, 和 (hé) is there to help you out. Just remember that 和 (hé) isn't a word you can use to translate just any usage of the English word "and."

examples.zh: 你和我
examples.en: you and I

examples.zh: 老板喜欢咖啡和茶。
examples.en: The boss likes coffee and tea.

examples.zh: 我的爷爷和奶奶都70岁。
examples.en: My grandpa and grandma are both 70 years old.

examples.zh: 他和他女朋友都喜欢中国菜。
examples.en: He and his girlfriend both like Chinese food.

examples.zh: 你爸爸和你妈妈都是美国人吗？
examples.en: Are your father and your mother both Americans?

examples.zh: 手机和电脑都很贵。
examples.en: Cell phones and computers are both expensive.

examples.zh: 德语和法语都很难吗？
examples.en: Are both German and French difficult?

examples.zh: 今天和明天都可以吗？
examples.en: Are today and tomorrow both OK?

suggestionsWithBaPattern.description: The particle 吧 (ba) has a number of different uses. Here we'll talk about the simplest way to use 吧 (ba): making suggestions.

examples.zh: 我们走吧。
examples.en: Let's go.

examples.zh: 你说吧。
examples.en: You say it.

examples.zh: 快点吃吧。
examples.en: Hurry up and eat.

examples.zh: 给我两个吧。
examples.en: Give me two.

examples.zh: 喝水吧。
examples.en: Have some water.

examples.zh: 我们去香港吧。
examples.en: Let's go to Hong Kong.

examples.zh: 我们六点去吧？
examples.en: We're going at 6 o'clock (right)?

examples.zh: 休息一下吧。
examples.en: Take a break.

examples.zh: 我们结婚吧。
examples.en: Let's get married.

examples.zh: 老板，便宜一点吧。
examples.en: Boss, can you make it cheaper?

expressingBeGoingToWithYaoPattern.description: The auxiliary verb 要 (yào) has several different meanings, and here we'll tackle the "be going to" meaning. You'll use this when you are discussing your plans with someone.

examples.zh: 我明天要买一个iPhone。
examples.en: I am going to buy an iPhone tomorrow.

examples.zh: 你们现在要出去吗？
examples.en: Are you all going out now?

examples.zh: 我们今年要去美国。
examples.en: We are planning to go to the U.S. this year.

examples.zh: 他下个月要来中国工作。
examples.en: He is coming to China to work next month.

examples.zh: 你下个星期要去她家吃晚饭吗？
examples.en: Are you going to her place for dinner next week?

examples.zh: 这个星期天你要做什么？
examples.en: What are you doing this Sunday?

examples.zh: 我晚上要给妈妈打电话。
examples.en: I am going to call my mom this evening.

examples.zh: 下午老师要来我家。
examples.en: The teacher is coming to my place this afternoon.

examples.zh: 老板明天要见他们吗？
examples.en: Is the boss going to meet them tomorrow?

examples.zh: 下班以后你要回家吗？
examples.en: Are you planning to go home after getting off work?

tagQuestionsWithBuPattern.description: In the same way you can tag questions with 吗 (ma), tag questions can also be formed using 不 (bù). This is done by putting an affirmative-negative question at the end of a sentence.

examples.zh: 你会说中文，对不对？
examples.en: You speak Chinese, right?

examples.zh: 他是你的老板，对不对？
examples.en: He's your boss, right?

examples.zh: 我们是好朋友，对不对？
examples.en: We are good friends, right?

examples.zh: 你昨天没回家，对不对？
examples.en: You didn't come back home yesterday, right?

examples.zh: 你有新女朋友了，是不是？
examples.en: You have a new girlfriend, right?

examples.zh: 九点开会，是不是？
examples.en: We are going to hold a meeting at 9, right?

examples.zh: 你姓王，是不是？
examples.en: Your last name is Wang, is it not?

examples.zh: 我们回家吧，好不好？
examples.en: Let's go home, OK?

examples.zh: 周末去看电影，好不好？
examples.en: Let's go to a movie this weekend, OK?

examples.zh: 你们明天来，好不好？
examples.en: You come here tomorrow, OK?

wantingToDoSomethingWithYaoPattern.description: The auxiliary verb 要 (yào) has several different meanings, and here we'll tackle the "want to" meaning. To express "wanting to do" something, use 要 (yào) before the verb.

examples.zh: 他要学中文。
examples.en: He wants to study Chinese.

examples.zh: 宝宝要睡觉。
examples.en: The baby wants to sleep.

examples.zh: 早饭我要吃肉。
examples.en: For breakfast I want to eat meat.

examples.zh: 今天很累，我要休息。
examples.en: Today I'm very tired. I want to rest.

examples.zh: 我要喝咖啡。
examples.en: I want to drink coffee.

examples.zh: 你要吃什么？
examples.en: What do you want to eat?

expressingExistenceInAPlaceWithZaiPatter.description: The verb 在 (zài) expresses existence in a location, similar to how we say in English, "to be at" or "to be in."

examples.zh: 我在上海。
examples.en: I'm in Shanghai.

examples.zh: 他们在英国。
examples.en: They're in England.

examples.zh: 老板在外面。
examples.en: The boss  is outside.

examples.zh: 他不在学校。
examples.en: He's not at school.

examples.zh: 她现在在家吗？
examples.en: Is she at home now?

examples.zh: 你在公司吗？
examples.en: Are you at the office?

examples.zh: 老师不在办公室吗？
examples.en: Is the teacher not in the office?

examples.zh: 谁在楼上？
examples.en: Who is upstairs?

examples.zh: 我和朋友在酒吧。
examples.en: I'm with a friend at a bar.

examples.zh: 你们明天在北京吗？
examples.en: Are you in Beijing tomorrow?

expressingNotVeryWithBuTaiPattern.description: You may be familiar with using 太 (tài) to express "too," such as when something is "too expensive" or "too hot." 不太 (bù tài) is a similar pattern for the negative, which just means "not very" or "not so" (literally "not too").  Note that this pattern does not normally use 了 (le).

examples.zh: 我家不太大。
examples.en: My house is not too big.

examples.zh: 那个地方不太远。
examples.en: That place is not very far away.

examples.zh: 老板今天不太高兴。
examples.en: The boss is not very happy today.

examples.zh: 这个店的衣服不太贵。
examples.en: The clothes in this shop are not too expensive.

examples.zh: 我觉得他不太聪明。
examples.en: I think he is not too smart.

examples.zh: 我不太懂。
examples.en: I don't really understand.

examples.zh: 他们不太想去。
examples.en: They don't really want to go.

examples.zh: 我哥哥不太喜欢他的工作。
examples.en: My older brother doesn't really like his job.

examples.zh: 他不太明白老板的意思。
examples.en: He didn't really understand what the boss meant.

siLePattern.description: In English, you might use the expression "you scared me to death!" In Chinese,  死了 (sǐ le) is used similarly to intensify an adjective with an unpleasant connotation.

examples.zh: 我饿死了。
examples.en: I'm starving!

examples.zh: 今天累死了。
examples.en: Today was so exhausting!

examples.zh: 热死了！
examples.en: It's ridiculously hot!

examples.zh: 这几天忙死了。
examples.en: It's been so terribly busy these days!

examples.zh: 这件衣服丑死了。
examples.en: This clothing is totally hideous!

examples.zh: 你的房间脏死了。
examples.en: Your room is absolutely filthy!

examples.zh: 吵死了！
examples.en: It's so terribly noisy!

examples.zh: 这里的东西贵死了。
examples.en: The things here are criminally expensive!

examples.zh: 我们都急死了。
examples.en: We are all so terribly anxious!

examples.zh: 这个孩子烦死了。
examples.en: This kid is so freaking annoying!

examples.zh: 哇，可爱死了！
examples.en: OMG, adorbs!

examples.zh: 漂亮死了！
examples.en: Drop-dead gorgeous!

examples.zh: 这个蛋糕好吃死了。
examples.en: This cake is to die for!

structures: Subj. + Verb + Obj. 1， 还 + Verb + Obj. 2
expressingAndAlsoWithHaiPattern.description: In English we use "and also" when we want to connect separate and different thoughts. We can do the same thing in Chinese by using 还 (hái).

examples.zh: 她有一个弟弟，还有一个妹妹。
examples.en: She has a younger brother and also has a younger sister.

examples.zh: 我老板会说法语，还会说日语。
examples.en: My boss can speak French and can also speak Japanese.

examples.zh: 你要一杯咖啡，还要什么？
examples.en: You want a cup of coffee, and what else do you want?

examples.zh: 我想吃冰淇淋，还想吃汉堡。
examples.en: I want to eat ice cream and I also want to eat a hamburger.

examples.zh: 爸爸有一个小米手机，还有一个iPhone。
examples.en: Dad has a Xiaomi phone and also has an iPhone.

examples.zh: 你晚上在家做了作业，还做了什么？
examples.en: You did your homework at home tonight, and what else did you do?

examples.zh: 他结婚的时候，请了同事，还请了谁？
examples.en: When he got married, he invited his co-workers. Who else did he invite?

examples.zh: 生日的时候，我们会吃蛋糕，还要送礼物。
examples.en: During a birthday, we eat cake and also give presents.

examples.zh: 去美国要带钱、护照，还要带什么？
examples.en: To go to the USA, you need to take money and a passport. What else do you need to take with you?

examples.zh: 他做了饭，还洗了碗。
examples.en: He fixed dinner and also washed the dishes.

examples.zh: 我洗了澡，还洗了衣服。
examples.en: I took a shower and also did my laundry.

examples.zh: 我们今天晚上出去吃饭了，还看了电影。
examples.en: We went out for dinner tonight and also watched a movie.

expressingActionsInProgressWithZaiPatter.description: 在 (zài) and 正在 (zhèngzài) can be used as auxiliary verbs to express that an action is ongoing or in progress. This is often the equivalent of present continuous in English, which is how we express that an activity is happening now.

examples.zh: 她在看书。
examples.en: She is reading.

examples.zh: 妈妈在打电话。
examples.en: Mom is making a phone call.

examples.zh: 阿姨正在打扫我们的房间。
examples.en: The cleaning lady is cleaning our room right now.

examples.zh: 昨天晚上七点，我们在吃饭。
examples.en: Yesterday at 7pm, we were eating dinner.

examples.zh: 我现在在上班，不方便离开。
examples.en: I am working now. It's not convenient for me to leave.

examples.zh: 我们正在上课，请你等一会儿。
examples.en: We are in class right now; please wait a moment.

examples.zh: 你正在开车，不可以玩手机。
examples.en: You're driving right now; you can't play with your cell phone.

examples.zh: 你给我打电话的时候，我正在跟朋友打游戏。
examples.en: When you called me, I was playing video games with friends.

structures: Subj. + 又 + Adj. 1 + 又 + Adj. 2
bothWithYouPattern.description: When you're getting descriptive, you may find yourself wanting to use multiple adjectives at a time. The character 又 (yòu) can be used to give two qualities to something. Using the double 又 (yòu) structure is like saying that something is "both… and…" in English.

examples.zh: 她男朋友又高又帅。
examples.en: Her boyfriend is both tall and handsome.

examples.zh: 这个房子又大又亮。
examples.en: This house is both big and bright.

examples.zh: 妈妈的头发又黑又亮。
examples.en: Mom's hair is both black and shiny.

examples.zh: 我姐姐又聪明又漂亮。
examples.en: My older sister is both smart and beautiful.

examples.zh: 中国菜又便宜又好吃。
examples.en: Chinese food is both cheap and good-tasting.

examples.zh: 你们老板又年轻又有钱。
examples.en: Your boss is both young and rich.

examples.zh: 这里的咖啡又贵又难喝。
examples.en: The coffee here is both expensive and bad-tasting.

examples.zh: 我家小狗又可爱又听话。
examples.en: My family's dog is both cute and obedient.

examples.zh: 上海的冬天又冷又湿。
examples.en: Winter here in Shanghai is both cold and humid.

examples.zh: 她小时候又矮又瘦。
examples.en: She was both short and thin when she was young.

zhenPattern.description: As an adverb, the word 真 (zhēn) means "really" or "truly."

examples.zh: 你女朋友真漂亮！
examples.en: Your girlfriend is really pretty!

examples.zh: 他家真有钱！
examples.en: His family is really rich!

examples.zh: 小狗真可爱！
examples.en: This puppy is really cute!

examples.zh: 今天真热！
examples.en: It's truly hot today!

examples.zh: 我真喜欢住在中国！
examples.en: I really like living in China!

examples.zh: 我真讨厌这种男人！
examples.en: I really hate this kind of guy!

examples.zh: 你真会说话！
examples.en: You are so good with words!

examples.zh: 你真能吃！
examples.en: You ate so much!

intensifyingWithDuoPattern.description: One way to intensify a sentence is to make it an exclamation. To do this, you can use 多 (duō).

examples.zh: 你女儿多聪明啊！
examples.en: Your daughter is so smart!

examples.zh: 今天天气多舒服！
examples.en: Today's weather is so nice!

examples.zh: 学中文多有意思啊！
examples.en: Studying Chinese is so interesting!

examples.zh: 这些菜多好吃啊！
examples.en: These foods are so delicious!

examples.zh: 你男朋友多帅啊！
examples.en: Your boyfriend is so handsome!

zuiPattern.description: The most common way to form a superlative (best, worst, biggest, smallest, etc.) in Chinese is to use 最 (zuì) before an adjective (and a few select verbs).

examples.zh: 哪个老师最好？
examples.en: Which teacher is the best?

examples.zh: 你们家谁最漂亮？
examples.en: In your family who is the most beautiful?

examples.zh: Zuckerberg最有钱。
examples.en: Zuckerberg is the richest.

examples.zh: 汉语最难。
examples.en: The Chinese language is the most difficult.

examples.zh: 这种事最麻烦。
examples.en: These kind of things are the most troublesome.

examples.zh: 小狗最可爱了。
examples.en: The puppy is the cutest.

examples.zh: 四川菜最辣了。
examples.en: Sichuan food is the spiciest.

examples.zh: 我的中国朋友最热情了。
examples.en: My Chinese friend is the most enthusiastic.

examples.zh: 他的学生最认真了。
examples.en: His student is the most serious.

examples.zh: 黄山的风景最美了。
examples.en: Huang Mountain's landscape is the most beautiful.

examples.zh: 老板最喜欢你了！
examples.en: The boss likes you the best!

examples.zh: 你最怕什么？
examples.en: What do you most fear?

examples.zh: 我最爱中国菜。
examples.en: I love Chinese food most.

examples.zh: 谁最了解你？
examples.en: Who knows you best?

examples.zh: 她最讨厌抽烟的男人了。
examples.en: She most hates men that smoke.

examples.zh: 你最喜欢什么颜色？
examples.en: What is your favorite color?

examples.zh: 你最喜欢什么动物？
examples.en: What is your favorite animal?

structures: Subj. + 跟 + Person + 一起 + Verb + Obj.
usingGenToMeanWithPattern.description: Using 跟 (gēn) to express "with" is so simple and helpful, after studying it briefly, it will always be with you! 跟 (gēn) is a very common word that will help complete many other sentence structures.

examples.zh: 我昨天跟朋友去海滩了。
examples.en: I went to the beach with friends yesterday.

examples.zh: 不要跟我说话！
examples.en: Don't talk to me!

examples.zh: 我明天要跟新客户见面。
examples.en: I'm going to meet new clients tomorrow.

examples.zh: 你什么时候跟你女朋友结婚？
examples.en: When are you gonna marry your girlfriend?

examples.zh: 你喜欢跟你父母聊天吗？
examples.en: Do you like to talk with your parents?

examples.zh: 你想跟我一起去吗？
examples.en: Do you want to go with me?

examples.zh: 请你们跟老师一起读。
examples.en: Please read together with the teacher.

examples.zh: 下周谁跟老板一起出差？
examples.en: Who is going on a business trip together with the boss next week?

examples.zh: 结婚以后，你想跟父母一起住吗？
examples.en: Do you want live together with your parents after you get married?

examples.zh: 今年中秋节你会跟家人一起过吗？
examples.en: Are you going to spend this Mid-Autumn Festival with your family?

examples.zh: 我要跟你见面。
examples.en: I want to meet with you.

examples.zh: 我昨天跟他见面了。
examples.en: I met with him yesterday.

examples.zh: 你什么时候跟她见面？
examples.en: When are you going to meet with her?

examples.zh: 明天我要跟我男朋友的家人见面。
examples.en: Tomorrow I am going to meet my boyfriend's family.

examples.zh: 你有没有跟Obama见过面？
examples.en: Have you ever met Obama?

examples.zh: 跟我读。
examples.en: Read after me.

examples.zh: 跟我一起读。
examples.en: Read with me.

structures: Subj. + 没 + Verb + 过 + Obj.
expressingExperiencesWithGuoPattern.description: The aspect particle 过 (guo) is used to indicate that an action has been experienced in the past.

examples.zh: 你学过中文吗？
examples.en: Have you ever studied Chinese?

examples.zh: 你见过那个人吗？
examples.en: Have you seen that person before?

examples.zh: 我们来过这个地方。
examples.en: We've been to this place before.

examples.zh: 我也吃过日本菜。
examples.en: I've also eaten Japanese food before.

examples.zh: 你看过这个电影吗？
examples.en: Have you seen this movie?

examples.zh: 我没想过这个问题。
examples.en: I've never thought about this question before.

examples.zh: 我没学过这个词。
examples.en: I have never studied this word before.

examples.zh: 妈妈没买过很贵的衣服。
examples.en: Mom has never bought any expensive clothes before.

examples.zh: 我们都没坐过飞机。
examples.en: None of us has ever been on a airplane before.

examples.zh: 你们没见过美女吗？
examples.en: Have you never seen beautiful girls before?

congDaoPattern.description: 从⋯⋯ 到⋯⋯(cóng... dào...) is used in the same way as "from... to..." is used in English, and can be used both for times and places.

examples.en: from 2004 to 2008

examples.zh: 从一号到五号都在下雨。
examples.en: From the first to the fifth, it's been raining non-stop.

examples.zh: 老板从周二到周五都要出差。
examples.en: From Tuesday until Friday the boss will go on a business trip.

examples.zh: 她从18岁到现在都一个人住。
examples.en: She's lived alone since she was 18 until now.

examples.zh: 你不能从早到晚不吃东西。
examples.en: You can't eat nothing from morning to night.

examples.zh: 从南京西路到南京东路
examples.en: from West Nanjing Road to East Nanjing Road

examples.zh: 从酒店到机场不太远。
examples.en: From the hotel to the airport is not too far.

examples.zh: 从上海到北京要几个小时。
examples.en: From Shanghai to Beijing it takes a few hours.

examples.zh: 从你家到机场可以坐地铁吗？
examples.en: From your place  to the airport, can I take the subway?

examples.zh: 从这里到我们公司，你会看见很多美女。
examples.en: From here to our company, you'll see many beautiful girls.

directionalVerbsLaiAndQuPattern.description: 来 (lái) and 去 (qù) are both words that help to express direction from the perspective of the speaker. 来 (lái) means "come" (towards the speaker), while 去 (qù) means "go" (away from the speaker). For example, if you are in China, a local person might ask you: "When did you come to China?" using 来 (lái). Another example is if you want to go from China to Japan, your friends might ask you:  “When are you going to Japan?" using 去 (qù).

examples.zh: 妈妈要去超市。
examples.en: Mom will go to the supermarket.

examples.zh: 老板今天来公司吗？
examples.en: Is the boss coming into the office today?

examples.zh: 你现在来南京路吧。
examples.en: Come to Nanjing Road now.

examples.zh: 你不想来我们公司工作吗？
examples.en: Do you not want to come to work for our company?

examples.zh: 去年她去美国工作了几个月。
examples.en: Last year she went to work in the USA for a few months.

examples.zh: 你们想去Starbucks还是Costa？
examples.en: Would you like to go to Starbucks or Costa?

examples.zh: 周末我喜欢去朋友家。
examples.en: I like to go to my friends' places on the weekends.

examples.zh: 爸爸明天去北京出差。
examples.en: Dad will go to Beijing on a business trip tomorrow.

examples.zh: 我今天不上班，你们可以来我家吃饭。
examples.en: I don't have to go to work today. You can come to my home to eat dinner.

structures: Subj. + 不 + 会 + Verb + Obj.
expressingWillWithHuiPattern.description: 会 (huì) has multiple uses, but in this context, it is being used to express the possibility of an action happening in the future.

examples.zh: 明天你会来吗？
examples.en: Will you come tomorrow?

examples.zh: 他会来看你吗？
examples.en: Will he come to see you?

examples.zh: 明天会下雨吗？
examples.en: Will it rain tomorrow?

examples.zh: 我出去一下，很快会回来。
examples.en: I'm going out for a little while. I'll come back very soon.

examples.zh: 老板会同意吗？
examples.en: Will the boss agree?

examples.zh: 你女儿会听你的话。
examples.en: Your daughter will listen to you.

examples.zh: 下班以后，我会给你打电话。
examples.en: After getting off work, I will give you a call.

examples.zh: 我们不会告诉你。
examples.en: We won't tell you.

examples.zh: 他不会跟你结婚。
examples.en: He won't marry you.

examples.zh: 今晚我不会在外面吃饭。
examples.en: Tonight I will not eat out.

structures: Subj. + 不 + 想 + Verb + Obj.
xiangPattern.description: If you want to express something that you "would like to do," 想 (xiǎng) will be a very helpful auxiliary verb to know. Although similar to 要 (yào), 想 (xiǎng) will give you another more tactful option when you want to articulate a desire.

examples.zh: 你想去吗？
examples.en: Would you like to go?

examples.zh: 我想吃面。
examples.en: I would like to eat noodles.

examples.zh: 你想喝水吗？
examples.en: Would you like to drink some water?

examples.zh: 我们想看电视。
examples.en: We would like to watch TV.

examples.zh: 他想买一个大房子。
examples.en: He would like to buy a big apartment.

examples.zh: 他们不想去酒吧。
examples.en: They wouldn't like to go to the bar.

examples.zh: 你不想认识这个美女吗？
examples.en: Would you not like to know this beautiful lady?

examples.zh: 我不想回家。
examples.en: I wouldn't like to return home.

examples.zh: 那个地方很近，我不想开车。
examples.en: That place is so close. I would not like to drive.

examples.zh: 他不想花父母的钱。
examples.en: He would not like to spend his parents' money.

structures: Subj. + 从来 + 没(有) + Verb + 过
expressingNeverWithConglaiPattern.description: Although it can also work in the positive, 从来 (cónglái) is usually used when you want to express that you never do something (as a habit, or as a rule), or that you have never done something (it's not a part of your life experience). In either usage, 从来 (cónglái) may be shortened to just 从 (cóng) in casual speech.

examples.zh: 她从来不喝酒。
examples.en: She never drinks.

examples.zh: 我女朋友从不给我打电话。
examples.en: My girlfriend never calls me.

examples.zh: 这个人很奇怪，他从来不笑。
examples.en: This person is very strange. He never laughs.

examples.zh: 你父母从来不打你吗？
examples.en: Your parents never hit you?

examples.zh: 他从不关心别人。
examples.en: He never cares about other people.

examples.zh: 你从来没有想过这个问题吗？
examples.en: Have you never thought about this question?

examples.zh: 她从来没见过她妈妈。
examples.en: She has never met her mother.

examples.zh: 我从没学过这个词。
examples.en: I have never before studied this word.

examples.zh: 你们从来没有听说过这个地方吗？
examples.en: Have you never heard about this place before?

examples.zh: 很多中国人从来没出过国。
examples.en: A lot of Chinese people have never been abroad.

expressingDifficultWithNanPattern.description: 难 (nán) is an adjective that means "difficult." When something is "hard to do" (as in difficult), the word 难 (nán) can be used before the verb.

examples.zh: 这句话很难懂。
examples.en: This sentence is hard to understand.

examples.zh: 汉语很难学。
examples.en: Mandarin is hard to learn.

examples.zh: 中国菜很难做。
examples.en: Chinese food is hard to make.

examples.zh: 这个东西现在很难买。
examples.en: This thing is really difficult to purchase now.

examples.zh: 这个汉字很难写。
examples.en: This character is very difficult to write.

examples.zh: 你做的菜很难吃。
examples.en: The dishes you cook taste bad.

examples.zh: 这里的咖啡很难喝。
examples.en: The coffee here tastes bad.

examples.zh: 这首歌很难听。
examples.en: This song is terrible (hard to listen to).

examples.zh: 这种花很难闻。
examples.en: This kind of flower smells bad.

examples.zh: 这件衣服很难看吗？
examples.en: Is this article of clothing ugly?

structures: Subj. + Verb + 了 + Duration + 了
Subj. + Verb + Obj. + Verb + 了 + Duration + 了
expressingOngoingDurationWithDoubleLePat.description: The 了 (le) particle is used in many different ways. In this article, we will explore how to use the double 了 (le) to express the duration of an activity that is ongoing.

examples.zh: 你睡了一天了。
examples.en: You have been sleeping for the whole day.

examples.zh: 他在北京住了两年了。
examples.en: He has been living in Beijing for two years.

examples.zh: 这个会，他们开了两个小时了。
examples.en: They've been holding this meeting for the past two hours.

examples.zh: 我在这儿等了半个小时了。
examples.en: I have been waiting here for half an hour.

examples.zh: 他们在酒吧待了一个晚上了。
examples.en: They have been staying at the bar for the whole evening.

examples.zh: 我学中文学了一年了。
examples.en: I have been learning Chinese for a year.

examples.zh: 他打电话打了一个多小时了。
examples.en: He has been on the phone for more than an hour.

examples.zh: 老板打游戏打了一个上午了。
examples.en: The boss has been playing video games all morning.

examples.zh: 你洗澡洗了差不多一个小时了。
examples.en: You have been showering for almost an hour.

examples.zh: 妈妈看电视看了一晚上了。
examples.en: Mom has been watching TV all evening.

usingHaoToMeanEasyPattern.description: Of course 好 (hǎo) means "good." But it can also be used to express that something is "easy to do" or "good to do." And it is quite... easy to do! All you need to do is place a 好 (hǎo) before a verb.

examples.zh: 这个词的意思很好懂。
examples.en: The meaning of this word is easy to understand.

examples.zh: 这个汉字很好写。
examples.en: This Chinese character is easy to write.

examples.zh: 三明治很好做。
examples.en: Sandwiches are easy to make.

examples.zh: 苹果手机现在很好买。
examples.en: iPhones are easy to buy now.

examples.zh: 这个笔很好用。
examples.en: This pen is easy to use.

examples.zh: 好吃
examples.en: good to taste, good to eat, delicious

examples.zh: 好喝
examples.en: good to taste, good to drink

examples.zh: 好看
examples.en: good to look at, good-looking, attractive

examples.zh: 好听
examples.en: good to listen to, pleasant to listen to, good-sounding

examples.zh: 好玩
examples.en: fun

examples.zh: 这首歌很好听。
examples.en: This song is great.

examples.zh: 这种茶很好闻。
examples.en: This kind of tea smells good.

examples.zh: 你的新包很好看。
examples.en: Your new bag looks good.

examples.zh: 妈妈做的菜很好吃。
examples.en: The food mom makes is delicious.

examples.zh: 我觉得上海很好玩。
examples.en: I think Shanghai is a lot of fun.

yixiaPattern.description: After briefly reading this article, you will know how to use 一下 (yīxià) to express a brief action!

examples.zh: 请你等一下。
examples.en: Please wait a little bit.

examples.zh: 你看一下。
examples.en: Take a look.

examples.zh: 试一下吧。
examples.en: Try it.

examples.zh: 我要想一下。
examples.en: I want to think a little.

examples.zh: 开一下门吧。
examples.en: Please open the door.

examples.zh: 请你说一下为什么。
examples.en: Please say why.

examples.zh: 不要生气了，笑一下！
examples.en: Don't be mad, laugh!

examples.zh: 宝宝，亲一下爸爸。
examples.en: Baby, give your dad a kiss.

examples.zh: 你可以来一下我的办公室吗？
examples.en: Could you please come to my office?

examples.zh: 你能介绍一下自己吗？
examples.en: Could you introduce yourself briefly?

buDongPattern.description: Chinese learners often have to express that they don't understand something, especially in the beginning when they start learning. One of the ways to express that is to use the 不懂 (bù dǒng) verb complement.

examples.zh: 我看不懂这本书。
examples.en: I don't understand the book.

examples.zh: 孩子们看不懂你写的汉字。
examples.en: Kids don't understand the characters that you wrote.

examples.zh: 你看不懂我的邮件吗？
examples.en: Do you not understand my emails?

examples.zh: 老板的中文说得很好，可是他看不懂中文报纸。
examples.en: The boss speaks very good Chinese, but he doesn't understand Chinese newspapers.

examples.zh: 我听不懂上海话。
examples.en: I don't understand Shanghai dialect.

examples.zh: 你们听不懂我的话吗？
examples.en: Do you not understand what I say?

examples.zh: 我听不懂你说的英语。
examples.en: I don't understand your English.

examples.zh: 我们都听不懂你的意思。
examples.en: None of us understand what you mean.

examples.zh: 很多人读不懂这本书。
examples.en: Many people don't understand this book.

examples.zh: 这个句子很难，学生们都读不懂。
examples.en: This sentence is very difficult. None of the students understand.

structures: Subj. + Verb + 完 (+ 了) + Obj.
resultComplementWanForFinishingPattern.description: On its own, 完 (wán) means "to finish" or "to complete." Using it in this grammar structure, it expresses the idea of doing some action to completion.

examples.zh: 我说完了。
examples.en: I am finished talking.

examples.zh: 你吃完了吗？
examples.en: Are you done eating?

examples.zh: 我想看完这个电影。
examples.en: I want to finish watching the movie.

examples.zh: 你做完以后，就可以下班了。
examples.en: After you finish doing it, you can get off work.

examples.zh: 你今天可以做完作业吗？
examples.en: Can you finish doing your homework today?

examples.zh: 你什么时候可以看完这本书？
examples.en: When can you finish reading this book?

examples.zh: 妈妈洗完衣服以后，就去做晚饭了。
examples.en: After mom finished washing clothes, she went to cook dinner.

examples.zh: 做完这些作业需要两个小时。
examples.en: To finish your homework you will need two hours.

examples.zh: 看完以后告诉我。
examples.en: Tell me when you have finished watching.

examples.zh: 我们学完了一百个词。
examples.en: We have finished learning 100 words.

examples.zh: 我看完了电影。
examples.en: I finished watching the movie.

structures: Subj. + 没 + Verb + 到 / 见 + Obj.
resultComplementsDaoAndJianPattern.description: Two of the most common result complements in Chinese are 到 (dào) and 见 (jiàn). On this page we're only going to be talking about verbs related to the senses ("see," "hear," etc.), and for this usage, the two are interchangeable.

examples.zh: 你看到那个帅哥了吗？
examples.en: Did you see that handsome guy?

examples.zh: 我看到了。
examples.en: I saw it.

examples.zh: 你听到了吗？
examples.en: Did you hear it?

examples.zh: 你没看见那个帅哥吗？
examples.en: You didn't see that handsome guy?

examples.zh: 我没有看见。
examples.en: I didn't see it.

examples.zh: 你没听见吗？
examples.en: You didn't hear it?

yixiePattern.description: In order to express "some" or "a few," you can use 一些 (yīxiē). To use it in this way, 一些 (yīxiē) is placed before the noun it modifies. 一些 (yīxiē) can modify the subject or the object.

examples.zh: 妈妈去超市买了一些水果。
examples.en: Mom went to the supermarket and bought some fruit.

examples.zh: 上个周末他买了一些衣服。
examples.en: He bought some clothes last weekend.

examples.zh: 我们很快会见到一些新同事。
examples.en: We're going to meet some new co-workers very soon.

examples.zh: 你饿不饿？这里有一些吃的。
examples.en: Are you hungry or not? There is some food here.

examples.zh: 下课以后，学生们问了一些问题。
examples.en: After class, the students asked some questions.

examples.zh: 给我一些时间，好吗？
examples.en: Give me some time, OK?

examples.zh: 他给我带了一些书。
examples.en: He brought me some books.

examples.zh: 你可以借我一些钱吗？
examples.en: Can you lend me some money?

examples.zh: 你想在咖啡里放一些糖吗？
examples.en: Do you want to put some sugar in your coffee?

examples.zh: 我在中国的时候，去过一些很漂亮的地方。
examples.en: When I was in China, I went to some beautiful places.

expressingHalfWithBanPattern.description: The Chinese word 半 (bàn) means "half." That's simple enough, but what can get slightly tricky is the rules for how it combines with measure words.

examples.zh: 半个小时
examples.en: half an hour

examples.zh: 半个月
examples.en: half a month

examples.zh: 半碗米饭
examples.en: half a bowl of rice

examples.zh: 半瓶酒
examples.en: half a bottle of liquor

examples.zh: 半份炒面
examples.en: half a serving of chow mein

examples.zh: 半个小时
examples.en: half an hour

examples.zh: 一个半小时
examples.en: an hour and a half

examples.zh: 三个半小时
examples.en: three and a half hours

examples.zh: 两个半月
examples.en: two and a half months

examples.zh: 一斤半水果
examples.en: one and a half jin of fruit

examples.zh: 一瓶半白酒
examples.en: one and a half bottles of wine

examples.zh: 四块半巧克力
examples.en: four and a half pieces of chocolate

examples.zh: 半天
examples.en: half a day

examples.zh: 半年
examples.en: half a year

examples.zh: 两天半
examples.en: two and a half days

examples.zh: 一年半
examples.en: a year and a half

examples.zh: 三天半
examples.en: three and a half days

examples.zh: 四年半
examples.en: four and a half years

duoshaoqianPattern.description: Cash is king, even though China is now crazy for mobile payments. Either way, though, mastering how to say quantities of money is vital!

examples.zh: 多少钱？
examples.en: How much?

examples.zh: 你的手机多少钱？
examples.en: How much was your cell phone?

examples.zh: 我们的午饭多少钱？
examples.en: How much is our lunch?

examples.zh: 这杯咖啡多少钱？
examples.en: How much for this cup of coffee?

examples.zh: 这件衣服多少钱？
examples.en: How much is this clothing?

examples.zh: 两块五毛
examples.en: two kuai five mao (2.5)

examples.zh: 三块八毛
examples.en: three kuai eight mao (3.8)

examples.zh: 十块两毛
examples.en: ten kuai two mao (10.2)

examples.zh: 二十三块八毛
examples.en: Twenty-three kuai eight mao (23.8)

examples.zh: 五十块五毛
examples.en: fifty kuai five mao (50.5)

examples.zh: 两块五
examples.en: two kuai five mao (2.5)

examples.zh: 两块二
examples.en: two kuai two mao (2.2)

examples.zh: 五块二
examples.en: five kuai two mao (5.2)

examples.zh: 三块八毛六
examples.en: three kuai eight mao six fen (3.86)

examples.zh: 三块
examples.en: Three kuai

structures: 这 / 那 + Measure Word + Noun
measureWordsWithThisAndThatPattern.description: In English, when you refer to "this table" or "that girl" you only need two words: "this" or "that" plus the noun you're referring to.  In Chinese, though, you also need a measure word in the middle between the two.
