In the very beginning you can get away with using 个 (gè) for everything, but pretty soon you're going to have to start using other measure words in these simple phrases.

examples.zh: 那个人
examples.en: that person

examples.zh: 这本书
examples.en: this book

examples.zh: 那件事
examples.en: that matter (in the sense of business, affair, or thing)

examples.zh: 这瓶啤酒
examples.en: this bottle of beer

examples.zh: 那个房间
examples.en: that room

examples.zh: 那台电脑
examples.en: that new computer

examples.zh: 这只猫
examples.en: that cat

examples.zh: 那条河
examples.en: that river

examples.zh: 这件衣服
examples.en: this piece of clothing

ordinalNumbersWithDiPattern.description: We use ordinal numbers to express things like "number one" or "second," so mastering them in Chinese is important. Fortunately, they are also very easy to learn by just adding the prefix 第 (dì).

examples.zh: 我是第一个到公司的人。
examples.en: I'm the first person that came to the office.

examples.zh: 他要坐早上第一班地铁去上班。
examples.en: He needs to take the first train in the morning to go to work.

examples.zh: 小李是她的第三个男朋友。
examples.en: Little Li is her third boyfriend.

examples.zh: 我的第一个中文老师是美国人。
examples.en: My first Chinese teacher was American.

examples.zh: 爸爸的第一个手机是NOKIA。
examples.en: Dad‘s first cell phone was a  Nokia.

examples.zh: 你的第一个工作是什么？
examples.en: What was your first job?

examples.zh: 到美国的第二个月，我找到了工作。
examples.en: I found a job the second month I was in the USA.

examples.zh: 第二行第五个汉字怎么读？
examples.en: How do you read the fifth character from the second line?

examples.zh: 这次考试，我是我们班第一。
examples.en: On this test, I was first in our class.

examples.zh: 这次比赛，我们班第一，他们班第二。
examples.en: In this contest, our class is the first, their class is the second.

examples.zh: 第一天，我们在宾馆里。
examples.en: On the first day, we will be in the hotel.

examples.zh: 来上海以后的第二年，他开了这家公司。
examples.en: He started this company his second year after coming to Shanghai.

examples.zh: 下个月的第一周老板要出差。
examples.en: The boss needs to go on a business trip the first week of next month.

examples.zh: 这是我第一次去北京。
examples.en: This is my first time going to Beijing.

structures: 快+ Verb / Verb Phrase + 了
快要 + Verb / Verb Phrase + 了
Subj. + 要 + Verb / Verb Phrase / Adj. + 了
expressingAboutToHappenWithLePattern.description: Remember that 了 (le) is not only for the past! When something is about to happen, you can also indicate this using 了 (le).  Normally it is paired with a 快 (kuài), 快要(kuàiyào) or a 要 (yào). This is a special form of using 了 to indicate a change of situation.

examples.zh: 我们快到了。
examples.en: We're almost there.

examples.zh: 快下雨了，我们走吧。
examples.en: It's going to rain soon. Let's go.

examples.zh: 快要过年了，你什么时候回家？
examples.en: It's almost Chinese New Year. When are you going back to your hometown?

examples.zh: 我女朋友快要过生日了。
examples.en: My girlfriend is about to have her birthday.

examples.zh: 快下车了，你再等一会儿。
examples.en: We're about to get off. Just wait a little while.

examples.zh: 天快黑了。
examples.en: It’s almost getting dark.

examples.zh: 我快好了。
examples.en: I'm almost ready.

examples.zh: 饭快凉了。
examples.en: The food is about to be cold.

examples.zh: 这些脏衣服快臭了。
examples.en: These dirty clothes are about to smell bad.

examples.zh: 不能再喝了，我快醉了。
examples.en: I can't drink another, I am almost drunk.

examples.zh: 我要生气了！
examples.en: I'm going to get angry!

examples.zh: 他们的孩子要出生了。
examples.en: Their child is about to be born.

examples.zh: 9点了，超市要关门了。
examples.en: It's 9 o'clock. The supermarket is about to close.

examples.zh: 我最好的朋友要结婚了！
examples.en: My best friend is about to get married!

examples.zh: 圣诞节要到了，你有什么打算？
examples.en: It's almost Christmas. What plans do you have?

structures: Topic (+ Subj.) + 什么 + 都 / 也 + Verb / Adj.
什么 + Noun + 都 / 也 + 不 + Verb
什么 + Noun + 都 / 也 + 没 (有) + Verb
shenmeDouPattern.description: 什么……都 (shénme... dōu) is a pattern often used to express "all" or "everything." Because it's not just one word, though, it can be a little tricky to get the hang of at first.

examples.zh: 我觉得这里的菜什么都好吃。
examples.en: I think everything is delicious here.

examples.zh: 中国的历史爸爸什么都知道。
examples.en: My dad knows everything about Chinese history.

examples.zh: 工作的事情老公什么都跟我说。
examples.en: My husband tells me everything about work stuff.

examples.zh: 妈妈做的菜我什么都喜欢。
examples.en: I like everything that mom cooks.

examples.zh: 我女朋友觉得外国的东西什么都好。
examples.en: My  girlfriend thinks that all foreign things are good.

examples.zh: 我们什么果汁都喝。
examples.en: We drink any kind of fruit juice.

examples.zh: 她什么衣服都是黑色的。
examples.en: All of her clothes are black.

examples.zh: 妈妈做的什么菜都好吃。
examples.en: All of the dishes mom makes are tasty.

examples.zh: 我男朋友什么运动都喜欢。
examples.en: My boyfriend likes all kinds of sports.

examples.zh: 你不应该什么话都跟他说。
examples.en: You shouldn't tell him everything.

examples.zh: 生病以后，爸爸什么酒都不能喝了。
examples.en: After dad got sick, he can't drink any kind of alcohol.

examples.zh: 老板现在很生气，什么人也不见。
examples.en: The boss is very angry. He's doesn't want to see anybody.

examples.zh: 今天我不舒服，什么东西都没吃。
examples.en: Today I don't feel well, so I didn't eat anything.

examples.zh: 昨天开会的时候，她什么话也没说。
examples.en: She didn't say anything at yesterday's meeting.

examples.zh: 你在家里怎么什么事都不做？
examples.en: How  come you haven't done anything at home?

structures: 别 + Verb / Verb Phrase + 了
bieLePattern.description: You may know how to make negative commands with "bie," but what if someone is already doing it? The pattern 别⋯⋯了 (bié... le) is all you need to tell someone to STOP DOING THAT (which they're already doing).

examples.zh: 别说了，我不想听。
examples.en: Stop talking. I don't want to listen.

examples.zh: 别问了，我不想说。
examples.en: Stop asking. I don't want to say.

examples.zh: 别做了，明天再做吧。
examples.en: Stop doing it. Do it tomorrow.

examples.zh: 别看了，睡觉！
examples.en: Stop watching. Go to sleep!

examples.zh: 别哭了，烦死了。
examples.en: Stop crying, it's so annoying.

examples.zh: 别笑了，别人都在看你。
examples.en: Stop laughing. Other people are looking at you.

examples.zh: 别吃了，我们要迟到了。
examples.en: Stop eating. We're going to be late.

examples.zh: 别玩了，去写作业。
examples.en: Stop playing. Do your homework.

examples.zh: 别买了，太贵了！
examples.en: Don't buy it. It's too expensive!

examples.zh: 别喝了，你已经喝了五杯了。
examples.en: Stop drinking. You've already drunk five glasses.

reduplicationOfVerbsPattern.description: One of the fun things about Chinese is that when speaking, you can repeat a verb to express "a little bit" or "briefly." This is called reduplication. It creates a casual tone, and a sense that whatever the action is, it's not going to take long.

examples.zh: 你看看。
examples.en: Take a little look.

examples.zh: 我试试。
examples.en: I'll give it a try.

examples.zh: 说说你的想法。
examples.en: Talk a little bit about your ideas.

examples.zh: 出去玩玩吧！
examples.en: Go out and have fun!

examples.zh: 我想出去走走。
examples.en: I want to go out and walk for a bit.

examples.zh: 别生气了，笑一笑！
examples.en: Don't be mad, gimme a smile!

examples.zh: 你去问一问他们厕所在哪里。
examples.en: Go and ask them where the bathroom is.

examples.zh: 我可以用一用你的电脑吗？
examples.en: Can I use your computer for a little bit?

examples.zh: 你现在有时间吗？我们聊一聊吧。
examples.en: Do you have a second? Let's chat for a bit.

examples.zh: 你想尝一尝我做的菜吗？
examples.en: Do you want to taste the food that I cooked?

examples.zh: 考虑考虑
examples.en: think it over

examples.zh: 讨论讨论
examples.en: discuss it

examples.zh: 商量商量
examples.en: talk it over

examples.zh: 打听打听
examples.en: inquire about it

structures: Subj. + 全 + 都 + Verb  / Adj.
Subj. + 全都 + 不 / 没 + Verb / Adj.
indicatingTheWholeWithQuanPattern.description: One of the uses of 全 (quán) is to indicate the entirety of something. It could be used for something like a whole household, an entire country, the whole world, etc.

examples.zh: 我们全家都去旅游了。
examples.en: The entire family went traveling.

examples.zh: 明天我全天都呆在家里。
examples.en: I am going to stay home all day tomorrow.

examples.zh: 全公司的人都知道这件事了。
examples.en: The whole company knew about this thing.

examples.zh: 打完球以后我全身都是汗。
examples.en: My whole body sweat after playing the ball.

examples.zh: 全世界的人都知道Obama是谁，你不知道？
examples.en: The whole world knows who Obama is. Don't you know?

examples.zh: 大家全都到了。
examples.en: Everybody has come.

examples.zh: 作业全都做完了吗？
examples.en: You've finished all your homework?

examples.zh: 我全都听懂了。
examples.en: I heard and understood all.

examples.zh: 你全都拿走吧。
examples.en: Take them all.

examples.zh: 他把咖啡全都喝了。
examples.en: He drank up all the coffee.

examples.zh: 他们全都没去。
examples.en: None of them went.

examples.zh: 这个周末我们全都不在家。
examples.en: None of us will be home this weekend.

examples.zh: 他说的话全都不要相信。
examples.en: Don't believe anything he says.

examples.zh: 你们的员工全都不会说英语吗？
examples.en: None of your employees can speak English?

examples.zh: 他们全都没学过汉语。
examples.en: None of them have studied Chinese.

examples.zh: 我们的朋友没全都来。
examples.en: Not all of our friends came.

examples.zh: 他的话你不能全都相信。
examples.en: You can't believe everything he says.

examples.zh: 中国菜我不全都喜欢。
examples.en: I don't like all Chinese food.

examples.zh: 这些菜我没全都吃完。
examples.en: I didn't eat all of the food.

examples.zh: 问题太多了，我没全都问他。
examples.en: I had too many questions for him. I didn't ask all of them.

positiveAdjectivesWithJilePattern.description: Just as 死了 (sǐle) can be used to intensify negative adjectives, 极了 (jíle) can be used to intensify positive adjectives. This is used in spoken, colloquial Chinese. 极 means "extreme" or "utmost," so using this grammar pattern takes your positive adjectives to the extreme!

examples.zh: 她好看极了。
examples.en: She is very pretty.

examples.zh: 这个啤酒好喝极了。
examples.en: This beer is very tasty.

examples.zh: 你的中文好极了。
examples.en: Your Chinese is very good!

structures: 就是 + Hypothetical Statement + 也 + Action
jiushiYePattern.description: 就是 (jiùshì) is one of the many "even ifs." Like 即使 , 就算 and 哪怕 it is used to introduce a hypothetical statement, which can then disregarded with 也.

examples.zh: 就是这台电脑价格上万，我也会买。
examples.en: Even if this computer's price is over 10,000 yuan, I'm still going to buy it.

examples.zh: 就是降温了，我也要穿热裤，时尚嘛!
examples.en: Even if it's starting to get cooler, I'm still going to wear short shorts. It's the fad!

examples.zh: 就是他变成一个穷光蛋，我也愿意跟他在一起。
examples.en: Even if he were penniless, I would still be willing to be with him.

yuanlaiPattern.description: 原来 (yuánlái) means "originally" (similar to 本来) or "former." It can also mean "all along," and can be used to indicate a sudden realization of something previously unknown, a bit like "so it's been like that all along, how could I not have realized?"

examples.zh: 你原来的发型很可爱。
examples.en: Your original hairstyle was very cute.

examples.zh: 这件衣服原来的价格是999块。
examples.en: The original price is 999 RMB.

examples.zh: 他原来不知道这件事，是我刚刚跟他说的。
examples.en: Originally he didn't know about this. I just told him.

examples.zh: 我们原来住在浦东，几个月以前搬到了这边。
examples.en: Originally we lived in Pudong. We moved here a few months ago.

examples.zh: 她原来是他的中文老师，现在是他老婆。
examples.en: She was originally his Chinese teacher. She is now his wife.

examples.zh: 原来是你！
examples.en: So it was you all along!

examples.zh: 原来你们认识！
examples.en: So you've known each other this whole time!

examples.zh: 原来他是你前男友！
examples.en: It turns out he was you ex-boyfriend!

examples.zh: 原来你这么有钱！
examples.en: It turns out you are so rich!

examples.zh: 原来你在骗我！我怎么那么傻？
examples.en: You have been tricking me, how could I be so stupid?

structures: 又 + 要 / 可以 / 能 + Verb Phrase ( + 了)
expressingAgainInThePastWithYouPattern.description: Whenever you want to express something like "you did it again!" in Chinese, you generally want to use 又 (yòu).

examples.zh: 又下雨了！
examples.en: It rains again!

examples.zh: 你又迟到了。
examples.en: You came late again.

examples.zh: 我又写错了。
examples.en: I wrote it wrong again.

examples.zh: 宝宝又哭了。
examples.en: The baby is crying again.

examples.zh: 他又喝醉了？
examples.en: He got drunk again?

examples.zh: 明天又是星期一！
examples.en: Tomorrow will be Monday AGAIN!

examples.zh: 我又要迟到了。
examples.en: I'm going to be late again.

examples.zh: 今晚又要加班！
examples.en: Tonight we're going to work late again!

examples.zh: 老板请客，又可以吃大餐了！
examples.en: The boss is going to treat us. We can have a big meal again!

examples.zh: 快过年了，我们又能拿压岁钱了！
examples.en: CNY is coming soon. We can get our new year money again!

structures: 又 + 不 / 没 + Verb / Adj.
emphasizingNegationWithYouPattern.description: One of the many versatile uses of 又 is to emphasize negation, giving your negative sentence a little kick!

examples.zh: 我又不知道，问我干吗？
examples.en: I definitely don't know. Why ask me?

examples.zh: 你又不忙，为什么不来？
examples.en: You're not busy. Why not come?

examples.zh: 我又没做错，你为什么生我的气？
examples.en: I didn't do anything wrong! Why are you mad at me?

examples.zh: 又不是我做的，看我干吗？
examples.en: I definitely didn't do that. Why are you looking at me?

examples.zh: 今天又不下雨，为什么要带伞？
examples.en: It's not going to rain today. Why are you bringing the umbrella?

examples.zh: 又不是你的事，你管那么多干吗？
examples.en: It's not any of your business. Why do you care so much?

examples.zh: 我又不是故意的，你不要这么生气。
examples.en: It really wasn't on purpose. Don't be so mad.

structures: Subj. + 最好 + 别 / 不要 + [Verb Phrase]
zuihaoPattern.description: 最好 can be used to express "had better"

examples.zh: 你最好先休息一下。
examples.en: You'd better take some rest first.

examples.zh: 你们最好给他打个电话问一下。
examples.en: You'd better call to ask him.

examples.zh: 那个地方不好找，我们最好查一下百度地图。
examples.en: It's not easy to find that place. We'd better search it on Baidu Map.

examples.zh: 外面挺冷的，最好多穿点。
examples.en: It's pretty cold outside. You'd better wear a little bit more.

examples.zh: 这个活动很重要，我们最好穿得正式一点。
examples.en: This is an important event. We'd better wear something more formal.

examples.zh: 最好别去。
examples.en: You'd better not go.

examples.zh: 最好不要这样说。
examples.en: You'd better not to say it like that.

examples.zh: 晚饭最好不要吃那么多。
examples.en: You'd better not so much for dinner.

examples.zh: 雨这么大，最好别出门。
examples.en: The rain is so heavy. You'd better not leave the house.

examples.zh: 这个问题是隐私，最好不要问。
examples.en: This question is privacy. We'd better not ask.

expressingQuiteWithTingPattern.description: 挺 can be used before an adjective to mean "quite," or "rather," or "pretty," as in "pretty good."

examples.zh: 这件衣服大小挺合适的。
examples.en: The size of this piece of clothes is quite suitable.

examples.zh: 我觉得你妈妈挺年轻的。
examples.en: I think your mom is quite young.

examples.zh: 你不觉得他挺帅的吗？
examples.en: You don't think he's quite handsome?

examples.zh: 他们家挺有钱的，但是他不像有钱人。
examples.en: Their family is quite rich, but he doesn't like like a rich person.

examples.zh: 大学生毕业找工作的压力挺大的。
examples.en: College graduates who are looking for jobs are under quite a lot of pressure.

examples.zh: 这份工作压力不大，挺适合女孩子的。
examples.en: This job doesn't give you much stress.It quite suits girls.

examples.zh: 我们一直都挺想你的。
examples.en: We always miss you.

examples.zh: 我真的挺讨厌你老板的。
examples.en: I really hate your boss.

examples.zh: 你不是挺喜欢他的吗？为什么要跟他分手？
examples.en: Don't you really like him? Why do you want to break up with him?

examples.zh: 他不是挺爱运动的吗？怎么不跟我们一起去爬山？
examples.en: Doesn't he love to do sports? Why didn't he climb the mountain with us?

expressingAlwaysWithConglaiPattern.description: Although perhaps more often used in the negative to mean "never," 从来 (cónglái) can be used with 都 (dōu) to mean "always" or "have always (done)."

examples.zh: 我从来都一个人住，已经习惯了。
examples.en: I have always lived alone; I'm used to it already.

examples.zh: 她从来都这么自私。
examples.en: She's always been this selfish.

examples.zh: 我们下棋，他从来都是赢的。
examples.en: He always wins when we play chess.

examples.zh: 他说话从来都很大声。
examples.en: He always speaks very loudly.

examples.zh: 她找男朋友从来都是要长得帅的。
examples.en: She always wants those good-looking guys when she looks for boyfriend.

examples.zh: 他工作从来都很努力。
examples.en: He always works very hard.

examples.zh: 我的学生从来都这么有自信。
examples.en: My students are always so confident.

examples.zh: 他的电影从来都是最受欢迎的。
examples.en: His movies are always the most popular ones.

examples.zh: 成功从来都要靠自己努力。
examples.en: Success always depends on one's own efforts.

structures: 要么 + Option A，要么 + Option B
yaomePattern.description: You can give a series of alternatives by using 要么 (yàome). The structure is pretty versatile, as you can put a wide variety of things after each 要么:

examples.zh: 老板今天不在，要么你们明天再来吧。
examples.en: The boss isn't here today. How about if you all come back tomorrow?

examples.zh: 大家都觉得累得不行了，要么休息一会儿吧。
examples.en: Everyone is super tired. Why don't we rest for a while?

examples.zh: 最近这段时间大家都比较忙，要么过段时间再聚吧。
examples.en: Recently everyone has been pretty busy. How about we meet up after this busy period has passed?

examples.zh: 我周末还没安排，要么你们来我家一起做饭吧。
examples.en: I don't have plans for the weekend. How about you guys come to my place and we cook dinner together?

examples.zh: 我现在没那么多现金，要么先把我的身份证放在你这儿吧。
examples.en: I don't have that much cash right now. How about I leave my ID card with you for now?

examples.zh: 要么你去，要么他去。
examples.en: Either you go, or he goes.

examples.zh: 要么现在就买，要么就别买。
examples.en: Either buy it now, or don't buy it.

examples.zh: 你要么快点找工作，要么准备考研，不能什么都不做。
examples.en: Either hurry up and find a job or apply for grad school, but you can't just do nothing.

examples.zh: 去年暑假，我每天要么去健身，要么去图书馆，特别无聊。
examples.en: Last summer vacation I either went to the gym or the library every day. It was so boring.

examples.zh: 你要么去看电视，要么出去玩，不要来打扰我工作。
examples.en: Either go watch TV or go outside and play. Stop disturbing my work.

yaoWoShuoPattern.description: “要我说” (yào wǒ shuō) is another, more colloquial way to say "in my opinion" or "the way I see it." It is generally used to express a person's perspective or opinion about a matter.

examples.zh: 要我说，这件事先不要告诉爸妈。
examples.en: The way I see it, this is something we shouldn't tell Mom and Dad.

examples.zh: 要我说，就去外面吃吧，不要在家做饭了。
examples.en: I say we should just eat out instead of cooking at home.

examples.zh: 要我说，他就不应该跟老婆离婚。
examples.en: I think he shouldn't divorce his wife.

examples.zh: 要我说，带不带礼物都没关系，重要的是人要去。
examples.en: In my opinion, bringing gifts or not isn't what matters, the important thing is that people go.

examples.zh: 要我说，你们还是分手吧，他不适合你。
examples.en: I think you guys should break up. He's not right for you.

sequencingWithXianAndZaiPattern.description: The word 再 (zài) actually has a lot of uses, beyond just "again."  "先⋯⋯， 再⋯⋯" (xiān..., zài...) is a pattern used for sequencing events, much like "First..., then..." in English. This pattern can also include "然后" (ránhòu) meaning "and after that."

examples.zh: 先洗手再吃。
examples.en: Wash your hands, and then eat.

examples.zh: 我喜欢先洗澡，再睡觉。
examples.en: I prefer to take a bath before I go to bed.

examples.zh: 请你先买票再进。
examples.en: Please buy a ticket first, and then you come in.

examples.zh: 你要先做作业再看电视。
examples.en: First you need to do your homework, and then you can watch.

examples.zh: 你先找工作再考虑买房子。
examples.en: First find a job, then you can think about buying a house.

examples.zh: 先吃饭再说。
examples.en: Let's eat first, then we'll talk.

examples.zh: 先休息一下再说。
examples.en: Let's rest a little first, then talk.

examples.zh: 你先看完再说。
examples.en: Finish reading first, and then we can talk.

examples.zh: 我先问一下老板再说。
examples.en: I'm going to ask the boss first.

examples.zh: 你们先讨论一下再说。
examples.en: You guys discuss a little first, then we'll talk.

examples.zh: 今早我起床以后先准备早饭，再叫孩子们起床，接着我们一起吃早饭，然后我送他们去学校。
examples.en: After I got up this morning, I first prepared breakfast, and then I woke up the kids. Afterwards, we ate breakfast together. After that, I took them to school.

ruguoDehuaPattern.description: "如果⋯⋯的话，⋯⋯" (rúguǒ... dehuà, ...) is a pattern commonly used in Chinese to express "if." An easy way to remember the pattern's format is that in the full form, the condition is "sandwiched" between 如果 and 的话. "就" is often optional.

examples.zh: 如果明天下雨的话，我们就不去了。
examples.en: If it rains tomorrow, we won't go.

examples.zh: 别点那么多菜。如果吃不完的话，就太浪费了。
examples.en: Don't order so much. It will be a big waste of food if we can't finish all.

examples.zh: 如果有人帮他的话，他就不会出事了。
examples.en: If someone had helped him, he would't have had this accident.

examples.zh: 如果你们不来的话，一定会后悔的。
examples.en: If you don't come, you'll definitely regret it.

examples.zh: 如果他还是不同意的话，你怎么办？
examples.en: What will you do if he still disagree?

examples.zh: 你喜欢的话，就拿走吧。
examples.en: Take it if you like it.

examples.zh: 见到他们的话，帮我问好。
examples.en: If you meet them, tell them I say hello.

examples.zh: 不想去的话就别去了。
examples.en: Don't go if you don't feel like going.

structures: 还有 + Time Period + 就（要） + Verb Phrase + 了
expressingAboutToWithJiuyaoPattern.description: 就要 (jiùyào) is similar to 快要 (kuàiyào), meaning "about to." They are interchangeable in some cases. But there is a major difference that you need to take a good look at. 快要 (kuài yào) is generally "about to" [happen], but 就要 (jiù yào) could be used to mark a more specific time. 要 (yào) here can be omitted. For this one, you wouldn't normally use "about to" for this English translation, but the feeling is nevertheless that the impending event is coming up fast.

examples.zh: 我就要饿死了。
examples.en: I'm about to starve to death.

examples.zh: 他们就要结婚了。
examples.en: They are about to get married.

examples.zh: 就要下课了，还有别的问题吗？
examples.en: The class is almost over. Are there any other questions?

examples.zh: 还有十天宝宝就一岁了。
examples.en: In ten more days, the baby will be one year old.

examples.zh: 还有十分钟就下班了。
examples.en: In 10 more minutes I get off work.

examples.zh: 还有五天就要放假了。
examples.en: In 10 more days, I go on vacation.

examples.zh: 还有一个月就要过年了。
examples.en: In another month it will be Chinese New Year.

examples.zh: 还有两个星期就要考试了。
examples.en: We're just two weeks away from the test date.

renhePattern.description: 任何 (rènhé) is a modifier that means means "any," "whichever," or "whatsoever." It is also like the English phrases "any and all" or "no matter what."

examples.zh: 这是我们俩的秘密，跟任何人都不要说。
examples.en: This is our secret. Don't tell it to anyone.

examples.zh: 我父母不让我参加任何校外的活动。
examples.en: My parents won't let me participate in any school activity.

examples.zh: 这么多年过去了，他还是没有任何变化。
examples.en: So many years have passed, and he hasn't changed a bit.

examples.zh: 这种情况在任何时候都不能发生。
examples.en: You can't let this kind of thing happen in any circumstance.

examples.zh: 我们老板人很好，你有任何想法都可以跟他说。
examples.en: Our boss is a very good person. Any thoughts you have you can discuss with him.

examples.zh: 我先走了，有任何需要给我打电话吧。
examples.en: I'm leaving now. Call me if you need anything.

weilePattern.description: 为了 (wèile) is most often used to indicate the purpose of an action, or the person that will benefit from some act of kindness.  In the "purpose" sense, it corresponds pretty well to "in order to" or "for the purpose of" in English.

examples.zh: 为了钱，他出卖了朋友。
examples.en: He betrayed his friends for money.

examples.zh: 为了给他太太庆祝生日，他办了一个盛大的派对。
examples.en: He threw a grand party to celebrate his wife's birthday.

examples.zh: 为了有一个好的未来，我必须好好学习。
examples.en: In order to have a good future, I have to study hard.

examples.zh: 为了让自己有更好的语言环境，我打算去中国留学一年。
examples.en: In order to have a better language-learning environment, I plan to go to study in China for 1 year.

examples.zh: 为了让孩子一生下来就是美国人，中国很多有钱人都在美国生孩子。
examples.en: In order to make their child an American citizen, a lot of  rich Chinese people stay in the United States during their pregnancy.

examples.zh: 我这么做是为了给你一个更好的未来。
examples.en: The reason I did all this was to give you a better future.

examples.zh: 我离开中国是为了去美国结婚。
examples.en: The reason I left China was to go to the United States to get married.

examples.zh: 他俩一直不要孩子是为了多点时间享受二人世界。
examples.en: The reason they don't want to have kids is so they can spend more time with each other.

expressingNotVeryWithBuZenmePattern.description: When you use 不怎么 (bù zěnme) before an adjective, it means "not very." This structure is similar to how English speakers may say something is "not very good."

examples.zh: 我觉得这个菜不怎么好吃。
examples.en: I think this food isn't very tasty.

examples.zh: 这个人不怎么大方。
examples.en: This person isn't very generous.

examples.zh: 这里的冬天不怎么冷。
examples.en: It's not very cold here in winter.

examples.zh: 他的工资不怎么高。
examples.en: His salary isn't very high.

examples.zh: 她家不怎么干净。
examples.en: Her house isn't very clean.

examples.zh: 这个词不怎么实用。
examples.en: This word isn't very practical.

examples.zh: 他工作的时候不怎么认真。
examples.en: He isn't very careful when he's at work.

examples.zh: 我的中文不怎么流利。
examples.en: My Chinese isn't very fluent.

examples.zh: 他们看起来不怎么高兴。
examples.en: They seem not very happy.

expressingNotOftenWithBuZenmePattern.description: You might be tempted to conclude that 不怎么 (bù zěnme) seems to mean "not how," but it actually means "not often" when used together with a verb.

examples.zh: 他不怎么喜欢说话。
examples.en: He doesn't like talking too much.

examples.zh: 我不怎么吃猪肉。
examples.en: I don't often eat pork.

examples.zh: 我老公不怎么做饭。
examples.en: My husband doesn't cook very often.

examples.zh: 我的室友不怎么去逛街。
examples.en: My roommates don't go shopping very often.

examples.zh: 我们不怎么看电视。
examples.en: We don't watch a lot of television.

examples.zh: 他没怎么说话。
examples.en: He didn't say much.

examples.zh: 昨天我没怎么复习。
examples.en: I didn't review much yesterday.

examples.zh: 我没怎么见过他。
examples.en: I haven't seen him much.

examples.zh: 我父母没怎么吃过西餐。
examples.en: My parents didn't eat western food much.

examples.zh: 我们没怎么讨论这件事。
examples.en: We didn't discuss this matter much.

jiushiPattern.description: As an adverb, 就 (jiù) can be placed before the predicate to add emphasis. It often has an intense or provocative feel to it, like how we sometimes say in English "it's just not right!," or other similar phrases. It often appears as 就是.

examples.zh: 你就是个笨蛋！
examples.en: You're exactly a moron!

examples.zh: 他就是个骗子！
examples.en: He's exactly a liar!

examples.zh: 乔布斯就是我的偶像！
examples.en: Jobs is exactly my idol!

examples.zh: 我就要去！
examples.en: I just want to go!

examples.zh: 我就是喜欢他。
examples.en: I just like him.

examples.zh: 他就想出国。
examples.en: He just wants to go abroad.

examples.zh: 我问过很多次，他就是不说。
examples.en: I asked him many times. He just wouldn't tell.

examples.zh: 很多年轻人就喜欢打游戏。
examples.en: A lot of young people just like to play video games.

examples.zh: 她就不听我的话。
examples.en: She just wouldn't listen to me.

examples.zh: 谁都知道抽烟对身体不好，可很多人就是不戒烟。
examples.en: Everyone knows that smoking is bad for your body but a lot of people just don't quit smoking.

zhenghaoPattern.description: 正好 (zhènghǎo) can be used as an adjective or adverb to help express a coincidence, and it could be related to size, volume, quantity, degree, time, etc. This is similar to how we say in English “Oh, this shirt I grabbed was just the right size." or something like that. When used with a noun, use 正好 right after it. When used with a verb, the 正好 goes right before it. You can also use 正好 along with 得. This is usually a clause of its own.

examples.zh: 这件衣服的大小正好。
examples.en: The size of these clothes is just right.

examples.zh: 两个人正好，一个说，一个演。
examples.en: Two people is perfect. One to speak and one to act.

examples.zh: 水温正好，不冷也不热。
examples.en: The temperature of the water is perfect, not too cold, not too hot.

examples.zh: 这个楼层正好，不高也不低。
examples.en: The floor is perfect, not too high, not too low.

examples.zh: 两个房间正好，我一间，我爸妈一间。
examples.en: Two rooms are perfect. One for me and one for my parents.

examples.zh: 我正好要出去，你要我帮你带什么东西吗？
examples.en: I'm just about to leave. What do you want me to bring for you?

examples.zh: 我现在正好没事做，可以帮你照顾一下宝宝。
examples.en: I just happened to have nothing to do now so I can help you with the baby.

examples.zh: 我出门的时候正好下雨了。
examples.en: I was going out the door just as it started to rain.

examples.zh: 你来了！我正好要给你打电话。
examples.en: You are here! I was just going to call you.

examples.zh: 他正好是学这个专业的，也许可以帮你。
examples.en: His major is just this. Maybe he could help you.

examples.zh: 你来得正好，不早也不晚。
examples.en: You arrived at just the right time, not too early and not too late.

examples.zh: 米饭煮得正好，不硬也不软。
examples.en: The rice was made perfectly, not too hard and not too soft.

examples.zh: 盐放得正好，不咸也不淡。
examples.en: The amount of salt you put was just right, not too salty and not too bland.

examples.zh: 钱给得正好，不多也不少。
examples.en: The money you gave was just right, not too much and not too little.

examples.zh: 这个地方你选得正好，离我们都很近。
examples.en: The place you chose was perfect. It was close to both of us.

jieguoPattern.description: 结果 (jiéguǒ) can be used as a conjunction or adverb, meaning "as a result" or "consequently." It comes at the beginning of the sentence and is typically used to introduce a negative or undesirable result.

examples.zh: 她穿得太少了，结果第二天就感冒了。
examples.en: She didn't wear enough, as a result, she had a cold the next day.

examples.zh: 我昨天去跟朋友喝酒，结果喝醉了。
examples.en: I went to have a drink with my friends yesterday. As a result, I got drunk.

examples.zh: 他没好好复习，结果没通过考试。
examples.en: He didn't review well. As a result, he didn't pass the exam.

examples.zh: 他经常麻烦别人，可是从来不帮朋友，结果一个朋友也没有。
examples.en: He often gives other people trouble, but he never helps his friends. As a result, he doesn't have any friends.

examples.zh: 我们买了很多菜，肯定够吃。
examples.en: We bought a lot of food. It must be good enough to eat.

examples.zh: 他带了好多衣服，应该够换。
examples.en: He brought a lot of clothes. It should be enough to change.

examples.zh: 我们只有三个人，你的车肯定够坐。
examples.en: We only have three people. I'm sure your car is big enough to sit in.

examples.zh: 这些菜够吃了，不要再买了。
examples.en: This food is enough to eat. Don't buy more.

examples.zh: 我带的钱够用了，你不用带了。
examples.en: I've brought enough money to spend. You don't need to  bring any.

examples.zh: 你家太小了，恐怕不够住。
examples.en: Your house is too small. I'm afraid it's not big enough to live in.

examples.zh: 你的包太小了，这些东西肯定不够放。
examples.en: You bag is too small. This stuff definitely can't fit in it.

examples.zh: 办公室的纸不够用了，你明天去买一些吧。
examples.en: The paper in the office is not enough to use. You should go buy some tomorrow.

examples.zh: 我这个月的钱不够花了，你能不能借我五百？
examples.en: I don't have enough money to spend this month. Could you lend me five hundred kuai?

examples.zh: 别说了！这些话我已经听够了！
examples.en: Stop talking! I've heard enough of it!

examples.zh: 你今天玩游戏已经玩了三个小时了，玩够了没有？！
examples.en: You've been playing games for three hours today. Are you not done yet?

examples.zh: 我受够了！我一定要跟他离婚！
examples.en: I had enough of him. I'm definitely going to divorce him.

examples.zh: 你天天都叫外卖，还没吃够吗？
examples.en: You order takeout every day. Haven't you gotten sick of eating it?

zheyangPattern.description: 这样 (zhèyàng) is used at the beginning of a phrase to express "this way" or "in this way."

examples.zh: 我们还是坐地铁吧，这样更方便。
examples.en: We'd better take the metro. It's more convenient this way.

examples.zh: 你要多吃蔬菜，这样对身体更好。
examples.en: You should eat more vegetables. It's better for your body this way.

examples.zh: 你要多说，这样才能提高汉语口语。
examples.en: You need to speak more. You can improve your spoken Chinese this way.

examples.zh: 你要让他自己做，只有这样他才能学会。
examples.en: You should let him do it by himself. Only in this way can he learn.

examples.zh: 这样的话，你还怕什么呢？
examples.en: What are you afraid of in this case?

examples.zh: 如果是这样的话，我觉得你们需要更多的帮助。
examples.en: If this is the case, I think you need to get more help.

examples.zh: 如果不是这样的话，那你为什么生我的气？
examples.en: If this is not the case, then why are you mad at me?

examples.zh: 如果不是这样的话，你还有什么更好的解释？
examples.en: If this is not the case, do you have a better explanation?

structures: 几乎 + Subj. + 都 + Verb / Adj.
Subj. + 几乎 + 不 / 没 + Predicate
jihuPattern.description: 几乎 (jīhū) means 'nearly', 'almost' or 'practically', and is used to emphasize that someone or something 'almost' meets a certain standard or is close to doing something.

examples.zh: 几乎每个人都有手机。
examples.en: Almost everyone has a cell phone.

examples.zh: 在我们公司，几乎每个人都会说英文。
examples.en: In our company, almost everyone can speak English.

examples.zh: 在中国，几乎所有老外都会说“你好”。
examples.en: In China, almost all of the foreigners can say "hello" in Chinese.

examples.zh: 几乎所有人都相信他。
examples.en: Almost everyone believes what he said.

examples.zh: 几乎全世界的观众都喜欢这部电影。
examples.en: Almost all the audience in the world like this movie.

examples.zh: 爸爸的头发几乎白了。
examples.en: Dad's hair is almost all white.

examples.zh: 这次旅行，他们几乎花了所有的钱。
examples.en: They spent almost all the money on this trip.

examples.zh: 他一个人几乎吃了一整个蛋糕。
examples.en: He almost ate this whole cake by himself.

examples.zh: 我老板几乎不喝酒。
examples.en: Almost all our family doesn't drink.

examples.zh: 老板这几个月几乎没好好休息过。
examples.en: The boss barely has taken any good rest for the recent few months.

structures: Subj. + Time  Word + 就 + Verb + Obj. + 了
expressingEarlinessWithJiuPattern.description: Just as 才 (cái) can express lateness, 就 (jiù) can be used to indicate that something happened earlier or sooner than expected.  It can also be used in the near future to indicate something will happen very soon. 早就 means "long ago," and is usually used to express a kind of impatience or surprise on the part of the speaker. It comes before the verb.

examples.zh: 我马上就来。
examples.en: I'll be there in a second.

examples.zh: 他们一会儿就到。
examples.en: They will be here in a few minutes.

examples.zh: 老板明天就回来。
examples.en: The boss will be back tomorrow.

examples.zh: 我昨晚八点半就睡觉了。
examples.en: I went to bed at half past eight last night.

examples.zh: 我们早上九点上课，可是他八点就来了。
examples.en: We have class at nine in the morning, but he came at eight.

examples.zh: 爷爷每天五点就起床了。
examples.en: Grandpa gets up at five o'clock every day.

examples.zh: 她十八岁就大学毕业了。
examples.en: She graduated from college when she was only 18 years old.

examples.zh: 我早就知道了！
examples.en: I knew that long ago!

examples.zh: 她早就结婚了。
examples.en: She got married long time ago.

examples.zh: 我们早就毕业了。
examples.en: We graduated a long time ago!

examples.zh: 我早就跟你说过，他不是好人。
examples.en: I told you a long time ago that he's not a good guy.

examples.zh: 这家店早就关门了。
examples.en: This shop closed a long time ago.

structures: Subj. + 就 + Number + Measure Word + Noun
expressingSmallQuantityWithJiuPattern.description: 就 (jiù) is often translated simply as "just" or "only," but there are some nuances to how it is used.

examples.zh: 这件事就我一个人知道。
examples.en: I'm the only person that knows about this.

examples.zh: 我们都忘了，就他还记得。
examples.en: We all forgot. Only he still remembers it.

examples.zh: 所有的菜都很好吃，就这个菜有点咸。
examples.en: All the food is delicious. Just this one dish is a little salty.

examples.zh: 大家都下班了，就老板还在办公室。
examples.en: Everyone finished work and left. Only the boss is still in the office.

examples.zh: 你觉得别人都是傻子吗？就你聪明？
examples.en: Do you think everyone is an idiot? That only you are smart?

examples.zh: 这家公司我就认识一个人。
examples.en: I only know one person in this company.

examples.zh: 这家餐厅我就来过一次。
examples.en: I've only been to this restaurant once.

examples.zh: 她在我们公司就工作了两个月。
examples.en: She has worked at our company for only two months.

examples.zh: 我老板就会说几句英文。
examples.en: My boss can only speak a few sentences of English.

examples.zh: 你怎么就点了这几个菜？
examples.en: How could you order just these few dishes?

examples.zh: 为什么这里就一个厕所？
examples.en: Why does this place only have one bathroom?

examples.zh: 你们家就一个孩子吗？
examples.en: Does your family only have one child?

examples.zh: 我就一个哥哥。
examples.en: I only have one brother.

examples.zh: 他在上海就一个朋友。
examples.en: He only has one friend in Shanghai.

examples.zh: 我们公司就三个员工。
examples.en: There are only three employees in our company.

expressingLatenessWithCaiPattern.description: One of the ways to express lateness in Chinese is with 才 (cái).

examples.zh: 我昨天十点才下班。
examples.en: I got off work at ten o'clock yesterday.

examples.zh: 他二十五岁才去上大学。
examples.en: He didn't go to college until he was 25.

examples.zh: 我们十点上课，可是他十点半才来。
examples.en: We have class at 10 o'clock, but he didn't come until 10:30.

examples.zh: 如果我晚上十二点半才回家，我妈会很不高兴。
examples.en: If I don't get home until 12:30 pm, my mother will be very unhappy.

examples.zh: 我等了十分钟，他才给我开门。
examples.en: He didn't open the door until I waited for ten minutes.

usingCaiForSmallNumbersPattern.description: The character 才 (cái) can be used to emphasize that a number is small, or less than expected.

examples.zh: 你才二十岁？
examples.en: You're only twenty?

examples.zh: 这家公司才三个员工。
examples.en: This company only has three employees.

examples.zh: 这个班才两个学生。
examples.en: This class only has two students.

examples.zh: 我一个月工资才两千。
examples.en: My monthly salary is only two thousand RMB.

examples.zh: 你才吃一个包子？
examples.en: You only ate one baizi?

examples.zh: 她才来上海两个月。
examples.en: She's only been in Shanghai for two months.

examples.zh: 我们才看完一页。
examples.en: We only finished reading one page.

examples.zh: 这顿饭才花了二十块。
examples.en: This meal only cost twenty kuai.

examples.zh: 他们认识才三个星期就结婚了。
examples.en: They only knew each other for three weeks before they got married.

structures: Subj. + 也 + 都 + Verb / Adj.
usingYeAndDouTogetherPattern.description: If you are trying to draw similarities amongst a group, you will want to pair two key words together. You will want to use 也 (yě) first followed by 都 (dōu) to express that a group of people have something in common.

examples.zh: 他们也都是法国人。
examples.en: They are also all French people.

examples.zh: 我们也都喜欢喝啤酒。
examples.en: We all like to drink beer too.

examples.zh: 你们也都是学生吗？
examples.en: Are you all students too?

examples.zh: 我的三个孩子也都是男孩。
examples.en: My three children are also all boys.

examples.zh: 我们办公室的女同事也都结婚了。
examples.en: Our female colleagues are all married too.

examples.zh: 这个酒吧里也都是年轻人。
examples.en: Everybody in this bar is also young.

examples.zh: 我们喜欢来这里，孩子们也都喜欢来这里。
examples.en: We like to come here, all the kids also like to come here.

examples.zh: 老板经常加班，你们也都加班吗？
examples.en: The boss constantly works overtime, do you all also work overtime?

examples.zh: 他们是你的朋友，他们也都是我的朋友。
examples.en: They are your friends, they are all my friends too.

examples.zh: 北京的房子很贵，别的大城市的房子也都很贵。
examples.en: Apartments in Beijing are very expensive, in other big cities all apartments are also very expensive.

examples.zh: 这里的同事也都很好。
examples.en: All the co-workers here are also really good.

examples.zh: 她的妹妹们也都很漂亮。
examples.en: Her little sisters are also very beautiful.

examples.zh: 这家店的面包不错，别的点心也都很好吃。
examples.en: This store's bread is not bad, the other snacks are also very delicious.

structures: Noun 1 + 比 + Noun 2 + Adj. + 得多 / 多了 / 很多
Noun 1 + 比 + Noun 2 + 还 + Adj.
expressingMuchMoreInComparisonsPattern.description: If you want to up the intensity of your comparisons, you might want to express "much more." You can do this using 多 (duō), but did you know there are actually three different ways to do it?

examples.zh: 上海比我老家贵多了。
examples.en: It's much more expensive in Shanghai than in my hometown.

examples.zh: 他打篮球比我厉害多了。
examples.en: He plays basketball much better than I do.

examples.zh: 这个老师比那个老师严格得多。
examples.en: This teacher is much more strict than that teacher.

examples.zh: 坐高铁比坐飞机方便很多。
examples.en: It's much more convenient to take the high-speed train than the airplane.

examples.zh: 韩国的整容技术比我们国家发达得多。
examples.en: The cosmetic technology in Korea is more developed than our country.

examples.zh: 北京的人口比上海还多。
examples.en: The population of Beijing is even bigger than Shanghai.

examples.zh: 这家店比那家店还贵。
examples.en: This shop is even more expensive than that one.

examples.zh: 他比姚明还高。
examples.en: He is even taller than Yao Ming.

examples.zh: 你比我还懒。
examples.en: You're even lazier than me.

examples.zh: 弟弟比哥哥还调皮。
examples.en: The younger brother is even more naughty than the elder brother.

shenmeDePattern.description: 什么的(shénme de) is an informal way to express "etc.," and is used to end a list of items when it is obvious to the listener what class of things the speaker is talking about. 什么的 can also be used after a single item if it is obvious enough what might follow.

examples.zh: 我奶奶不吃肉，只吃蔬菜、豆腐什么的。
examples.en: My grandma doesn't eat meat. She only eats vegetables, tofu, and so on.

examples.zh: 养狗很麻烦，你要喂它，给他洗澡，跟它玩什么的。
examples.en: Having a dog gives you too much trouble. You need to feed it, give it a bath, play with it, and so on.

examples.zh: 数学、物理、化学什么的，我都不感兴趣。
examples.en: Math, physics, chemistry, and so on. I'm not interested in any of them.

examples.zh: 我喜欢实用的礼物，手表、衣服、书什么的。
examples.en: I like practical presents, watch, clothes, books and so on.

examples.zh: 我们见面一般就是吃饭、聊天什么的。
examples.en: When we meet, we just eat and talk, and so on.

examples.zh: 明天去野餐，我们要不要买一些水果，零食什么的。
examples.en: We are going on picnic tomorrow. Shall we buy some fruits, snacks, and so on.

examples.zh: 跑步、游泳、篮球什么的，这些运动他都喜欢。
examples.en: Running, swimming, basketball, and so on. He likes all these sports.

examples.zh: 长城、故宫什么的，都是北京很有名的景点。
examples.en: The Great Wall, Summer Palace, and so on. They're all very famous tourist attractions in Beijing.

examples.zh: 一个人住，洗衣服、做饭什么的都要自己做。
examples.en: When you live alone, you need to do things all by yourself, doing laundry, cooking, and so on.

examples.zh: 电视、洗衣机什么的，我爸爸都会修。
examples.en: Television, washing machine, and so on. My father can fix many things.

zhileidePattern.description: 之类的 (zhīlèide) can be translated as "and so on" or "and stuff like that." As in English, this grammar point is used to continue a list without explicitly mentioning further items within it.

examples.zh: 越来越多的人不吃快餐，像KFC之类的。
examples.en: More and more people don't eat fast food, like KFC and stuff like that.

examples.zh: 我喜欢呆在大城市，像上海、香港之类的。
examples.en: I like to stay in big cities like Shanghai, Hong Kong, and places like that.

examples.zh: 他喜欢谈论漂亮的女明星，像章子怡、张柏芝之类的。
examples.en: He likes to talk about pretty actresses like Zhang Ziyi, Zhang Baizhi, and people like that.

examples.zh: 你喜欢看《西游记》之类的电影吗？
examples.en: Do you like to watch movies like "Journey into the West"?

examples.zh: 一看就知道她很有钱，穿的都是Gucci、Chanel之类的衣服。
examples.en: You can tell she is rich as soon as you look at her. All of her clothes are brands like Gucci and Chanel.

haiyouPattern.description: "还有" (háiyǒu) is used to express "in addition..." or "and also..." in a conversation. It is introducing new information to the topic the speaker is talking about, as an afterthought. While it's not the most challenging grammar structure, an important thing to keep in mind is that 还有 normally starts a completely new sentence or clause.

examples.zh: 你需要吃点药。还有，要多休息。
examples.en: You need to take some medicine. Also, you should get more rest.

examples.zh: 你跟他一起去吧。还有，别忘了带这些材料。
examples.en: Please go with him. Also, don't forget to bring these materials.

examples.zh: 我今天要考试。还有，我必须要写完中文作文。
examples.en: I’m going to have an exam today. Plus, I must finish writing my Chinese essay.

structures: 另外 ＋ 一 + Measure Word + Noun
lingWaiPattern.description: 另外 (lìng wài) can be used to express "in addition," often with 还 used in the following phrase.

examples.zh: 希望你不要再迟到了。另外，你应该穿得正式一点。
examples.en: I hope you won't be late again. In addition, you should also dress a little more formally.

examples.zh: 我刚才说的这些都很重要，不过大家另外补充的也很重要。
examples.en: What I just said is very important, but what everyone added is also very important.

examples.zh: 不好意思先生，这里是VIP室，要另外加钱才能用。
examples.en: I'm sorry sir, this is the VIP section. You will have to pay more in order to use it.

examples.zh: 我们这儿每天九点关门。九点以后，你还想学习的话，要另外找地方。
examples.en: We close at 9pm every day. You need to find another place if you still want to study after that.

examples.zh: 我有两个手机，一个是Lenovo，另外一个是iPhone。
examples.en: I have two cell phones. One is Lenovo, and the other is iPhone.

examples.zh: 她有两套房子，一套自己住，另外一套租给了别人。
examples.en: She has two houses. She lives in one and rents out the other one.

examples.zh: 我们可以早点去，另外几个人晚点到也没关系。
examples.en: We can go a  little bit earlier. It's OK that the other few people come a little bit late.

examples.zh: 这些书太重了，我想先带几本最近需要的，另外几本下次再拿。
examples.en: These books are too heavy. I want to take a few that I'll be needing recently. I can get the rest of them next time.

zaishuoPattern.description: "再说⋯⋯" (zàishuō...) is used in a similar way as "In addition" or "Moreover," in that it is adding on additional information or reasons to the topic at hand.

examples.zh: 我还不想结婚，因为年纪太小了。再说，也没有遇到合适的人。
examples.en: I don't want to get married yet because I'm too young. And besides, I haven't met the right one.

examples.zh: 现在太早了，我不想去，再说那个商店还没开门。
examples.en: It's too early now. I don't want to go. The store hasn't opened yet, anyway.

examples.zh: 我不想帮助他，因为他经常说谎，再说我也没钱。
examples.en: I don't want to help him because he lies a lot. Furthermore, I don't have any money.

structures: 要不 + Option A，要不 + Option B
yaobuPattern.description: 要不 (yàobù) can have a number of meanings, ranging from "either/or" to "how about."

examples.zh: 要不你去，要不他去。
examples.en: Either you go or he goes.

examples.zh: 你要不回家，要不陪我再玩一会儿。
examples.en: You either go home or hang out with me a little more.

examples.zh: 你要不安静一点，要不就出去。
examples.en: You can either be quiet or get out.

examples.zh: 一个人去没意思，要不我们一起去吧？
examples.en: It's no fun to go by myself. How about we go together?

examples.zh: 下雨了，要不明天再去吧。
examples.en: It's raining. How about we go tomorrow?

examples.zh: 家里停水了，要不今晚出去吃吧。
examples.en: We have a blackout of water supply at home. How about we go eat out tonight?

examples.zh: 走路过去挺远的，要不我开车送你去吧。
examples.en: It's quite far away to walk there. How about I drive you there?

examples.zh: 要不我们去逛街吧，比在家看电视有意思。
examples.en: Let's go shopping. It's more fun than watching TV at home.

examples.zh: 打个车吧，要不会迟到的。
examples.en: You should take a taxi, otherwise you'll be late.

examples.zh: 快点做吧，要不又得加班了。
examples.en: Do it faster, otherwise we are going to work late again.

examples.zh: 快点回家吧，要不你爸妈会担心的。
examples.en: Hurry and go home, or your parents will start to worry.

examples.zh: 少放点辣椒，要不太辣了。
examples.en: Don't put so much chili pepper, otherwise it'll be so spicy.

structures: A + 是 / 占 (+ B) + 的 + Denominator + 分之 + Numerator
fenzhiPattern.description: 分之 (fēnzhī) is used to form a fraction in Chinese. When expressing a fraction, the denominator is always said before the numerator. This pattern is also the way percentages are expressed in Chinese.

examples.zh: 蛋糕还有八分之一。
这桶水还有五分之三。
我的手机电量还有百分之三十。
押金要付百分之二十。
我们班有三分之一的同学是外国人。
examples.en: One third of our classmates are foreign students.

examples.zh: 美国人口差不多是中国人口的四分之一。
我们学校四分之三的老师都是男老师。
我们的需求占整个市场需求的十分之三。
电动车的销量占新车销量的八分之五。
Trump在这个州的支持率是百分之五十七点四。
过去二十年，大城市年轻人的离婚率增加了百分之八。

expressingWhenWithShiPattern.description: By now you should now how to express "when" using "的时候" (de shíhou). But there's also a slightly shorter, more formal way to do it: simply use 时 (shí) all by itself. (No 的!)

examples.zh: 考试时不要说话。
examples.en: When you take a test, don't talk.

examples.zh: 面试时我经常会问这个问题。
examples.en: I often ask this question in a job interview.

examples.zh: 会议结束时老板才来。
examples.en: The boss showed up when the meeting was over.

examples.zh: 我生气时不想说话。
examples.en: I don't want to talk when I'm angry.

examples.zh: 他们结婚时什么都没有。
examples.en: They've got nothing when they got married.

examples.zh: 大学毕业时，他们分手了。
examples.en: When they graduated, they broke up.

examples.zh: 飞机起飞时，他关了手机和电脑。
examples.en: When the plane took off, he turned off his cell phone and computer.

examples.zh: 他去世时儿女都不在身边。
examples.en: His parents weren't home when he passed away.

examples.zh: 我们公司成立时只有三个人。
examples.en: There were only three people when this company was founded.

examples.zh: 跟父母说话时不要玩手机。
examples.en: Stop playing with your cell phone when you talk with your parents.

structures: 自 / 从 / 自从 + Time or Event + 以来
yilaiPattern.description: There are a few ways to express "ever since" in Chinese. In English, we would say something like "ever since I came to Shanghai, my Chinese has improved a lot." In this article, we will first take a look at using 以来 (yǐlái) to mean "ever since." We will also take a quick look at using "ever since" with 来 (lái), which is similar but used in a somewhat different way.

examples.zh: 上大学以来，我一直没逃过课。
examples.en: Since I was in college, I haven't skipped a class.

examples.zh: 到上海以来，他的汉语水平提高了。
examples.en: Ever since he came to Shanghai, his Chinese has been improving.

examples.zh: 住院以来，常常有朋友来医院看望她。
examples.en: Ever since she was in hospital, her friends have constantly come and visited her.

examples.zh: 自从我拿到驾照以来已经有五年了。
examples.en: I've had my license for five years.

examples.zh: 自从去年夏天以来，他一直没有回过家。
examples.en: He hasn't  returned home since last summer.

examples.zh: 自从退学以来，他一直在帮父母做农活。
examples.en: Since he left school,he's been helping her parents do farm work.

examples.zh: 自从1979年改革开放以来，中国人的生活水平得到了提高。
examples.en: Ever since the 1979 reform, the Chinese people's level of living has gone up.

examples.zh: 三个月来，我们去了很多地方旅游。
examples.en: Since three months ago, we've traveled to a lot of places.

examples.zh: 五年来，物价一直上涨。
examples.en: Ever since five years ago, prices have been going up.

examples.zh: 我的同学几天来一直没有上课。
examples.en: My classmate hasn't come to class for a few days now.

guanyuPattern.description: 关于 (guānyú) usually points to a range or scope, acting like the English word "about." It can be used in a few ways, often marking a topic of a statement, or modifying a noun.

examples.zh: 关于中国历史，我知道的不多。
examples.en: As for Chinese history, I don't know a lot.

examples.zh: 关于这次考试，我还有几个问题要问。
examples.en: As for this exam, I still have a lot of questions that I need to ask.

examples.zh: 关于这个问题，你们还是问他吧。
examples.en: As for this problem, you'd better ask him.

examples.zh: 关于你的建议，老板还在考虑。
examples.en: As for your suggestion, the boss is still thinking it over.

examples.zh: 关于那个调查结果，我们也不太清楚。
examples.en: As for the result of that research, we don't know much either.

examples.zh: 你有关于这次会议的PPT吗？
examples.en: Do you have the Powerpoint for this meeting?

examples.zh: 这是一份关于中国市场的报告。
examples.en: This is a report about the Chinese markets.

examples.zh: 关于这次旅行的计划还没做好。
examples.en: We haven't really figured out our plan for this trip yet.

examples.zh: 经理想了解更多关于新项目的情况。
examples.en: The manager wants to know more about the new project.

usingDuiWithVerbsPattern.description: When using 对 (duì) as a preposition, it is used to indicate "to" or "towards" an object or target. As with all prepositions, some care should be taken when using this particle, as usage of 对 doesn't always totally "make sense" or correspond to English at all.

examples.zh: 宝宝对我笑了。
examples.en: The baby smiled at me.

examples.zh: 小狗在对你叫。
examples.en: The dog is barking at you.

examples.zh: 你不应该这样对我们说话。
examples.en: You shouldn't talk to us this way.

examples.zh: 你怎么能对你妈妈大喊大叫？
examples.en: How could you shout at your mother?

examples.zh: 不要对孩子发脾气！
examples.en: Don't lose your temper at the child!

examples.zh: 对我来说，中文最难的语法是把字句。
examples.en: To me, the most difficult Chinese grammar is Ba sentence.

examples.zh: 对他来说，家人比工作更重要。
examples.en: To him, family is more important than work.

examples.zh: 对老板来说，赚钱是第一。
examples.en: To the boss, making money comes first.

examples.zh: 穿这种衣服对我们来说太奢侈了。
examples.en: To us, it's too luxurious to wear this kind of clothes.

examples.zh: 这个问题对一个五岁的孩子来说太复杂了。
examples.en: For a five-year-old kid, this question is too complicated.

examples.zh: 你要对自己的工作负责。
examples.en: You need to be responsible for your job.

examples.zh: 老板好像对你不太满意。
examples.en: The boss seems not very satisfied with you.

examples.zh: 这里的服务员都对顾客很热情。
examples.en: The waiters here are all very friendly to the customers.

examples.zh: 这个App对我的英语学习很有帮助。
examples.en: This method helps a lot with my English learning.

examples.zh: 这件事对他的影响很大。
examples.en: This piece of matter has a big influence on him.

structures: Subj. + 把 + Obj. + Verb + 给 + Somebody
verbsFollowedByGeiPattern.description: Although it's standard practice to put a word or phrase that modifies a verb before the verb, there are, of course, exceptions. 给 (gěi) is one of those exceptions; it sometimes comes before the verb, and sometimes after. This article is about when it comes after.

examples.zh: 他送给了我一束花。
examples.en: He gave me a bouquet of flowers.

examples.zh: 这个老板卖给了我一条死鱼。
examples.en: This boss sold me a dead fish.

examples.zh: 我要还给你三十块钱。
examples.en: I need to return 30rmb to you.

examples.zh: 房东租给了我一个很便宜的房子。
examples.en: The landlord rented a very cheap house to me.

examples.zh: 我借给了他一本书。
examples.en: I lent him a book.

examples.zh: 我要糖，他递给了我一瓶盐。
examples.en: I wanted sugar, he handed me a bottle of salt.

examples.zh: 姐姐分给了我一块蛋糕。
examples.en: Older sister gave me a piece of cake.

examples.zh: 老师传授给了学生很多经验。
examples.en: The teacher passed on a lot of experience to us.

examples.zh: 我们献给了老师一首歌。
examples.en: We dedicated a song to the teacher.

examples.zh: 这些校友捐给了学校二十万。
examples.en: These alumni donated two hundred thousand to the school.

examples.zh: 主人赏给了小狗一块肉。
examples.en: The owner rewarded his dog with a piece of meat.

examples.zh: 一个孩子交给了我一封信。
examples.en: A child gave me a letter.

examples.zh: 他把一束花送给了我。
examples.en: He gave me a bouquet of flowers.

examples.zh: 这个老板把一条死鱼卖给了我。
examples.en: This boss sold me a dead fish.

examples.zh: 房东把一个很便宜的房子租给了我。
examples.en: The landlord rented a very cheap house to me.

examples.zh: 我把书借给了他。
examples.en: I lent him a book.

examples.zh: 我要糖，他把一瓶盐递给了我。
examples.en: I wanted sugar, he handed me a bottle of salt.

examples.zh: 姐姐把一块蛋糕分给了我。
examples.en: Older sister gave me a piece of cake.

examples.zh: 老师把很多经验都传授给了学生。
examples.en: The teacher passed on a lot of experience to us.

examples.zh: 我们把一首歌献给了老师。
examples.en: We dedicated a song to the teacher.

examples.zh: 这些校友把二十万捐给了学校。
examples.en: These alumnus donated two hundred thousand to the school.

examples.zh: 主人把一块肉赏给了小狗。
examples.en: The owner rewarded his dog with a piece of meat.

examples.zh: 一个孩子把一封信交给了我。
examples.en: A child gave me a letter.

expressingThenWithNamePattern.description: When expressing "Then...," you can use "那么" (nàme) or "那" (nà) in order to begin a judgment or result from previous context. An example of this in English would be "Then, what should we do?"

examples.zh: 大家都同意这个方案，那么，我们就开始实施吧。
examples.en: Everyone agrees on this plan, so we'll start to implement it.

examples.zh: 你认为这个想法行不通，那么，你有其他的想法吗？
examples.en: You don’t think this idea is possible. Then have you got any other good idea?

examples.zh: 他不听，那我应该怎么办？
examples.en: He wouldn't listen. What shall I do then?

examples.zh: 你说得有道理，那么就这么办吧。
examples.en: What you said makes sense to me, so just do it as you said.

examples.zh: 老板不同意，那你怎么办？
examples.en: The boss is not very satisfied with the p, so you keep working on it.

examples.zh: 大家都到了，那么请开始表演吧。
examples.en: Everybody is here, so let the performance begin.

examples.zh: 热身完了，那我们开始吧。
examples.en: The warmup is over. Now let't start.

examples.zh: 你认为这个办法不行，那你有别的办法吗？
examples.en: You don't think this idea is good. Then have you got any other good idea?

examples.zh: 他最近的表现不错，那么就让他通过吧。
examples.en: His recent performance is not bad, so let him pass.

examples.zh: 你不让我管，那你会管吗？
examples.en: You don't let me take care of it. So will you take care of it?

examples.zh: 雨太大了，那你们今晚都留下来吧。
examples.en: The rain is too heavy, so you should all stay here for tonight.

examples.zh: 客户确认了，那么我们就准备签合同了。
examples.en: The client has confirmed, so let's get prepared to sign the contract.

advancedYesnoQuestionsWithMaPattern.description: The question particle 吗 (ma) is a very simple way to convert it into a "yes/no question," and beginners will learn not to use 吗 with other question words, because it's redundant. More advanced students, however, will note that 吗 has some more complicated structures that do involve combining it with question words in order to ask very specific types of confirming questions. Note that the following examples typically contains some kind of "verb of understanding" such as 知道 (zhīdào),了解 (liǎojiě), 明白 (míngbai), 认识 (rènshi), etc. Then "吗" (ma) can still be added at the end of the question, turning it into a kind of confirmation.

examples.zh: 你知道这是什么东西吗？
examples.en: Do you know what this thing is?

examples.zh: 你知道他是谁吗？
examples.en: Do you know who he is?

examples.zh: 你明白这是什么意思吗？
examples.en: Do you understand the meaning of this?

examples.zh: 你明白他的问题是什么吗？
examples.en: Do you understand what his question is?

examples.zh: 你知道他叫什么名字吗？
examples.en: Do you what his name is?

examples.zh: 你知道王老师在哪里吗？
examples.en: Do you know where Teacher Wang is?

reviewOptionsBaPattern.description: When 吧 (ba) is used twice in a sentence, it is used to list two options that the speaker is debating. It gives the sentence an indecisive feel, as though the speaker doesn't know which one to choose. This construction often has a negative connotation, since the options usually are not ideal.

examples.zh: 去上海吧，太远；去北京吧，人太多。
examples.en: Going to Shanghai is too far away, going to Beijing has too many people.

examples.zh: 冬天去吧，太冷；夏天去吧，太热。
examples.en: Going in the winter is too cold, going in the summer is too hot.

examples.zh: 买房吧，没钱；不买房吧，没老婆。
examples.en: If you buy a house, you won't have money. If you don't buy a house you won't have a wife.

examples.zh: 学中文吧，太难；不学中文吧，找不到好工作。
examples.en: Studying Mandarin is too hard, but if you don't study Mandarin you cannot find a job.

examples.zh: 去学校工作吧，钱太少；去公司吧，太累。
examples.en: Working at the school, the pay is too little, but working at a company is too tiring.

examples.zh: 这件衣服，买吧，太贵；不买吧，又很喜欢。
examples.en: If I buy these clothes, they're too expensive, but if I don't buy them, I'll really want them.

examples.zh: 上班吧，很累；不上班吧，又无聊。
examples.en: Going to work? Too tiring. Not going to work? There's nothing to do.

examples.zh: 这件事情，你同意吧，你不高兴；不同意吧，别人不高兴。
examples.en: As for this matter, if you agree, you'll be unhappy, if you don't agree, other people will be unhappy.

examples.zh: 早点去吧，需要等；晚点吧，可能迟到。
examples.en: If we go early we'll have to wait, but if we go later, we might arrive late.

examples.zh: 在复习一点吧，太累了；去睡觉吧，怕明天考的不好。
examples.en: I should study more, but I'm too tired. However if I go to sleep now, I'm afraid I won't do well on the test tomorrow.

expressingForWithWeiPattern.description: When you work for a company, or do other sorts of physical (and even mental) activities for another party, you're likely to use the Chinese preposition 为 (wèi), which is often translated into English as "for," a translation which is often unnatural or unnecessary, depending on the particular phrase.  The super common Mao-era phrase, 为人民服务 ("serve the people"), doesn't need the word "for" in English, for example.

examples.zh: 他为我做了很多事。
examples.en: He's done a lot for me.

examples.zh: 我们都为你高兴。
examples.en: We are all happy for you.

examples.zh: 你们可以来为我们加油。
examples.en: You can come to cheer us up.

examples.zh: 她为美国政府工作。
examples.en: She works for the United States government.

examples.zh: 为人民服务。
examples.en: Serve the people.

examples.zh: 公司为她提供了很多资源。
examples.en: The company provided her with many resources.

kanqilaiPattern.description: One of the most common ways to express "it looks like" is to use 看起来 (kànqǐlái). This is what we would use if we wanted to express something like, "she looks tired."

examples.zh: 这个看起来很漂亮。
examples.en: This looks very pretty.

examples.zh: 他看起来很友好。
examples.en: He looks friendly.

examples.zh: 这个蛋糕看起来很好吃。
examples.en: This cake looks really tasty.

examples.zh: 你今天看起来很累。
examples.en: You look really tired today.

examples.zh: 这家餐厅看起来不错。
examples.en: This restaurant looks good.

expressingTowardsWithXiangPattern.description: 向 (xiàng) is a preposition that means "towards," and is used often when expressing or referring to a certain point.

examples.zh: 向东走。
examples.en: Walk towards east.

examples.zh: 向前看。
examples.en: Look forward.

examples.zh: 向左转。
examples.en: Turn left.

examples.zh: 老师正向我们走来。
examples.en: The teacher is walking up towards us.

examples.zh: 火车已经开了，她还在向我招手。
examples.en: The train already took off. She kept waving towards me.

examples.zh: 你必须向他道歉！
examples.en: You must apologize to him!

examples.zh: 这件事你应该向老板汇报一下。
examples.en: You should report this to the boss!

examples.zh: 向雷锋同志学习！
examples.en: Learn from Comrade Lei Feng!

examples.zh: 我不喜欢向朋友借钱。
examples.en: I don't like to borrow money to my friends.

examples.zh: 你会向陌生人求助吗？
examples.en: Would you ask strangers for help?

examples.zh: 我们都没经验，是来向你请教的。
examples.en: None of us have experience. We're here to ask you for advice.

expressingAfterWithJingguoPattern.description: The first way that 经过 is used as a verb is that it means "to pass by" or "to pass through." It is like saying "I went through downtown" or "I passed by the shop." As a preposition, 经过 means "to experience something" or "going through a time." It emphasizes the process of that experience. If it is talking about "going through a time," it is usually talking about the past. As a noun, 经过 refers to the process of something.

examples.zh: 我每天上班都会经过人民广场。
examples.en: I pass the People's Square every day on my way to work.

examples.zh: 你经过我家门口的时候叫我一下。
examples.en: Call me when you pass by my door.

examples.zh: 她经过这个咖啡店的时候会想到他。
examples.en: She thinks about him when she walks past this cafe.

examples.zh: 经过自己的努力，她考上了北京大学。
examples.en: After all of her hard work, she was admitted into Peking University.

examples.zh: 经过两个月的准备，他顺利地通过了这次面试。
examples.en: After two months of preparation, he successfully passed the job interview.

examples.zh: 经过调查，我们发现他跟这件事真的没有关系。
examples.en: After investigating, we found out that he had nothing to do with this.

examples.zh: 经过这几年的发展，我老家发生了很大变化。
examples.en: After the last few years of development, my hometown has changed a lot.

examples.zh: 经过一个月的培训，他对公司的业务已经比较熟悉了。
examples.en: After going through a month of training, our staff is well prepared.

examples.zh: 请你跟我们说一下当时的经过。
examples.en: Please tell us a little about that process.

examples.zh: 事情的真实经过谁都不知道。
examples.en: No one knows the actual course of events.

duokuiPattern.description: 多亏(duōkuī) can be translated as "thanks to" and is used to express that, due to somebody's help, a negative result has been averted. 了 is often placed after it as it's about something in the past. Note that 多亏(duōkuī) can be placed in the beginning or the middle. You can add in 不然 for an "otherwise... (this really bad thing would have happened)" explanation. When the good outcome comes before 多亏, there is no need to add in 才. But if the good outcome comes after 多亏, you need to add in 才 to indicate "as a result...(the good outcome happened)."

examples.zh: 多亏了大家的帮助！
examples.en: Thanks to everyone's help!

examples.zh: 我的问题能这么快解决，多亏了他的人脉关系。
examples.en: Thanks to his connections, I can solve my problem so soon.

examples.zh: 你没迟到，多亏了她的车。
examples.en: Thanks to her car, you were not late to get there.

examples.zh: 这件事情多亏了你的提醒，不然我肯定忘了。
examples.en: Thank you for your reminding me about this matter! Otherwise I would definitely forget.

examples.zh: 多亏你送她去医院了，不然她的情况会很严重。
examples.en: Thanks to you taking her to the hospital, otherwise her condition can be really severe.

examples.zh: 多亏了你的建议，不然我还不知道怎么办.
examples.en: Thanks to your advice, otherwise I still don't know what to do about it.

examples.zh: 多亏了你的车，我才没迟到.
examples.en: Thanks to your car, I'm not late to get here.

examples.zh: 多亏了你的介绍，我才有机会认识他.
examples.en: Thanks to your introduction, I get the chance to meet him.

examples.zh: 多亏你帮我，我才能这么快做完。
examples.en: Thanks for your help, I can finish doing it so soon.

haoxiangPattern.description: To express "seems," the word 好像 (hǎoxiàng) can be used.

examples.zh: 他们好像要结婚了。
examples.en: They seem to be getting married.

examples.zh: 小猫好像饿了。
examples.en: The small cat seems to be hungry.

examples.zh: 好像要下雨了。
examples.en: It seems like it's going to rain.

examples.zh: 你好像很生我的气。
examples.en: You seem to be getting very upset with me.

yiweiPattern.description: In English, the verb "to think" can imply that the belief is incorrect, e.g. in "I thought it was legal here." Chinese has a specific verb for this kind of mistaken belief: 以为 (yǐwéi). Literally these two characters mean "take to be," i.e. someone takes one thing to be something else.

examples.zh: 我以为他是英国人。
examples.en: I thought he is British.

examples.zh: 我们以为只有家人知道。
examples.en: We thought only family members know.

examples.zh: 我以为中国电影在美国很受欢迎。
examples.en: I thought Chinese movies are very popular in the USA.

examples.zh: 所有人都以为你才二十岁！
examples.en: Everybody thought you're only twenty.

examples.zh: 我以为你们分手了。
examples.en: I thought you guys broke up.

examples.zh: 我们都以为你生气了。
examples.en: We all thought you were angry.

examples.zh: 老师以为学生都听懂了。
examples.en: The teacher thought students all understood.

examples.zh: 大家都以为他是大老板。
examples.en: Everybody thought he's the big boss.

examples.zh: 她是你外婆？我以为是你妈妈。
examples.en: She's your grandma? I thought she's your mother.

examples.zh: 你怎么会去吃四川火锅？我以为你不爱吃辣。
examples.en: Why would you go to Sichuan hotpot? I thought you don't like eating spicy food.

examples.zh: 从我家走到这里需要通过两座桥。
examples.en: To get here from my house, I have to cross two bridges.

examples.zh: 你往前走，通过一个红色的大门，然后左拐就看到了。
examples.en: Go straight ahead, go through a red door, turn left, and you'll see it.

examples.zh: 我通过了这次考试。
examples.en: I passed this test.

examples.zh: 纽约大学通过了我的申请。
examples.en: New York University went through my application.

examples.zh: 他没通过那家公司的面试。
examples.en: He didn't pass the interview by that company.

examples.zh: 我们是通过他的朋友找到他的。
examples.en: We found him via his friends.

examples.zh: 通过这次调查，我们发现很多员工对新政策都不满意。
examples.en: Through this survey, we found many employees are not very satisfactory about the new policy.

examples.zh: 通过参加这个活动，大家互相都更了解了。
examples.en: Through attending this activity, everyone knows more about each other.

doingSomethingLessWithShaoPattern.description: Often heard when scolding or giving advice (like when parents talk to children) is 少 (shǎo), which can mean "to do less of something."

examples.zh: 废话少说！
examples.en: Speak less nonsense!

examples.zh: 你应该少抽烟！
examples.en: You should smoke less!

examples.zh: 学中文的学生需要少说英文。
examples.en: Students learning Chinese need to speak English less.

doingSomethingMoreWithDuoPattern.description: In China, you often hear you should do this or that more (eat more, drink more water, wear more warm clothing etc.), and they often use the word 多 (duō). What's not intuitive to learners is that the word 多 should come before the verb.

examples.zh: 多吃点。
examples.en: Eat a little more.

examples.zh: 多喝热水。
examples.en: Drink more hot water.

examples.zh: 多喝啤酒吧！
examples.en: Drink some more beer!

examples.zh: 我应该多运动。
examples.en: I should exercise more.

expressingMustWithDeiPattern.description: Learning how to use 得 to mean "must" must be done by those wishing to master Chinese!

examples.zh: 时间不早了，我得回家了。
examples.en: It's getting late. I have to go home.

examples.zh: 你病得太严重了，得去看医生。
examples.en: You are badly ill. You need to go see a doctor.

examples.zh: 朋友们都在等，我们得走了。
examples.en: Our friends are waiting, we need to go.

examples.zh: 我没带钥匙，你得回来帮我开门。
examples.en: I forgot my keys. You need to come back to help me open the door.

structures: 想 + Verb (+ Obj.) + 就 + Verb (+ Obj.)
想 + Verb + Question Word + 就 + Verb + Question Word
expressingAsOneLikesWithJiuPattern.description: When we want to express "to do something as one pleases," we can use the "想 + verb +就 + verb" form.

examples.zh: 你想来就来。
examples.en: If you want to come, come.

examples.zh: 想唱就大声唱。
examples.en: If you want to sing, sing loudly.

examples.zh: 想做就做，不想做就别做。
examples.en: Do what you want to do, don't do what you don't want to do.

examples.zh: 想去哪儿就去哪儿。
examples.en: Wherever you want to go, go there.

examples.zh: 你想吃什么就吃什么，我无所谓。
examples.en: Eat whatever you want, I don't care.

examples.zh: 我想怎样就怎样，不关你的事。
examples.en: I will do it how I want to do it. It has nothing to do with you.

structures: 哪儿 / 哪里 + 都 + Verb Phrase
什么 时候 + 都 + Verb Phrase
多少 (+ Noun) + 都 + Verb Phrase
everyDouPattern.description: This grammar point is not about how to use 每 (měi) to mean "every," but rather how to combine question words with 都 (dōu) to make words and phrases like "everywhere" or "everyone." You may have learned this same pattern for expressing "everything," but now it's time to extend it.

examples.zh: 谁都喜欢美食。
examples.en: Everyone likes delicious food.

examples.zh: 这个地方谁都可以进。
examples.en: Everyone can go inside this place.

examples.zh: 谁都不相信他说的话。
examples.en: No one believes what he said.

examples.zh: 谁都不希望发生这样的事。
examples.en: No one wants this kind of thing to happen.

examples.zh: 谁都没办法证明他拿了公司的钱。
examples.en: No one can prove that he took the company's money.

examples.zh: 你家太乱了，哪儿都是脏衣服。
examples.en: Your place is so messy. Dirty clothes are everywhere.

examples.zh: 昨天运动得太厉害了，现在哪儿都疼。
examples.en: I exercised too strenuously yesterday. Now everywhere hurts.

examples.zh: 我太累了，哪儿都不想去。
examples.en: I'm too tired. I don't want to go anywhere.

examples.zh: 你什么时候来都行。
examples.en: You can come anytime.

examples.zh: 什么时候开始都不晚。
examples.en: It's never too late to begin.

examples.zh: 我家什么时候都有人在。
examples.en: There is always someone at home.

examples.zh: 多少钱都买不到这个东西。
examples.en: You can't buy this thing at any price.

examples.zh: 你想吃多少都可以。
examples.en: You can eat however much you want.

examples.zh: 这些是免费的，我们拿多少都没问题。
examples.en: These are all free. We can take however much we want.

examples.zh: 我想怎么做都可以吗？
examples.en: Is it OK if I do however I want?

examples.zh: 别人怎么想都不重要。
examples.en: It doesn't matter however other people think.

examples.zh: 这件衣服怎么穿都好看。
examples.en: This clothing looks good however you wear it.

xiaquPattern.description: 下去 (xiàqù) is one of the most often heard result complements. 下去 can be used as a result complement to talk about things continuing or carrying on. Think of it as a figurative way of "keeping the ball rolling" (downhill).

examples.zh: 这个故事太无聊了，我听不下去了。
examples.en: This story is too boring, I can't keep listening to it.

examples.zh: 这个菜很难吃,我吃不下去。
examples.en: This food is disgusting, I can't keep eating it.

examples.zh: 这个电影画面太残忍了，我看不下去了！
examples.en: This scene in the movie is too cruel, I can't keep watching it.

qilaiPattern.description: 起来 (qǐlái) comes up very frequently in Chinese and can be used both literally and figuratively. This is a little like the usage of "up" in English which can be used literally, as in "stand up," or figuratively, as in "add up."

examples.zh: 请大家站起来。
examples.en: Everyone, please stand up.

examples.zh: 快把地上的书捡起来。
examples.en: Quickly pick up the books on the floor.

examples.zh: 你怎么不把老人扶起来？
examples.en: Why didn't you keep the old man upright?

examples.zh: 别动！把手举起来。
examples.en: Don't move! Put your hands up.

examples.zh: 大家笑起来了。
examples.en: Everyone started laughing.

examples.zh: 宝宝哭起来了。
examples.en: The baby started crying.

examples.zh: 两个大妈吵起来了。
examples.en: Two middle-aged ladies started arguing.

examples.zh: 他的病好起来了。
examples.en: His illness is starting to get better.

examples.zh: 他看起来很友好。
examples.en: He looks very friendly.

examples.zh: 这件事情听起来有点复杂。
examples.en: This matter sounds a little bit complex.

examples.zh: 你点的菜尝起来不错。
examples.en: The dishes that you ordered taste good .

examples.zh: 这件衣服摸起来很舒服。
examples.en: These clothes feel very comfortable.
